chunks.original_text: 法事升坛千众集，香云结盖万神朝。 从兹降福禳禳满，一县潜推百祸消。 过盖公岘山 岘石崎岖马不禁，溪风萧飒虎难寻。 山横剑戟参差大，气郁烟霞晻蔼深。 道众不游闲景色，天涯都是好丛林。 因循北海修黄箓，宛转东莱谒翠岑。 避事过盖公岘 乘闲杖策蹑仙踪，度石穿林望盖公。 西海有云波惨澹，东山初日气蒙鸿。 崎岖万壑深港迹，牢落三州暗转蓬。 出处自非心染着，从教着棒打虚空。 骤雨 万迭浓云霭霭屯，千寻白雨下山门。 阴阳气激风雷急，草木声号宇宙昏。 乌兽相迷烟惨惨，鱼龙交错水浑浑。 一时造化惊天地，咫尺中间孰见根。 季冬八日大雪二首 昨夜南风又北风，晓来天地一蒙鸿。 零珠碎玉随高下，万壑千岩合异同。 日月不知安顿处，山川塞在杳冥中。 返观性命阴阳理，始识虚无造化功。 昨夜南风又北风，晓来天地一蒙鸿。 山村野店家家异，柳絮梅花处处同。 石室松堂云敛后，瑶台琼榭月明中。 何须更问丰年瑞，祇此深佳大道功。 酬同知定海军节度使张侯雪中见访二首 法宇沉沉不下帏，清斋兀兀坐忘机。 纷纷满地天花落，浩浩盈山海月微。 淡日悠扬金殿晓，冲风散漫玉尘飞。 三冬瑞雪真嘉庆，万古何人识是非。 瑞雪飘飘野兴浓，开门杖策久从容。 贪看六出瑶花坠，不觉三清宝殿封。 暗室郊原彰玉马，斜拖阙角隐金龙。 高人冷冽寒岩下，莫辨遥山第几重。 竹轩太虚观也 小轩幽槛不栽花，只种琅玕主岁华。 直节自非凡草木，虚心真合道生涯。 风吹瑟瑟香还冷，雨洗涓涓净更嘉。 不待岁寒方见重，吟窗朝夕思无邪。 登临有感 陆彼高岗马足跷，观乎大地我心摇。 山河气象连天阔，洞府神仙避世遥。 白玉黄金终莫守，春花秋月固难饶。 百年一觉浮生梦，万事俱非恨寂寥。 〔赠刘师鲁〕二首 定海军节度使致政，刘师鲁挈其子见访于栖霞太虚观。 数骑翩翩出郡城，西风摇荡菊花清。 吟诗马上无横槊，访道人间暂濯缨。 露下天高秋气爽，金声玉振晓霞明。 山堂尽日萧然坐，似觉浮生梦且轻。 师鲁先生有宴息之所，榜曰中室。 又从而索诗。 一阴一阳之谓道，太过不及俱失中。
chunks.translated_text:
**Ritual Ascends the Altar, a Thousand Gather**
Incense clouds weave a canopy as myriad spirits pay homage.
From this moment, blessings descend and misfortunes disperse,
A whole county stealthily shifts—hundreds of calamities vanish.

**Passing Mount Gongxian**
Gongxian’s jagged rocks forbid the horse’s tread,
Valley winds sigh, tigers elude the seeker’s gaze.
Mountains bristle like swords and halberds, vast and uneven,
Qi thickens in mist and haze, deep and obscure.
The Daoist throng does not idle to admire the scenery—
Every horizon is but a fine grove of trees.
Thus we proceed from the North Sea’s Yellow Register rites,
Wending eastward to Lai to pay homage at Emerald Peak.

**Avoiding Affairs, Passing Mount Gongxian**
Leisurely staff in hand, I tread the immortal’s trail,
Crossing stones and threading woods toward Master Gai.
The Western Sea’s clouds churn darkly,
The Eastern Mountains’ dawn sun veils the wild geese.
Ten thousand ravines twist in deep, hidden paths,
Three prefectures drift like tumbleweeds in the gloom.
In action or retreat, the heart remains unstained—
Let the staff strike empty space at will.

**Sudden Rain**
Myriad layers of dense clouds mass,
A thousand fathoms of white rain plunge from the mountain gate.
Yin and yang clash, wind and thunder rage,
Grasses and trees wail as the cosmos darkens.
Birds and beasts lose their way in the gloom,
Fish and dragons entwine in turbid waters.
In this instant, creation startles heaven and earth—
Who perceives the root within a hand’s span?

**Two Poems on the Great Snow of the Eighth Day of Late Winter**

**I**
Last night the south wind shifted to the north,
By dawn, heaven and earth were veiled in wild geese’s flight.
Scattered pearls and shattered jade follow high and low,
Ten thousand ravines and a thousand peaks merge in sameness.
Sun and moon know not where to settle,
Mountains and rivers are sealed in boundless obscurity.
Only in returning to observe the principles of yin and yang and life’s nature
Do I recognize the workings of emptiness and creation.

**II**
Last night the south wind shifted to the north,
By dawn, heaven and earth were veiled in wild geese’s flight.
Mountain hamlets and rustic inns differ house by house,
Willow fluff and plum blossoms are alike everywhere.
Clouds withdraw from pine halls and stone chambers,
Jade terraces and crystal pavilions gleam in the moonlight.
Why inquire further of the omen of a bountiful year?
This profound beauty is the very work of the Great Dao.

**Two Poems in Response to Prefect Zhang of Dinghai Commandery’s Visit in the Snow**

**I**
The ritual hall lies deep, its curtains undrawn,
In pure fasting, I sit in stillness, oblivious to schemes.
Heavenly flowers drift down in profusion,
The sea’s moon glows faintly over the vast mountains.
The pale sun drifts through the golden hall at dawn,
The piercing wind scatters jade-like dust in flight.
This auspicious snow of midwinter is true joy—
Yet through the ages, who discerns right from wrong?

**II**
Auspicious snow flutters, my rustic mood runs deep,
I open the gate, staff in hand, lingering at ease.
Greedily watching the six-petaled jade flowers fall,
I fail to notice the Three Clarities’ halls sealed in snow.
Dark fields and plains reveal jade steeds,
The palace’s eaves trail golden dragons in concealment.
Amid the cold crags, the lofty one stands—
Which distant peak is the first, the second, or the third?

**The Bamboo Pavilion of the Great Void Abbey**
This small pavilion’s secluded balustrade bears no flowers,
Only jade-green bamboo, sovereign of the year’s splendor.
Its upright stalks are no common grass or tree,
Its hollow heart truly befits the Daoist’s livelihood.
The wind’s soughing brings a chill fragrance,
The rain’s cleansing leaves it purer still.
It need not wait for the year’s cold to prove its worth—
By my chanting window, morning and night, it embodies flawless integrity.

**Reflections on Climbing Heights**
I urge my horse up the high ridge, its hooves unsteady,
Gazing upon the vast earth, my heart trembles.
Mountains and rivers stretch boundless to the sky,
Grotto heavens and immortals dwell far from the world.
White jade and yellow gold are never truly held,
Spring blossoms and autumn moons are never truly possessed.
A hundred years pass like a fleeting dream of floating life—
All things prove illusory, leaving only regret’s desolation.

**Two Poems for Master Liu Shiru**
Prefect of Dinghai Commandery, retired from office, Master Liu Shiru visits with his son at the Great Void Abbey in Qixia.

**I**
Several riders lightly depart the prefectural city,
The west wind sways, chrysanthemums gleam pure.
Reciting poems on horseback, no lance in hand,
I seek the Dao among men, briefly washing my cap strings.
Dew falls, the sky soars, autumn’s air is crisp,
Golden chimes and jade vibrations brighten the dawn clouds.
All day in the mountain hall, I sit in tranquil solitude—
As if sensing the floating life’s dream grow faint.

**II**
Master Shiru has a retreat for rest and repose, named the Central Chamber.
He further requests a poem.

That which is called the Dao is the interplay of yin and yang,
Excess or deficiency alike miss the mean.

chunks.original_text: 道贯三乘玄莫测，中包万有体无穷。 高人未悟犹占僻，下士能明便发蒙。 儒释道源三教祖，由来千圣古今同。 次韵答奉圣州节度使移刺仲泽佳什 忘机不用苦清谈，大隐何烦住小庵。 海印发光吞宝月，天心烛物迈寒潭。 黄庭雅弄琴三迭，紫府高吟酒半酣。 西北文章贤太守，肯将珠玉寄东南。 送蓬莱州节度使邹应中移镇兖州 人生七十古来稀，不夜功成赋式微。 便欲休官栽菊去，还令杖节与心违。 行藏未出阴阳数，夙夜难逃变化机。 异日挂冠须在早，莫教林下有人讥。 赞道 造物悠扬气势雄，三光日夜转鸿蒙。 冥冥会合阴阳秀，矫矫神奇幻化丛。 春去秋来生杀异，天长地久古今同。 灵台有个真消息，未悟那堪性不通。 达士 随机接物外同尘，应变无方内入神。 心地出离三界苦，洞天游赏四时春。 金丹大药经年久，火枣交梨逐日新。 一服定超生死梅，不知谁是有缘人。 灵虚观赏梨花 妙景从来说武官，周天回斡暮春看。 千株白锦霜凝雪，一派香风吐麝兰。 羽客徘徊升月榭，高真依约下星坛。 神功暗结灵虚秀，化作无边碎玉团。 旧游 秦川渭水好行程，不问长亭及短亭。 西岳云开仙掌白，南山雨过佛头青。 丹霄仿髴舒晨彩，碧岫参差列画屏。 海上交朋闻我道，虚心侧耳尽来听。 磻溪集卷之一竟 磻溪集卷之二
chunks.translated_text:
**The Dao Encompasses the Three Vehicles**
The Dao encompasses the Three Vehicles, its mystery unfathomable,
At its center it embraces the myriad existences, its essence boundless.
The lofty man, though yet unenlightened, still seeks seclusion,
While the lesser scholar, once awakened, casts off ignorance.

The founders of the Three Teachings—Confucian, Buddhist, Daoist—
From ancient times to now, a thousand sages share one source.

**Matching Rhymes in Reply to Prefect of Fengsheng Commandery, Yila Zhongze’s Fine Verse**
No need for idle chatter, abandoning worldly schemes,
The great hermit need not dwell in a humble hut.
The ocean’s reflection shines, swallowing the jeweled moon,
The heart of heaven illuminates all things, outshining the cold pool.

In the *Yellow Court*, elegant strains rise in tripled melody,
In the *Purple Palace*, lofty verses flow with half-drunken joy.
O learned governor of the northwest, master of letters—
Would you deign to send your pearls and jade to the southeast?

**Seeing Off Prefect of Penglaizhou, Zou Yingzhong, Transferred to Yanzhou**
Since ancient times, few live to seventy,
Yet your deeds shine bright before twilight’s decline.
You long to retire, to plant chrysanthemums and depart,
But the imperial staff still commands, thwarting your heart’s desire.

Your course remains bound by the reckoning of yin and yang,
Day and night, you cannot escape the workings of change.
One day, when you doff your cap, do so early—
Lest those in the groves have cause to mock your delay.

**In Praise of the Dao**
Creation’s grandeur sways in boundless might,
The Three Luminaries turn through primal chaos day and night.
In darkness, yin and yang converge in splendor,
In wondrous transformation, spirits soar in myriad forms.

Spring departs, autumn arrives—life and death diverge,
Yet heaven endures, earth persists, ancient and now the same.
Within the numinous terrace lies a true message—
Without awakening, how can one’s nature be unobstructed?

**The Enlightened Scholar**
Adapting to circumstances, he meets the world yet remains dust-free,
Responding without fixed form, his inner spirit attains mastery.
His mind transcends the three realms’ suffering,
Roaming the grotto-heavens, he enjoys eternal spring.

The Golden Elixir, the great medicine, ripens over years,
Fire-jujubes and celestial pears renew with each passing day.
One dose ensures transcendence beyond life and death’s plum—
Who, then, is the destined one?

**Viewing Pear Blossoms at Lingxu Abbey**
This wondrous sight, they say, belongs to the martial temple,
As the heavens revolve, we behold it in late spring.
A thousand trees of white brocade, frost congealed as snow,
A single breeze of fragrance breathes forth musk and orchid.

Feathered guests wander, ascending the moonlit pavilion,
Lofty immortals descend, as if from the starry altar.
The abbey’s numinous beauty silently takes form—
Transformed into boundless fragments of scattered jade.

**Former Travels**
The road through Qin’s plains and Wei’s waters was fair,
No need to ask of long pavilions or short.
When clouds part over Western Peak, the Immortal’s Palm gleams white,
When rain passes Southern Mountain, the Buddha’s Crown shines green.

The cinnabar dawn seems to unfurl its morning hues,
Jagged emerald peaks stand like painted screens.
Friends beyond the sea, hearing of my Dao,
Listen with open hearts, ears inclined.

*End of Volume One of the* Panxi Collection

chunks.translated_text:
**Seven-Character Quatrains by Qiu Chuji, the Ever-Spring Master of Mount Qixia**

**[Ritual Rectification]**
The folk of Guanzhong are simple and sincere,
Many incline toward goodness.
Daoists revere the seventh [month],
Buddhists turn the eighth [wheel].
Each year’s end, they gather in great numbers,
After noon, before the sacred icons, they chant scriptures and repent—
This is called *Ritual Rectification*.
Only when the month concludes does it end.

Snow clears, spring’s light reveals great peace,
Wind gentle, sun warm—all the brighter.
Sing high in assembly, cast off melancholy,
Boil round cakes crisp for *Ritual Rectification*.

**In Reply to Scholar Fan**
Ask not how the threads of fate are woven,
Only cultivate hidden virtue, thoughts ever renewed.
Human sentiments shift like the Dao of immortals—
In daily practice, exert all your strength.

**For Daoist Friend Liu the Second**
This man loves wine and chess.
When merry, he drinks a thousand cups of wine,
In stillness, he plays a game of chess.
White-haired years should serve as a distant mirror,
Red-dust trifles—know them not too well.

**Two Poems Admonishing Qiang of Jingyang**
Su Qin, Lu Jia—all return to emptiness,
Through the ages, the wise wake from one dream.
How much better to forget cunning and seal the lips,
Silently seize the nine-heaven wind!

A hundred years, ten thousand affairs—all a void,
Swift as a fleeting shadow through a crack.
Why do men of the floating world not awaken?
Foolish hearts still grasp at spring’s breeze.

**To Layman Yang the Fifth**
I wished to send a poem, but paper was lacking,
Sifting through scrolls, I found an old letter.
After it, I earnestly inscribed a quatrain,
Urging you: do good, do not hesitate.

**Returning the Paper Fan Bestowed by Yang the Fifth**
Grateful for your gift of white banana-leaf fan,
In mountain valleys, winds rise without summons.
In the city’s scorching days, no cool air comes—
I beg you, hold it and leisurely wave.

**In Reply to Scholar Qiao**
Newly widowed, he seeks to still his heart and enter the Dao.
Beyond the world, his heart returns, cutting off the great demon,
In leisure, he sings even more loftily.
The mind’s terrace now bears few desires,
His sturdy bones will ride the wind in days to come.

**Inscribed on Yang the Fifth’s Paper Fan**
Towering peaks press against the heavens,
Precipitous cliffs, distant mists clinging.
Since ancient times, visitors to Mount Song,
Haughty immortals of Mount Hua.

**Inscribed on Scholar Wang’s Paper Fan**
I love the boundless sky, summer days long,
Who hates the cruel heat, the blazing clouds?
The triple-burner’s toxic heat, years of it, now gone—
One grasp of cool wind brings eternal chill.

**Inscribed on Scholar Qiao’s Paper Fan**
Fiery sun, flying clouds of flame,
Wayfarers on the road bathe in sweat.
In the deep green caves of the mountains, carefree guests
Recline beneath pines, playing chess at ease.

**Inscribed on Wang the Second’s Paper Fan**
After the *Ruibin* [fifth lunar month] heat grows fiercer,
Toxic warmth steams, nowhere to hide.
Only in the emerald caves of Ever-Spring Mountain
Does coolness linger all day, naturally serene.

**Inscribed on Zhou Daoquan’s Paper Fan**
Stream winds sigh like descending frost,
Gully waters ripple like churning snow.
All day, no toil or burden weighs—
When will stifling heat return?

**Inscribed on Madam Pang’s Rattan Fan**
Delicate patterns woven in silver threads,
Gentle breezes scatter jade-like grace.
Though autumn’s gales bring crispness,
For you, it will not be long.

**Chen Family Thatched Hall by the Luo River**
A thatched hall stands high in half the grove’s shade,
Tall trees, uneven, deep green bamboo.
No sound of carriages or horses—fame and profit far,
In quietude all day, the heart finds rest.

**Scholar Duan’s Raft Lost to Rising Waters**
Scholar Duan launched his raft down Western Mountain,
Just as waves surged, sweeping all beyond the pass.
Turning back, he bore no grudge against the River Lord,
Singing high, rejoicing in his light return.

**Flying Immortals**
Penglai, Fangzhang, and Yingzhou,
The three isles’ immortals wander as one.
Merged with the nine heavens, no hindrance,
They soar through the eight directions, freely roaming.

**Painting of Zhong and Lü**
No self, no other—nature free,
Master and disciple converse in harmony.
Expounding scriptures, teaching Dharma on the three mountains,
Riding mists, soaring clouds, a thousand miles they roam.

**Two Poems on Dwelling in Mount Jingfu**
Tigers roar in fierce winds, beasts startle,
Demons meet in long nights, sleep’s soul trembles.
When will the simple and upright Dao-heart appear?
The sun of wisdom dawns, the heavenly eye opens.

Jingfu’s depths, worldly affairs few,
Dragon Gate’s tranquility, Tiger Creek’s clarity.
At times, the cry of the red pheasant—*jieguo jiazha*—
Like the creaking of an axle’s lock.

A kind of red pheasant in the mountains
Makes the sound *jieguo jiazha*.
Woodcutters entering the hills
Joke that it is "snow settled."
The descending call turns to *goujia gezhe*—
The partridge’s cry.

**Four Poems Expressing My Aspirations**
I seek the Dao, letting my spirit roam free,
At Dragon Gate, tigers now and then intrude.
On mountain peaks, fierce fires blaze in midwinter,
In ravine depths, yin winds chill the fifth month.

The subtle principle of pure emptiness spans the world,
The great simplicity’s honest breeze fills the age.
The supreme Dao has a name—where is its reality?
The enlightened speak not, yet know and return.

The root of entering the Dao lies in self-commitment,
Who knows the message of transcending the dust?
First, *Nanhua* brings carefree joy,
Finally, the boundless sea meets its vast appointment.

Wild cranes, solitary clouds—my livelihood,
Cool winds, bright moon—my Daoist life.
A thousand mountains, piled high, gather cloud and mist,
The four seas, radiant, gleam with sunlight.

**Four Poems on Yang of Longzhou Bringing Moon Osmanthus to Visit**
Buried in dust, how pitiable,
Following worldly ways for years.
By chance, a noble scholar roams hills and waters,
Meeting lofty immortals, companions of sages.

A lone branch, elegant, leans on cold mountains,
All flowers of the four seas bow in shame.
If it meets a fine wind and auspicious air,
Heavenly fragrance will drift through the world.

From first breath, it received the true essence,
Passing on splendor, linking fragrance like fire.
Among the world’s hundred flowers, none rivals the moon,
Only this can endure through the ages.

Dense trees, high mountains, hidden in the earth,
Many winds, little dew—fearing the cold sky.
One day, it will return to the Moon Palace,
Where the five peaks gather clouds, the four seas gaze.

**Releasing a Hawk**
Let it fly, rivaling Zhi Dun’s crane,
Never cage it like Wang Xizhi’s goose.
Though it matches Zhuangzi’s "crying for justice,"
Beware it learns Mao’s immortal’s love-demons.

**Clear Dream Pavilion in Longzhou Hall**
In Clear Dream Pavilion, pure scholars dwell,
In tranquil leisure, they nurture true suchness.
When true suchness is nurtured, dreams grow clear,
Dreamless, pure joy abounds.

No need to ask of long pavilions or short.
When clouds part over Western Peak, the Immortal’s Palm gleams white,
When rain passes Southern Mountain, the Buddha’s Crown shines green.

The cinnabar dawn seems to unfurl its morning hues,

chunks.translated_text:
**Reply to Magistrate Xiao of Longzhou’s Summons**

Parting from Long Mountain on business,
I passed through Tingchuan to Shihui Temple,
lingering for days—my resolve yet unformed.
Then your letter arrived, and joyfully I returned.
Soon came word of your honored appointment at the Qianyuan frontier,
and I longed to rest in quietude beneath Longxi’s skies.
The yellow crane scorns a thousand-mile flight,
while white clouds still cling to their old mountain perch.

**Gazing Back at Longmen Mountain from the Road After Returning from Tingchuan**

Southward, Longmen gapes wide in a single cleft,
as the crane-borne immortal turns his head once more.
Deeply I know this place’s weight of karmic ties—
no other land could encompass such virtue and power.

**Reply to the Recluse of Rest-and-Rest, Summoned by Princess Cao**

Mountains and hidden ravines are no mark of loftiness;
I examine my heart and find it clouded, benighted.
Vain fame brings only confusion and entanglement—
better to sit idle, nurturing blindness and deafness.

**Reply to the Military Commissioner of Jingzhao, Jiagu Longhu’s Summons**

Just as the Recluse of Rest-and-Rest was about to depart,
the illustrious prince and marquis arrived in turn.
I am ashamed to find no Daoist arts within my heart,
only my outer traces scattered like dust.

**To Master Yunwai’s Disciple Sun Keda, Traveling to the West to Spread the Dao**

In the western lands, many turn toward the Dao,
yet the Daoist’s comings and goings are full of error.
You must tread the rugged path through mountain prefectures,
vigilant lest heterodox demons arise.

**Sent to Magistrate Rong of Fufeng**

When the heart is true, even fish scales grow vast;
why begrudge a horse’s bones their towering height?
If your dwelling holds sincerity, trust will follow—
without wisdom, descending the hall is but empty toil.

**Compassion**

A sick dog, none to brew its porridge;
a freezing donkey, stiff-limbed on the ground.
If one fails to cultivate hidden virtue in life,
how can the turning shell escape calamity?

chunks.original_text: 日月匆匆顶上飞，光阴匆匆眼前移。 回头返顾即成老，下手速修犹太迟。 聪明 修行大抵要聪明，祇恐聪明同外呈。 外假内真两相克，一边败后一边成。 弃本逐末 一念无生即自由，千灾散尽复何忧。 不堪下劣众生性，日夜奔驰向外求。 进呈世宗皇帝 九重天子人间贵，十极仙灵象外尊。 试问一方终日守，何如万里即时奔。 答宁海书召 雪满群山路不通，天教车马不西东。 可怜宁海官民意，目断西山一望空。 闻韶起玉阳公戏作 三竿红日自由睡，万顷白云相对闲。 只恐虚名动华阙，有妨高枕卧青山。 春晚登眺 残花冉冉飞红雨，落日依依散白毫。 遥望西山官堠子，倚天孤耸一拳高。 春寒 海上春风日日颠，山头春色几时妍。 清朋过了朱明近，未有红芳到眼前。 阳九百六 劫运天灾不可当，高真上圣救无方。 直须受尽丰年孽，再得升平入道场 公山十四首 余乡公山之阳，故作是诗。 公山隐隐插苍穹，松影森森锁碧空。 顶戴松花吃松子，松溪和月饮松风。 松风习习透松烟，习习松烟散九天。 天外轻盈笼万象，交光日月共回旋。 千寻瀑布清明秀，一派岚光气势雄。 时被祥风吹作雨，潇潇溟漠洒虚空。 青城华岳与天台，怎比吾山至大哉。 一簇峰峦千万仞，威仪真不让蓬莱。 公山高隐白云宫，宫压公山第一峰。 峰上白云飞不断，悠悠来去惹青松。 参差山色有无中，半入幽溟半入空。 依约天涯寻不见，飘飘常被白云笼。 公山自古白云多，结盖层层入大罗。 出没群仙常不见，云中唯听洞仙歌。 仙歌缥缈入公山，渐入公山太一坛。 坛上诸仙安药鼎，时时烧出大还丹。 撞开天汉拂星辰，独坐蟾宫抱日轮。 夜牧灵龟朝引鹤，饥餐松实冷披云。 山头点起一轮灯，天下妖魔尽不生。 唯有堂堂圆觉士，松间独弄宝珠行。 公山春 闲遣青龙褥月华，同驱白虎种黄芽。 黄芽欲发雷霆震，迸出青龙白虎牙。 公山夏 阳光泼泼火云凝，海底蛟笼即上升。 徧撮山头三伏暑，却教化作一团水。 公山秋 云兴霞烁映天衢，松密山高压地图。 绝顶峥嵘人不到，昭昭独放月轮孤。 公山冬 同云漠漠雪霏霏，凛冽寒风刮地威。 吹起山中无限景，瑶花琼萼满天飞。 〔牢山吟〕二十首 东莱即墨之牢山，三围大海，背俯（或作负）平川，巨石巍峨，群峰峭拔，真洞天福地，一方之胜境也。 然僻於海曲，举世鲜闻，其名亦不佳。 予自昌阳醮罢，抵於王城永真观，南望烟霭之间，隐隐而见。 道众相邀，迁延数日而方届。 遂闲吟二十首，易为鳌山，因清畅道风云耳。 卓荦鳌山出海隅，霏微灵秀满天衢。 群峰削蜡几千仞，乱石穿空一万株。 道祖二宫南镇海，谓上清宫、太清宫也。 王明三崮北当途。 谓太平兴国观道南也。 是知物外仙游境，不向人间作昼图。 初观山色有无时，十日迁延尚未之。 咫尺洞天行不到，空余吟咏满囊诗。 浮烟积翠这山城，迭嶂层峦簇画屏。 造物建标东枕海，云舒霞卷日冥冥。 三围大海一平田，下镇金鳌上接天。 日夜潮头风辊雪，彩霞深处有飞仙。 佳山福地隐仙灵，万壑千岩锁洞庭。 造化不教当大路，为嫌人世苦膻腥。 牢山本即是鳌山，大海中心不可攀。 上帝欲令修道果，故移仙迹近人间。 重岗复岭势崔鬼，照眼云山翠作堆。 路转山腰三百曲，行人一步一徘徊。
chunks.translated_text:
**Time’s Flight**

Sun and moon rush past above my head,
light and shadow glide before my eyes.
Turn but once to look back—already old;
even hastening to cultivate, one acts too late.

**Wisdom**

In cultivation, wisdom is paramount,
yet fear it may show only outwardly.
Outer falsehood and inner truth clash—
one side fails as the other succeeds.

**Forsaking Root for Branch**

A single thought of no-arising brings freedom;
a thousand calamities disperse—what cause for grief?
Yet base is the nature of most beings,
who day and night race outward in pursuit.

**Presented to Emperor Shizong**

Ninefold, the Son of Heaven is earth’s noblest;
tenfold, the immortals are beyond form’s revered.
Ask this: which is better—
to guard one corner all day,
or to traverse ten thousand leagues in an instant?

**Reply to Ninghai’s Summons**

Snow blankets the mountains, paths impassable;
heaven bids carriages and horses halt east and west.
Pitiful, the intent of Ninghai’s officials and people—
their gaze fixed on Western Mountain, all in vain.

**On Hearing the Shao Music, Playfully Composed for Lord Yuyang**

Three poles high, the sun sleeps at ease;
ten thousand acres of white clouds idle in pairs.
I only fear that hollow fame may stir the palace halls,
disturbing my high-pillowed rest in the green hills.

**Late Spring Ascent**

Fading blossoms drift like crimson rain;
the setting sun scatters pale rays.
Gazing afar at Western Mountain’s watchtowers,
they stand like a fist raised against the sky.

**Spring’s Chill**

Spring winds on the sea toss daily;
when will spring’s hues grace the mountain peaks?
Pure companions have passed, the Vermilion Bright nears,
yet no crimson blossoms have touched my eyes.

**The Nine-and-Sixty Calamity**

The kalpa’s disasters, heaven’s scourges—none can withstand;
even high immortals and sages find no remedy.
One must endure the full measure of prosperous years’ retribution,
then ascend to peace and enter the Dao’s precincts.

**Fourteen Poems on Gong Mountain**

I composed these verses on the southern slopes of Gong Mountain, my homeland.

Gong Mountain looms, piercing the azure vault;
pine shadows dense, sealing the emerald sky.
Atop its crown, I wear pine blossoms, eat pine seeds,
drink by the pine stream beneath the moon, sipping pine winds.

Pine winds sigh through pine mist,
the sighing mist disperses through the nine heavens.
Beyond the sky, lightly veiling all things,
they mingle with sun and moon in shared revolution.

A thousand-fathom waterfall, bright and graceful;
a single sweep of misty light, majestic in force.
At times, auspicious winds blow it into rain,
a drizzling vastness that scatters into empty space.

Though Qingcheng, Huashan, and Tiantai stand tall,
how can they compare to my mountain’s grandeur?
A cluster of peaks, ten thousand fathoms high—
its majesty truly rivals Penglai.

Gong Mountain’s heights cradle the White Cloud Palace,
the palace pressing upon the mountain’s foremost peak.
Above the peak, white clouds drift ceaselessly,
leisurely coming and going, entwining the green pines.

Mountain hues waver between presence and absence,
half dissolving into dark depths, half into the void.
Vaguely at the sky’s edge, yet nowhere to be found—
ever drifting, ever shrouded in white clouds.

Since ancient times, Gong Mountain has known many white clouds,
layer upon layer forming a canopy into the Great Net.
Immortal hosts appear and vanish unseen,
only the songs of grotto immortals heard amid the clouds.

Ethereal immortal songs enter Gong Mountain,
gradually merging with the Great One’s altar.
Upon the altar, immortals tend their cauldrons,
ever refining the Great Return Elixir.

Striking open the Milky Way to brush the stars,
alone I sit in the Toad Palace, embracing the solar wheel.
By night I herd the sacred tortoise, by dawn I lead the crane;
hungry, I eat pine nuts; cold, I wrap myself in clouds.

Atop the mountain, I kindle a single lamp—
all demons under heaven cease to stir.
Only the steadfast, enlightened adept
walks among the pines, playing with the luminous pearl.

**Spring on Gong Mountain**

Leisurely I send the Azure Dragon to gather moonlight,
together driving the White Tiger to sow the Yellow Sprout.
When the Yellow Sprout is about to burst forth,
thunder shakes the earth—
the Azure Dragon and White Tiger’s fangs jut out.

**Summer on Gong Mountain**

Sunlight spills like fire, clouds congeal;
sea-bottom dragons coil, then ascend.
Gathering the triple summer’s heat from every mountain peak,
they transform it into a single sphere of water.

**Autumn on Gong Mountain**

Clouds surge, rosy hues gleam on heaven’s thoroughfare;
pines dense, mountains high, pressing upon the earth’s map.
At the summit’s sheer pinnacle, none tread—
only the solitary moon shines, radiant and clear.

**Winter on Gong Mountain**

Layered clouds stretch boundless, snow falls thick;
bitter winds howl, scraping the earth with force.
They stir the mountain’s endless scenes—
jade flowers, coral petals fill the sky.

**Twenty Odes on Laishan**

Laishan in Donglai’s Jimo, encircled thrice by the sea,
its back to the plains, colossal stones towering,
peaks soaring—truly a grotto-heaven blessed land,
a realm of surpassing beauty in this corner of the world.

Yet remote at the sea’s edge, few in the world know it,
and its name is not auspicious.
After concluding my rites in Changyang, I arrived at Yongzhen Abbey in Wangcheng.
Gazing south through the mist, I glimpsed it faintly.
The Daoist community urged me to stay, and after several days’ delay, I finally reached it.
Thus I composed these twenty leisurely odes, renaming it Aoshan,
to invigorate the winds of the Dao.

Aoshan rises boldly from the sea’s edge,
its subtle numinous beauty filling heaven’s thoroughfare.
Peaks carved like wax, thousands of fathoms high,
countless jagged rocks piercing the sky.

The Two Ancestral Palaces stand south, guarding the sea—
namely, the Supreme Clarity and Grand Clarity Palaces.
The Three Peaks of Wangming face north, blocking the road—
that is, the Taiping Xingguo Abbey south of the Dao.

Know then that this immortal realm beyond the world
does not deign to be mapped in daylight.

At first, the mountain’s hues wavered between presence and absence;
ten days passed in delay, yet I had not arrived.
A grotto-heaven so near, yet unreachable—
only my poems filled my satchel.

Floating mists, layered greens—this mountain city,
ridges and peaks stacked like painted screens.
Creation set its marker here, eastward resting on the sea,
where clouds unfurl and rosy hues swirl as the sun darkens.

Threefold the sea, one level field—
below it anchors the golden turtle, above it meets the sky.
Day and night, tide winds roll like snow,
and amid deep rosy clouds, flying immortals dwell.

A blessed mountain, a land of fortune, veiling immortals—
ten thousand ravines, a thousand cliffs, sealing the grotto court.
Creation did not place it along the great road,
for it disdains the world’s foul stench.

Laishan is none other than Aoshan,
unclimbable at the sea’s heart.
The Lord on High wished to perfect the Dao’s fruit,
so he moved the immortal traces near to humankind.

Layered ridges, repeated peaks—towering and jagged,
cloud-mountains dazzle the eye, emerald heaped upon emerald.
The path winds three hundred turns around the mountain’s waist—
with each step, the traveler lingers, loath to proceed.

**Sent to Magistrate Rong of Fufeng**

When the heart is true, even fish scales grow vast;
why begrudge a horse’s bones their towering height?
If your dwelling holds sincerity, trust will follow—
without wisdom, descending the hall is but empty toil.

**Compassion**

A sick dog, none to brew its porridge;
a freezing donkey, stiff-limbed on the ground.
If one fails to cultivate hidden virtue in life,
how can the turning shell escape calamity?

**Too Late to Act**

chunks.original_text: 松岩郁崛瑞烟轻，洞府深沉气象清。 怪石乱峰谁变化，亘初开辟自天成。 因持翰墨写形容，陟彼高岗二十重。 南出巨平千万迭，一层崖上一层峰。 四更山吐月犹斜，直上东峰看晓霞。 日色丽天明照海，金光射目眼生花。 天柱峰也巍峨独建标，上穿云雾入青霄。 不知日月星辰谢，但觉阴阳气候调。 洞有佳名号白龙洞也，不知何代隐仙踪。 至今万古人更变，犹自嵌岩对老松。 洞有仙名唤老君洞也，神清气爽独超群。 凭高俯视临沧海，守静安闲对白云。 华盖真人宋太祖时得道者也上碧霄，道山从此郁清标。 至今绝壁幽岩下，尚有群仙听海潮。 修真野客非才子，行到鳌山亦有诗。 只欲洞天观海日，不劳云雨待青词。 白发苍颜未了仙，游山玩水且留连。 不嫌天上多官府，只恐人间有俗缘。 修真却似上山劳，脚脚难移步步高。 若不志心生退怠，直趋天上摘蟠桃。 鳌山三面海浮空，日出扶桑照海红。 浩渺碧波千万里，尽成金色满山东。 山川皆属道生涯，万象森罗共一家。 不是圣贤潜制御，乾坤那得久光华。 可叹巍巍造化功，山河大地立虚空。 八荒四海知多少，尽在含元一气中。 〔再题牢山〕二十首 大安己已胶西醮罢，道众相邀再游鳌山，复留题二十首。 上清宫十首 醮罢归来访道山，山深地僻海湾环，棹船即向波涛看，化出蓬莱杳霭间。 群峰峭拔下临渊，绝顶孤高上倚天。 沧海古今吞日月，碧山朝夕起云烟。 青山本是道人家，况此仙山近海涯。 海阔山高无浊秽，云深地僻转清嘉。 怪石嵌空自化成，千奇万状不能名。 断崖绝壁无人到，日夜时闻仙乐声。 晓日蒙咙渐起云，山色惨澹不全真。 直须更上山头看，似驾天风出世尘。 巨石森森岭上排，巅峰岌岌到无阶。 三秋水冻层冰结，九夏云寒迭嶂霾。 海上观山势转雄，清高突兀倚虚空。 朝昏磊落生云气，变化皆由造物功。 陕右名山华狱稀，江南尤物九华奇。 鳌山下枕东洋海，秀出山东尽不知。 重重迭迭互相遮，簇簇攒攒竞斗嘉。 眼界清凉心地爽，神山自古好生涯。 五岳曾经四岳游，群山未必可相俦。 只因海角天涯背，不得高名贯九州。 太清宫十首 烟岚初别上清宫，晓色依稀路径通。 才到下方人未食，坐观山海一蒙鸿。 云烟惨澹雨霏微，石洞留人不放归。 应是洞天相顾念，一生嗟我到来稀。 云海茫茫不见涯，潮头只见浪翻花。 高峰万迭连云秀，一簇围屏是道家。 松风涧水两清幽，尽日清音夜未休。 野鹤时来应不倦，闲人欲去更相留。 溪深石大更松多，郁郁苍苍道气和。 不是历年樵采众，浮云蔽日满岩阿。 贯世高名共切云，游山上士独离群。 仙卿贵重三茅客，仕族尊荣万石君。 西山仰视刺天高，山上仙家种碧桃。 桃熟几番人换世，洞中秦女体生毛。 清歌窈袅步虚齐，月下高吟凤舞低。 谈笑不干浮世事，相将直过九天西。 烟霞紫翠白云高，洞府群仙醉碧桃。 鼓透碧岩雷震骇，满山禽兽尽呼号。 道力神功不可言，生成万化独超然。 大山海岳知轻重，没底空浮万万年。 中秋诗十五首 八月十日自昌乐县还潍州城北玉清观作。 西县东来至玉清，金风一扫暮天晴。 开怀便赏中秋月，只恐临时晦不明。 万木西风徧九州，严光一夜向西流。 出尘爽气清人骨，是处歌欢不解留。
chunks.translated_text:
Pines and crags rise steep, auspicious mist drifts light,
grotto-palaces lie deep, their qi and aspect pure.
Strange rocks and jagged peaks—who wrought their change?
From primal creation’s dawn, heaven shaped them so.

With brush and ink I sought to capture their form,
climbing those high ridges, twenty tiers in all.
Southward, vast plains stretch a thousandfold,
each layer of cliff crowned by another peak.

At the fourth watch, the mountain births the moon, still slanting,
I ascend the eastern peak to watch the dawn’s rosy clouds.
Sunlight adorns the sky, bright upon the sea,
golden rays strike the eye, dazzling like blossoms.

Heaven’s Pillar Peak stands towering, solitary,
piercing clouds and mist to enter the azure vault.
I know not when sun, moon, and stars fade,
only that yin and yang’s seasons harmonize.

A grotto bears the fine name White Dragon Grotto—
I know not which age concealed immortal traces.
To this day, through ten thousand ages of human change,
it still nestles ‘gainst the crags, facing ancient pines.

Another grotto holds the immortal name Old Lord’s Grotto—
its spirit clear, its qi fresh, peerless in transcendence.
From on high, I gaze down upon the blue-green sea,
guarding stillness, at ease, facing white clouds.

Master Hua Gai, who attained the Dao in Song Taizu’s time, ascended to the azure heavens,
and from that day, the Dao-mountain’s purity stood eminent.
Even now, beneath sheer cliffs and secluded crags,
immortals still gather to listen to the sea’s tide.

A cultivator, rustic wanderer, no man of letters,
yet upon reaching Aoshan, even I compose verse.
I seek only to behold the grotto-heaven’s sea and sun,
no need for cloud and rain, nor prayers in blue-green script.

White-haired, careworn, yet unfinished as an immortal,
I wander mountains and rivers, lingering in delight.
I do not mind the heavens’ many offices,
only fear the world’s vulgar ties.

Cultivation is like climbing a mountain—arduous,
each step hard-won, each step higher.
If the heart’s resolve does not falter or flag,
one may ascend to heaven and pluck the immortal peaches.

Aoshan’s three sides float upon the sea,
as the sun rises from Fusang, gilding the waves red.
Vast and boundless, azure waves stretch a thousand leagues,
all turned to gold, suffusing the mountain’s east.

Mountains and rivers belong to the Dao’s livelihood,
the ten thousand forms, all one family.
Were it not for sages’ hidden governance,
how could heaven and earth long endure their splendor?

I sigh at creation’s majestic work,
mountains, rivers, and earth stand in empty space.
How much fills the eight wastes and four seas?
All rests within the one qi of Primordial Harmony.

**Twenty Poems Revisiting Laishan**
*Composed in the year Da’an Jisi, after the Jiao rites in Jiaoxi, when Daoist companions invited me to revisit Aoshan, and I again inscribed twenty poems.*

**Ten Poems at Shangqing Palace**
Returning from the rites, I sought the Dao-mountain,
deep in the wilds, where the sea’s bays encircle.
Boarding a boat, I turned toward the waves,
and there, amid misty vapors, Penglai took form.

Peaks rise sheer, overhanging the abyss,
their lofty summits lean against the sky.
The blue-green sea, ancient and everlasting, swallows sun and moon,
while the azure mountains, morning and evening, birth clouds and mist.

Green mountains are the Daoist’s true home,
and here, this immortal mountain nears the sea’s edge.
The sea vast, the mountain high—no filth or foulness,
clouds deep, the land secluded—all the more refined.

Strange rocks, hollowed by time, shaped by nature,
a thousand marvels, ten thousand forms—beyond naming.
Sheer cliffs, unvisited by men,
yet day and night, strains of immortal music drift.

At dawn, the sun veiled, clouds begin to rise,
the mountain’s hues somber, not yet fully revealed.
One must climb higher to see from the peak—
as if riding heaven’s winds, leaving the dust behind.

Massive boulders stand in ranks upon the ridge,
the summit’s perilous heights—no path remains.
In late autumn, waters freeze, layered ice congeals,
in the ninth month of summer, clouds chill, peaks shrouded in haze.

Viewing the mountain from the sea, its grandeur shifts,
its purity and loftiness jut into empty space.
From dawn to dusk, boulders birth clouds,
all transformations wrought by creation’s hand.

In the west, renowned mountains like Huayue are rare,
in the south, wonders like Jiuhua stand alone.
Aoshan cradles the Eastern Ocean,
its beauty surpassing all in Shandong—yet unknown.

Peaks upon peaks, overlapping, concealing,
clustered, thronging, vying in splendor.
The eye finds cool clarity, the heart’s ground is refreshed—
since ancient times, immortal mountains have been the finest livelihood.

I have wandered the Five Peaks, journeyed the Four Sacred Mountains,
yet no range can compare.
Only because it lies at the sea’s edge, the sky’s rim,
has its lofty name not resounded through the Nine Provinces.

**Ten Poems at Taiqing Palace**
Leaving Shangqing Palace, mist and haze part,
the dawn’s light faint, the path barely discernible.
Arriving below, before men have eaten,
I sit and behold the mountain and sea—a vast expanse.

Clouds and mist dim, rain falls in fine drops,
the stone grotto detains me, will not let me go.
Perhaps the grotto-heaven takes pity,
lamenting how rarely I come.

The cloud-sea stretches boundless, no shore in sight,
only the tide’s crest, waves churning like blossoms.
High peaks, a thousand folds, linked in cloud-borne beauty,
one cluster forms a screen—this is the Daoist’s home.

Pine winds, stream waters—both pure and secluded,
their clear sounds fill the day, cease not even at night.
Wild cranes come and go, never weary,
while idle visitors wish to depart, yet are urged to stay.

The stream runs deep, stones lie vast, pines grow thick,
lush and verdant, the Dao’s qi harmonious.
Were it not for years of woodcutters’ toil,
floating clouds would veil the sun, filling the crags’ recesses.

A name renowned through the ages, soaring with the clouds,
the mountain-wandering scholar stands apart.
Immortal lords, noble as the Three Mao Masters,
official clans, honored as the Ten Thousand Stone House.

Gazing west, the mountain pierces the sky,
where immortals’ homes cultivate the azure peach.
How many times has the peach ripened, while men change worlds?
In the grotto, Qin’s maidens grow fur upon their bodies.

Clear songs, delicate as the void’s steps, rise in unison,
beneath the moon, high chants, phoenix dances dip low.
Their laughter and talk touch not the floating world’s affairs,
together they pass straight beyond the Ninth Heaven’s west.

Purple and emerald mists, white clouds soaring high,
in grotto-palaces, immortals feast on jade peaches.
Drums echo through the azure cliffs, thunder shakes in fright,
and all the mountain’s birds and beasts cry out in chorus.

The Dao’s power, divine work—beyond words,
alone it transcends, shaping the ten thousand transformations.
Mountains and seas know their weight,
while the bottomless void floats for ten thousand years.

**Fifteen Poems on the Mid-Autumn Festival**
*Composed on the tenth day of the eighth month, returning from Changle County to the Yuqing Abbey north of Weizhou city.*

From the western county, eastward to Yuqing,
the golden wind sweeps the evening sky clear.
I open my heart to welcome the Mid-Autumn moon,
only fearing clouds may dim its brightness at the hour.

The western wind stirs through the ten thousand trees of the Nine Provinces,
the cold light of night flows westward in a single stream.
The air beyond the dust cleanses to the bone,
and everywhere, songs and joy refuse to let one linger.

chunks.original_text: 初离海峤有余清，万国欢心贺太平。 但愿宝光无晦朔，不教天质有亏盈。 浑金璞玉上天衢，抱雪凝霜耀太虚。 四海百川无不鉴，群生万象悉安居。 一片清光万里开，无分茅屋与楼台。 家家尽得闲吟赏，更有清风助快哉。 有客徘徊望太虚，开尊专欲赏蟾蛉。 蟾光不解留人意，澹澹青霄只自如。 金波昼夜不曾闲，淡荡清辉出海山。 素魄高升游物外，恩光下照满人间。 碧汉峥嵘自有期，天光照耀本无私。 却忧下土昏魔重，不见金轮出现时。 团团皓月挂空虚，百炼青铜鉴不如。 一切水中皆影现，群魔摘胆尽消除。 桂影朦胧下照人，纵横万古不知因。 何当跨鹤云霄上，俯视青天白玉轮。 云去云来不暂停，朝昏恍惚变阴晴。 今宵幸对婵娟质，剩作新诗畅道情。 年年此际杀生多，造业弥天不奈何。 幸谢吾皇严禁切，都教性命得安和。 圣主登基万物安，仁风灭杀自朝端。 邦君士庶皆修德，好放蟾光与众看。 静夜迢迢起黑云，众生无分乐天真。 空中自是云遮眼，天外何曾月避人。 百岁光阴瞬息间，中秋几度得闲颜。 不如炼性如秋月，晃朗身心自在闲。 磻州集卷之二竟 磻溪集卷之三
chunks.translated_text:
At first parting the sea’s ridges, a lingering clarity remains,
the hearts of ten thousand lands rejoice in grand peace.
May the precious radiance know no wax nor wane,
and heaven’s essence never suffer gain or loss.

Like unrefined gold and jade upon the celestial thoroughfare,
embracing snow and congealing frost, it illumines the great void.
The four seas and hundred rivers all reflect its light,
while the myriad beings and forms dwell in tranquility.

A single expanse of pure light unfurls for ten thousand miles,
no distinction between thatched huts and towering halls.
Every household delights in leisurely verse and admiration,
while a fresh breeze lends its aid to joy unbounded.

A traveler lingers, gazing toward the vast heavens,
raising a cup, intent on savoring the moon’s glow.
Yet the moon’s light knows not how to detain the heart,
faintly drifting through the azure sky, serene and self-contained.

Golden waves never rest day or night,
their gentle, clear radiance emerging from sea and mountain.
The pale orb ascends, wandering beyond all things,
its gracious light descending to bathe the human realm.

The azure firmament’s majesty has its appointed time,
heaven’s light shines impartially by nature.
Yet I fear the lower world’s heavy darkness of delusion,
obscuring the moment when the golden wheel appears.

Round and bright, the moon hangs in the empty sky,
even a hundred-fold refined bronze mirror cannot compare.
In every body of water, its reflection appears,
dissolving the gall of all demons, leaving none untouched.

The hazy shadow of the osmanthus drifts down to illuminate mortals,
spanning the ages, its cause unknown.
When shall I ride a crane to the clouds above,
and gaze down upon the azure heavens and the white jade wheel?

Clouds come and go without pause,
dawn and dusk shift between clarity and gloom.
Tonight, fortunate to behold this beauty,
I compose new verses to express the Dao’s sentiment.

Year after year at this time, lives are taken in great number,
heaven-piercing karma arises—what can be done?
Yet thanks to our sovereign’s strict prohibition,
all beings’ lives find peace and harmony.

The sagely ruler ascends the throne, and all things are at rest,
a benevolent wind curbs killing, beginning at court.
Lords and commoners alike cultivate virtue,
that the moon’s radiance may shine upon all.

In the stillness of night, dark clouds arise,
none among the living share in heaven’s true joy.
Yet it is only the clouds that veil the eyes in the sky—
beyond the heavens, the moon has never shunned mortals.

A hundred years of time pass in an instant,
how many Mid-Autumns bring a moment of leisure?
Better to refine one’s nature like the autumn moon,
its clarity and brightness bringing ease to body and mind.

*End of Volume Two of the Panzhou Collection*
*Panxi Collection, Volume Three*

From the western county, eastward to Yuqing,
the golden wind sweeps the evening sky clear.
I open my heart to welcome the Mid-Autumn moon,
only fearing clouds may dim its brightness at the hour.

The western wind stirs through the ten thousand trees of the Nine Provinces,
the cold light of night flows westward in a single stream.
The air beyond the dust cleanses to the bone,
and everywhere, songs and joy refuse to let one linger.

chunks.translated_text:
**Songs and Hymns by Qiu Chuji, the Ever-Spring Master of Mount Xi**

**[Song of the Azure Heavens]**
Azure heavens, let no drifting clouds arise,
for clouds that rise obscure the myriad forms.
The myriad forms arrayed repel a hundred evils—
when light fails to shine, demon-kings prevail.

At first, I swept the skies and earth to clarity,
a thousand gates and ten thousand doors sang of great peace.
Yet sometimes a single black cloud would rise,
and the nine apertures and hundred bones knew no peace.

Thus I ever kindle the fierce wind of wisdom,
sweeping through the Three Realms and Ten Directions.
When clouds disperse, the void’s true body appears,
and naturally, the moon shines in every home.

Beneath the moon, one may play the flute,
a single resonant note subduing Hua and Yi.
Startled, the Jade Lad of the East rides forth,
astride a white deer, swift as a shooting star.

Presently, another melody arises—
neither sheng nor horn, yet of a kind.
A three-foot cloud-zither with twelve studs,
carved through kalpas by the Primal One.

Jade-like tones, pure and clear, surpassing Zheng’s music,
light and penetrating, reaching the hearts of the enlightened.
Since I attained this, ghosts and spirits lend aid,
ascending to heaven, descending to earth, transcending past and present.

Unfettered, unbound, my heart seeks no glory,
my body knows no disgrace.
At leisure, I sing the *White Snow* within the gourd,
in stillness, I tune the *Yangchun* beyond the world.

This music of mine arises naturally—
pipes without holes, zithers without strings.
Awakened from the dream of floating life,
day and night, pure sounds fill the cavern-heaven.

**[Six Hymns]**

**Hymn of the Primordial**
In the quiet of an empty mountain’s night, faint clouds form,
a pale moon, sparse stars, and the cold qi intermingle.
Suddenly, the Long Star gleams in the great void;
turning, I see the Northern Dipper hidden in the vast expanse.

Heaven and earth shift from gloom to brightness in an instant,
the cosmos in turmoil—what does it rely upon?
There must be a mechanism, silently moving,
revolving in emptiness, reciprocating endlessly.

Great indeed is the boundless, mysterious Dao of the Primordial,
what does it not nurture with its numinous efficacy?
It transforms the Three Luminaries, turning the skies azure,
nourishing the myriad things, unfolding their blossoms and calyxes.

Soaring through past and present, it never decays,
enduring peril and hardship, yet never weakened.
The vast torrent surges and swells of its own,
who measures the great transformations?

The Primal Qi first stirs change,
the Supreme Honored One alone transcends all.
Trampling the void, emerging from the unfathomable,
splitting open chaos, giving birth to radiance.

Yin and yang ascend and descend, forming gates,
the sun and moon traverse, serving as locks and keys.
Heat departs, cold arrives; day and night divide,
times flow and ebb, prosperity and decline take their turns.

Above, the pivot of heaven and earth is established,
below, the bell of guidance resounds.
Virtue is built according to place, things are measured by need,
teachings are set forth in accord with the times, following human joy.

The Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors all revere it as their ancestor,
the Six Paths and Four Births all submit in assent.
Even the sagely literary talent of Confucius began in ignorance—
how vast the Dao and virtue of the Hidden Dragon!

**Hymn of Deliverance**
Deep in the mountains, the path is secluded, few travelers pass,
all day in the quiet crags, I listen to the birds’ cries.
No guests to accompany me beneath the bright moon,
sometimes I stand alone above the azure clouds.

Above the clouds, my solitary chant drives a hundred evils far,
gazing to the horizon, the mountains shrink to naught.
The tune soars, the wind swift, the melody lingering,
pure and transcendent, my steps ethereal, my spirit untethered.

I recall the days when Chongyang roamed the corners of the earth,
his pure chant yearning to restore heaven and earth’s simplicity.
He cast his line in Fufeng, unknown to all,
measuring the great sea, I alone foresaw.

His divine subtlety defies distinction,
his transcendent discourse is not what the world studies.
Looking back today, the Dao stands lofty,
only now do I grasp the towering merit of those years.

First, in Dongmou, he expounded benevolence and filial piety,
yet could not transform the customs, lifting the veil.
Five assemblies arose, each with its name:
in Ninghai, the Golden Lotus; in Dengzhou, the Jade Splendor;
in Laizhou, the Level Equality; in Wendeng, the Seven Treasures;
in Fushan, the Three Lights.

In three prefectures, the three teachings flourished,
households entered trance, spirits descended in dreams, people were astounded.
Discarding caps and crowns, I weighed my course.
The Master dwelt by the Eastern Sea, a hidden dragon;
Ma entered the Western Qin, transforming into a leopard.

Danyang’s propagation of the Dao thrived in Shaanxi.
In the summer of the *jichou* year of the Dading era,
I and several others, including Danyang,
followed Master Chongyang from Wendeng to Ninghai.
The season turned to Dragon Spring, the sun’s heat grew intense.

The Master bade us go ahead while he held the umbrella behind,
some half a *li* distant.
Suddenly, I turned and saw the umbrella soar into the sky.
I hurried back to ask, and he said:
“It was borne aloft by the whirlwind, I know not how.”

At first, the umbrella rose to the northeast,
floating gently, then fell among the sands.
We searched in the direction he pointed, but found nothing.
At that time, my Dharma kin, Huiyangzi Wang,
was secluded on Zha Mountain by the Eastern Sea’s edge.

The mountain lay one hundred and ten *li* from Wendeng,
and Wendeng was seventy *li* from where the umbrella rose.
The umbrella ascended at the *chen* hour,
and by dusk, it fell into the handle of Huiyang’s hut.

Huiyang was his Daoist name,
bestowed by the Master—a character not found in the *Pian Yun*.
The umbrella was later kept by the Zhai family below Zha Mountain,
borrowed from Fan Mingshu of Ninghai.
When Fan later learned of this and sought to reclaim it, they refused.

As for my discarding of the cap:
When the Master first climbed the northern city to view the sea,
his bamboo-skin cap suddenly fell into the water and drifted away,
only to return later.
*Qian* is pronounced like *zhu*.

**Hymn of Carefree Wandering**
The Ten Isles and Three Mountains in the vast sea,
crimson towers and jade pavilions, soaring unevenly into the void.
Pine shadows densely veil, fearing no scorching sun,
silken fans still, yet a pure breeze arises.

Molten gold’s heat—
the jade-belted immortals never speak of it.
Crystal palaces open,
jeweled thrones arrayed with stars.

The azure void suspends images around the towers,
the pure and transformed body is not of flesh and blood.
This original body,
naturally attuned to the divine,
in laughter and speech, suddenly startles the immortals of heaven.

**Hymn of Ease**
Jade terraces and Penglai gardens in the azure vault,
auspicious clouds and blessed qi, brimming and filling the sky.
Immortals appear and vanish, scattering pure rain,
the myriad transformations unfold, stirring fragrant winds.

The scorching heat—
where is there a household that has not spoken of it?
Mists withdraw, grotto-heavens open,
gates stand aligned with the Milky Way.

From time to time, the Nine Heavens host illustrious guests,
a thousand *li* away, no need to ride a sweating steed.

Yet it is only the clouds that veil the eyes in the sky—

chunks.original_text: 物外身，自清神，谁羡登楼摇扇人。 望海吟 余观天下形势壮观，自潼关以东、淮水以北，无出登州。 因作《望海吟》，用纪其实。 蓬莱僻东隅，壮观天下绝。 地邻仙圣域，山枕鱼龙穴。 凭高望羲和，目极犹未彻。 苍苍天水回，泛泛云霞泄。 长风起波涛，万里卷霜雪。 凭凌登岛屿，滉漭失丘垤。 有时灵气和，变化非常别。 森罗无限景，欲辨难措舌。 大哉百谷王，沉沉洞清彻。 随时潮有信，历代旱无竭。 人间顷亩池，是处广开列。 比之鲸波大，状若蛙井劣。 望平音洋不见端，弥天自严洁。 众流莫浑浊，万古超生灭。 仙游吟 阆苑红尘外，瑶台碧汉间。 洞中仙不老、云外客长闲。 赤凤吟舟穴，红厖吠药栏。 青衣传诏下，白鹤送书还。 宴赴琼林会，诗裁羽客斑。 浩歌金母殿，长啸玉龟山。 果结三千岁，楼高十二环。 穆王何日到，方朔几时攀。 姑射肌犹洁，双成貌更殷。 飞琼投月窟，弄玉华鬟。 命驾游三岛，搏风过百蛮。 周旋窥海岳，奋掷上天关。 荡荡空无极，滔滔兴未阑。 恢然超法界，不复恋人寰。 颂三首 赞道
chunks.translated_text:
Beyond the mundane, the body—
naturally pure in spirit—
who would envy those who climb towers, fanning themselves?

**Ode Gazing at the Sea**
I have observed the grandeur of the world’s terrain,
and east of Tong Pass, north of the Huai River,
none surpasses Dengzhou.
Thus I compose *Ode Gazing at the Sea* to record its truth.

Penglai lies secluded in the eastern corner,
its grandeur unmatched beneath heaven.
The land borders the realm of immortals and sages,
the mountains rest upon the dens of fish and dragons.
From on high, I gaze toward Xihe,
my vision stretching yet never reaching its end.
Vast and boundless, sky and sea merge,
billowing clouds and mist spill forth.
Long winds stir the waves,
a thousand *li* of frosty snow surging.
Ascending the isles, I stand in lofty dominion,
the earth’s mounds lost in the vast expanse.
At times, the numinous *qi* harmonizes,
transformations beyond the ordinary unfold.
Myriad scenes array in boundless splendor,
too wondrous to describe.

Great indeed is the lord of a hundred rivers,
deep and clear, its depths unfathomable.
With the tides, it keeps its faithful rhythm,
through the ages, it never runs dry in drought.
Beside it, the ponds of mortal fields,
scattered far and wide, lie open.
Compared to its leviathan waves,
they are but frogs in a well—pitifully small.

Gazing across the level expanse, no shore in sight,
it stretches boundless, majestic and pure.
No tributary muddies its waters,
through ten thousand ages, it transcends birth and decay.

**Ode of Immortal Wandering**
Beyond the red dust of the mortal world,
between the jade terraces and azure heavens,
immortals in the grottoes never age,
wanderers beyond the clouds remain ever at ease.
The crimson phoenix sings from its cavernous nest,
the red hound barks by the alchemical railing.
A maiden in blue delivers the imperial decree,
a white crane returns bearing a letter.

Feasting at the banquet of the Jasper Grove,
poems are composed by the feathered guests.
In the Golden Mother’s palace, songs resound,
on Jade Turtle Mountain, long whistles echo.
Fruits ripen once in three thousand years,
the tower spirals twelvefold in ascent.
When will King Mu arrive?
When will Dongfang Shuo climb?
The Lady of Guye’s skin remains pure,
He Xiangu’s beauty ever radiant.
Feiqiong plunges into the moon’s cavern,
Nongyu adorns her hair with blossoms.
They command their chariots to roam the Three Isles,
riding the winds past a hundred barbarian lands.
They circle the seas and mountains,
leaping to ascend the gates of heaven.
Boundless and empty, without limit,
their soaring spirits never wane.

Transcendent, they surpass the dharma-realm,
no longer yearning for the mortal world.

**Three Hymns in Praise of the Dao**

chunks.original_text: 前贤后圣无差别，异派同源化执迷。 太一混元开户牖，玄真直指上天梯。 去惑 他人之言不可听，自己之心但可正。 若凭他口是非言，坏却自身功德性。 示众戒色 劳生有万种，最大无过色。 不唯丧命根，复乃销阴德。 还能戒此一，酷胜其他百。 慕道修仙人，从来是标格。 步虚词二首 旷荡修真教，飘飖出世门。 先师开户牖，归马动乾坤。 陋室迥仙观，高名轧帝阍。 云朋霞友会，朝礼太虚尊。 宝炷成云篆，华灯簇夜光。 星河初焕烂，锺磬乍悠扬。 醮主承嘉会，虔心祷上苍。 诸仙来顾眄，接引下虚皇。 世宗挽词一首并引 臣处机以大定戊申春二月，自终南召赴阙下，蒙赐以巾冠衫系，待诏於天长观。 越十有一日，旨令处机作高功法师，主万春节醮事。 夏四月朔，徙居城北官庵。 越二日己巳，奉圣旨塑纯阳、重阳－、丹阳三师像于官庵，彩绘供具，靡不精备。 后五月十八日，召见於长松岛。 秋七月十日，再召见，剖析天人之理，颇惬宸衷，薄暮言归。 翌日，迨中使赐桃一盘。 处机不食茶果十有余年，过荷圣恩，即啖一枚。 中秋，以他事得旨，许放还山，仍赐钱十万。 表而辞之。
chunks.translated_text:
The former worthies and later sages differ not,
divergent schools share one source—transforming delusion.
The Supreme Unity’s chaos opens the door and window,
mysterious truth points straight to heaven’s ladder.

**Dispelling Delusion**
The words of others must not be heeded,
only one’s own heart may be rectified.
If swayed by others’ right and wrong,
one’s own merit and inner nature are undone.

**Admonition to the Multitude: Curb Desire**
Of life’s myriad toils,
none exceeds desire.
It not only severs the root of life,
but also consumes hidden virtue.
To curb this one thing
surpasses all other restraints.
Those who yearn for the Dao and cultivate immortality
have ever held this as their standard.

**Two "Steps in Emptiness" Hymns**
Vast and boundless, the teaching of true cultivation,
billowing forth from the gate of the world-transcending.
The former masters opened the door and window,
the returning steeds shook heaven and earth.
A humble chamber, a secluded immortal abode,
yet its lofty name resounded at the imperial gate.
Cloud companions and rosy-hued friends gather,
paying homage to the honored one of the Great Void.
Precious incense forms cloud-script,
brilliant lamps cluster like nocturnal radiance.
The starry river first gleams,
bells and chimes suddenly resonate.
The master of the rite upholds the auspicious gathering,
with reverent heart praying to the heavens above.
The various immortals deign to glance,
receiving and guiding from the august Sovereign of Emptiness.

**A Lament for Emperor Shizong, with Preface**
In the spring of the wuyin year of the Dading era [1218], your servant Chji was summoned from Mount Zhongnan to the capital. There, he was bestowed with cap, sash, and robe, and awaited imperial command at the Temple of Eternal Longevity. Eleven days later, an edict appointed Chji as High Ritual Master to preside over the rites of the Wanchun Festival. On the first day of the fourth lunar month, he was moved to the official hermitage north of the city. Two days later, on jisi, by imperial decree, statues of the Three Masters—Chunyang, Chongyang, and Danyang—were sculpted for the hermitage, their adornments and offerings meticulously prepared.

On the eighteenth day of the fifth month, he was summoned to Evergreen Isle. In autumn, on the tenth day of the seventh month, he was again received in audience. There, he expounded the principles of heaven and humanity, much to the emperor’s satisfaction. As dusk fell, he took his leave. The following day, an imperial messenger presented a tray of peaches. Though Chji had abstained from tea and fruit for over a decade, he partook of one in gratitude for the imperial favor.

At the Mid-Autumn Festival, by imperial decree on another matter, he was permitted to return to the mountains, with an additional gift of one hundred thousand coins. He respectfully declined the latter.

chunks.original_text: 逮己酉岁春，途经陕州，遽承哀诏。 时也风尘洞，天气苍黄，士庶官僚尽皆素服，处机虽道修方外，身处世间，重念皇恩，宁不有感。 谨缀挽词一首，用表诚恳云。 哀诏从天降，悲风到陕来。 黄河卷霜雪，白日翳尘埃。 自念长松晚，天恩再韶回。 金盘赐桃食，厚德实伤哀。 古调十五首 速修 一日一日复一日，短景浑如电光疾。 天长地久磨古今，春去秋来变时律。 大梦沉沉无昼夜，浮生兖兖差劳逸。 人情不断犹着空，我志虽高尚忧失。 壳昧游魂如陷弃，心怀嗜欲同怜蜜。 蜜甜有味何日忘，阱黑无明几时出。 出拔须凭高尚行，修治平音不假虚憢术。 但能物我却亲疏，自然神鬼难凶吉。 吾身道性未开眼，土塌紫扉且容膝。 和光同尘随是非，化声相待无相诘。 〔觅纳衣〕 时八月间，令人持诗於县中，觅破布袖衣西虢也。 白露将残寒露洁，山家冷淡观游绝。 树头黄叶坠千林，身上麻袍联百结。 旧布重烦七里市到城七里也，衲衣复待三冬雪。 城中豪富各仁慈，庶在磻溪长守拙。 陇山松 我居西山时六年，山西上有松孤然。 朝云霏微接关塞，暮雨淅沥交洞天。 天生此境为吾伴，隔涧相陪远相看。 郁郁苍苍气色佳，萧萧瑟瑟风声贯。 连枝合抱垂重阴，受命已经千载深。 如何今岁上春月，平地忽遭樵斧侵。 斧声丁丁响溪谷，松烟惨惨愁山麓。 也知天意我将归，故遣灵岩尔先覆。 有夏禹庙甚灵。 景亡人散复何陈，空山黯淡悲游人。 白鹤高飞失行止，苍龙偃卧无精神。 亦知物象终难固，凡百有形皆有数。 高歌物外归去来，大隐尘中益开悟。 赠潍阳唐括姑 乃故丞相之女弟也。 予时在陇山，京兆统军夹谷公，专人书召，姑寻至。 东莱之姑性玄远，蕴德含章自超拔。 未能捞洒今古原，西出长安载脂牵。 殷勤邀吾於陇山，余时杖策徐东还。 还到长安旧游处，故人不死多苍颜。 回头为报姑明取，百岁光阴一寒暑。 速抛家业违物情，早作闲人伴仙侣。 壶中自游日月长，身外不复衰残殃。 跨古腾今别无事，只由大德心开张。 因旱作 玄元大道统阴阳，造化乾坤万物昌。 高下如能各处分，始终即得免罹殃。 今之曷故多栽障，盖为人心胡纵放。 美食鲜衣器用华，狂明怪侣邪淫王。 阴阳交错古来传，恩害相生本自然。 迤逦不能廉度日，因循直致旱经年。 青霄碧落常无雨，紫陌红尘唯播土。 铄石流金万物焦，镕肠裂背群生苦。 有时率众取湫科，蛮肉粒盘自噎饥。 侮慢加之伤物命，喧呼何足动神袛。 哀哉俗态荒声色，个个倾危身反侧。 安得人心似我心，免遭痛切临头厄。 赠华州沙涧寨刘校尉 刘公满室皆行善，供养闲人心不倦。 巧行馒天我不为，至心奉道人皆羡。 殷勤种德养灵芽，阖郡生民有几家。 伫看异日功夫到，共蹑祥云阿母家。 憨物二首 比岁饥疫相仍之故也。 天苍苍兮临下土，胡为不救万灵苦。 万灵日夜相凌迟，饮气吞声死无语。 仰天大叫天不应，一物细琐徒劳形。 安得大千复混沌，免教造物生精灵。 呜呼天地广开辟，化出众生千百亿。 暴恶相侵不暂停，循环受苦知何极。 皇天后土皆有神，见死不救知何因。 下土悲心却无福，徒劳日夜含酸辛。 六月庚午喜雨 我闻东山雨，千载无西行。 胡为阅今夏，屡及滂拖霐。 昨日午时后，一洗芽甲生。
chunks.translated_text:
In the spring of the *jiyou* year, as he passed through Shanzhou, he suddenly received the sorrowful imperial edict. At that time, the world was in turmoil, the sky and earth dimmed in pallor; officials and commoners alike donned mourning white. Though Qiu Chuji had cultivated the Dao beyond the worldly realm, dwelling still within the mortal sphere, how could he not be moved by the weight of imperial grace? He respectfully composed an elegy to express his sincerity:

*The sorrowful edict descended from heaven,
A mournful wind reached Shanzhou.
The Yellow River churned with frost and snow,
The sun veiled in dust and grime.
I recalled the twilight of Evergreen Isle,
Where imperial favor twice renewed my years.
A golden tray bore peaches for my partaking—
Such profound virtue now deepens my sorrow.*

**Fifteen Poems on Swift Cultivation**

Day after day, day upon day,
The fleeting light races like lightning.
Heaven endures, earth persists, grinding through ages,
Spring departs, autumn arrives, the seasons shift.
The great dream drifts, day and night indistinguishable,
Floating life flickers, toiling or at ease.
Human attachments cling even to emptiness,
My aspirations soar, yet fear of loss remains.
The deluded soul wanders like one cast aside,
The heart, craving desires, clings to sweetness like honey.
How can one forget honey’s sweetness?
The pit of ignorance—when will one emerge?
Emergence demands lofty conduct,
Cultivation of the pure tone brooks no false arts.
Only by dissolving self and other, near and far,
Can gods and demons be powerless over fortune or misfortune.
My Dao-nature still blind,
I dwell in a humble hut with purple doors, content in cramped space.
Harmonizing light with dust, I follow the world’s right and wrong,
Responding to sounds without contention.

**Seeking a Patched Robe**
In the eighth month, he sent someone to the county to seek a tattered cloth sleeve-robe from Western Guo.

*White dew wanes, cold dew gleams,
Mountain homes grow desolate, wanderers cease.
Yellow leaves fall from a thousand trees,
My hempen robe stitched with a hundred patches.
Old cloth, weary from the seven-li market to the city,
The patched robe awaits winter’s snow.
Let the city’s wealthy show their kindness,
That I may long dwell in seclusion by Pan Stream.*

**Pine of Long Mountain**
For six years I dwelt on Western Mountain,
Where atop its western slope stood a solitary pine.
Morning clouds, misty, brushed the passes,
Evening rains, pattering, merged with the cavern-heavens.
Heaven shaped this place as my companion,
Across the ravine, we kept distant company.
Lush and verdant, its qi and hue sublime,
Soughing and rustling, the wind’s voice resounded.
Intertwined branches cast layered shade,
Its mandate endured a thousand years deep.
Yet in this year’s early spring,
It suddenly fell to the woodcutter’s axe.
The axe’s *ding-ding* echoed through valleys,
The pine’s smoke, mournful, darkened the mountain’s foot.
I knew then heaven’s intent: I would soon depart,
Thus sent the sacred crag to fall before me.
By the numinous Xia Yu Temple—
Scenes fade, people scatter, what remains to recount?
The empty mountain dims, grieving the traveler.
White cranes soar, losing their path,
The azure dragon lies prone, devoid of spirit.
I know all phenomena are ultimately impermanent,
All forms bound by fate.
Singing beyond the worldly, I return—
The greater hermitage in the dust deepens my awakening.

**To Tangkuo Gu of Weiyang**
She was the younger sister of a former prime

chunks.original_text: 今日申时前，再倾车轴烹。 千山日惨惨，四野雷轰轰。 平地涌三尺，大河侵五更。 蛟龙出池沼，旱魃填沟坑。 云汉复何有，天衢从此亨。 题刘节使所藏显宗御画庄子 显宗好道富年壮，手笔南华古形状。 南华去世千载余，状貌风格知何如。 只是今人重古道，仿髴气象加襟裾。 至人胸中本无待，万窍吹嘘任天籁。 杨韩嵇阮心不同，到了各归於大块。 冬日郊外闲步 草木既凋残，冰霜何凛冽。 长空乌飞尽，大海鱼游绝。 商旅不行舟，昆虫皆闭穴。 谁能丰足外，解把孤贫设。 秋风海上 蓬莱有客无家乡，身拟学仙游大方。 大方洪水浸天阔，东极万里青茫茫。 晓来雨过西风急，策杖凭高看呼吸。 鸿雁连天剥枣晴，鱼龙戏水操舟入。 千尺丝轮直下垂，碧波深处钓鲸统。 纷纷鱼龞不肯食，橄接波澜空自迷。 挂席未能超彼岸，乘槎再欲浮天汉。 天汉高高万象明，白云谁是长生伴。 登州修真观建黄箓醮 浑沦至道急如箭，反覆阴阳自交战。 太极茫茫造化开，平空落落神奇见。 群生万象参差出，六合八弦妆点遍。 跨古腾今逐日新，流形返朴随时变。 有情无情不可穷，大智小智交相攻。 不有圣贤开教化，那知动植本虚空。 千经万论垂方便，宝岌琅函兴众善。 自昔根源发杳冥，迄今道德犹光显。 迩来天下教门兴，达士随方化有情。 我亦周流三十载，还乡复到海边城。 城南磊落修真观，气势清高接河汉。 俯视沧茫渤澥深，仰观卓荦星辰焕。 城中信士往来多，物外交朋意气和。 承安四年冬十月，大兴黄箓演金科。 赤书玉字先天有，白简真符破邪久。 三级瑶坛映宝光，九卮神灯摛星斗。 巉岩破钱酆都山，列峙升仙不可攀。 四夜严陈香火供，九朝时听步虚环。 千门万户生欢悦，六街三市齐铺设。 金花银烛相辉映，表裹光明自通彻。 忽闻空外显嘉祥，萧索轮困有异常。 玉帝传宣行大赦，仙童骑鹤下南昌。 幽魂滞魄皆超度，白叟黄童尽钦慕。 天涯好事未尝闻，压尽山东河北路。 潍州城北千户新观 清闲不在苦幽栖，心上无尘到处宜。 北海葱葱郡城角，地多花木景多奇。 昔年车马空撩乱，今日翻为玉清观。 观中游戏是何人，天下往来都散汉。 池塘寂寂锁烟霞，大宝莲开十丈花。 借问经营谁施主，袭封千户太均家。 题莱州招远县云屯山观 云屯山上云冥冥，天风荡摇飞雨零。 神奇幻怪不可测，千变万化无常形。 云收雨霁杳无迹，但见群山罗翠屏。 山高谷深复何有，白石磊磊松烟青。 春游浩荡满山谷，直上似欲趣天庭。 心虚目极淡天阔，俯视模漠环沧溟。 昔居庵地走三郡，登莱宁海人多期拜，今为洞天朝万灵。 虚空旧基作新观，人呼旧址为虚空也，万世不朽传佳铭。 五言短句三首 警世
chunks.translated_text:
Here the rain pours axle-deep before the hour of *shen*,
A thousand peaks grow dim, the four wilds thunder.
The flat earth swells three feet,
The great river swallows five watches of the night.
Dragons surge from ponds and marshes,
Drought demons fill ditches and gullies.
What remains of the Milky Way?
From this day the celestial thoroughfare stands open.

**Inscribed on the Zhaungzi Scroll in the Collection of Commissioner Liu**
Illustrious Zong loved the Dao in his prime,
His hand traced the ancient forms of the *Nanhua*.
A thousand years have passed since the *Nanhua* departed—
What might its manner and spirit have been?
Only that men today revere the ancient Way,
And in faint imitation drape its aura over their robes.
The perfected one’s breast originally held no waiting,
Ten thousand pores breathe freely with heaven’s wind.
Yang, Han, Ji, Ruan—each heart differed,
Yet all returned to the great clod.

**A Winter Stroll Beyond the Suburbs**
Grasses and trees withered,
Ice and frost bitterly cold.
The long sky—birds flown to the last,
The great sea—fish vanished without trace.
Merchants’ boats lie idle,
All insects sealed in their burrows.
Who beyond abundance
Can loosen the grip of lonely poverty?

**Autumn Wind on the Sea**
A wanderer from Penglai has no home,
His body vows to learn immortality and roam the great expanse.
The great expanse—floodwaters drown the sky’s vastness,
Eastward ten thousand miles stretch blue and boundless.
At dawn, rain passed and the west wind rose sharp;
Staff in hand, I climbed high to breathe the air.
Wild geese fill the sky, peeling jujubes in the clear weather,
Fish and dragons sport in the waves as boats ply the currents.
A thousand feet of silk line drop straight down,
In the jade depths angling for the whale’s bridle.
Yet fish and turtles scatter, refusing the bait,
Grappling with the waves, lost in vain.
My sail cannot yet cross to the far shore,
Again I would ride the raft to float the River of Stars.
The River of Stars looms high, all phenomena bright,
But which white cloud is the companion of long life?

**On the Construction of the Huanglu Jiao at the Xiuzhen Abbey in Dengzhou**
The primal Dao, chaotic and urgent as an arrow,
Yin and yang in ceaseless strife.
The Great Ultimate, vast and dim, opened creation,
From the void, numinous marvels appeared.
All beings, myriad forms, emerged unevenly,
The six directions and eight winds adorned everywhere.
Spanning past and present, ever renewed with the sun,
Flowing forms return to simplicity, changing with the times.
Sentient and insentient cannot be exhausted,
Great wisdom and small wisdom locked in struggle.
Had sages and worthies not opened teachings,
Who would know that movement and stillness are fundamentally empty?
A thousand scriptures, ten thousand treatises offer expedient means,
Precious registers and jade cases inspire all goodness.
From ancient roots in the unseen,
To this day, the Dao and virtue still shine.
Of late, the world’s teachings flourish,
The enlightened transform beings wherever they go.
I too have wandered thirty years,
Returning home to this city by the sea.
South of the city, the towering Xiuzhen Abbey
Stands pure and lofty, touching the River of Stars.
Below, the vast and deep Bohai,
Above, the brilliant stars and constellations.
Within the city, devotees come and go,
Beyond the world, friends share harmonious spirit.
In the tenth month of winter, the fourth year of Cheng’an,
A grand Huanglu rite unfolds the golden code.
Crimson script and jade characters predate heaven,
White talismans and true seals long break evil.
Three-tiered jade altars reflect precious light,
Nine cups of divine lamps scatter stars.
Crags shatter the money of Fengdu Mountain,
Peaks rise in ranks—immortals’ ascent beyond reach.
For four nights, incense and offerings arrayed in solemnity,
For nine mornings, the steps of emptiness echo in circles.
A thousand gates and ten thousand doors brim with joy,
The six streets and three markets all adorned.
Gold flowers and silver candles gleam in radiance,
Inner and outer light pierce through.
Suddenly from the void, auspicious signs appear,
A desolate wheel turns—something extraordinary.
The Jade Emperor proclaims a great amnesty,
Immortal youths ride cranes down to Nanchang.
Lost souls and lingering spirits all ascend,
White-haired elders and yellow-haired children all admire.
Such fine deeds are unheard of at the world’s edge,
Outshining all in Shandong and Hebei.

**The New Abbey North of Weizhou City**
Tranquility need not lie in reclusive suffering,
Where the heart is dust-free, all places suit.
North of the lush prefectural city,
Land rich with flowers and trees, scenes full of wonder.
Once, carriages and horses clamored in vain,
Now transformed into the Jade Purity Abbey.
Who plays within the abbey?
All under heaven who come and go—free wanderers.
Ponds and pavilions lie quiet, veiled in mist and rosy clouds,
The great treasure lotus blooms a ten-zhang flower.
I ask: who is the benefactor of this enterprise?
The ennobled Qianhu, Lord Tai of the great household.

**Inscribed at the Yuntun Abbey on Mount Yuntun in Zhaoyuan County, Laizhou**
On Mount Yuntun, clouds shroud in darkness,
Heavenly winds sway, flying rain scatters.
Numinous and strange, beyond all measure,
A thousand changes, ten thousand transformations—no constant form.
Clouds withdraw, rain clears, no trace remains,
Only rows of mountains arrayed like emerald screens.
How high the peaks, how deep the valleys—what more is there?
White stones piled, pine smoke green.
Spring’s exuberance fills the valleys,
Straight ascent seems to reach heaven’s court.
Heart empty, gaze far, the sky vast and serene,
Looking down, the indistinct encircles the blue-green sea.
Once, the hermitage here spanned three prefectures,
Dengzhou, Laizhou, Ninghai—many came to pay homage.
Now it is a grotto-heaven, all spirits come to court.
The old foundation in the void becomes a new abbey—
People call the old site “the Void,”
An eternal legacy inscribed in fine verse.

**Three Five-Character Short Poems: Admonitions to the World**

chunks.translated_text:
**Five Long Five-Character Poems: Teachings for the Assembly**

---

**I. Admonitions to the World**

Powder and rouge, jewels and treasures—
flourishing splendor, vain and fevered chaos.
To know all things are empty,
one must view them through a century’s gaze.

**Climbing the Northern Mountains of Jiaoshui**
Ascending high to gaze upon the Southern Sea,
the eye strains—heaven’s vault, vast and blue.
At the sky’s edge, white clouds arise,
soaring aloft into boundless void.
When clouds disperse, the Eastern Sea’s moon gleams clear,
the Western Mountains’ snow gleams bright.
As the dying night suddenly congeals,
how radiant the pure light!

**II. The Nature of Existence**

Thoughts chase boundless desires,
how many ten thousand kalpas in samsara?
The Five Phases shift with change,
the Four Elements lack firm foundation.
Life is but a fleeting convergence of causes,
vainly toiling through the years in greed.
Not knowing the body itself is affliction,
they futilely vie for things as lofty.
In affairs, though capable,
in self, utterly lacking discipline.
The Six Dusts flutter ceaselessly,
the Three Realms rush in clamor.
Dazzled, the eyes grow weary,
greed presses upon the greying hair.
The heart carved out, lacking courage,
clinging to beauty, slick with fat.
Hair white as snow,
complexion no longer peach-like.
Unable to follow the teachings,
still they gallop in violence and pride.
Swift as the cloud-piercing magpie,
mad as the wall-clinging gibbon.
At times, cunning arises,
in idleness, waves stir.
Sins pile like mountains,
the spirit erodes like the sea’s tides.
No way to companion the pines and cypress,
only to await burial in the weeds.

---

**III. Expressions from the Sea**

On the sea, the wind is crisp and cold,
the sky’s root and water stretch into the distant.
Though icebergs sever,
the summer’s heat naturally fades.
Lofty aspirations span noble integrity,
an empty heart accords with the great Dao.
Parting clouds to roam the boundless,
plying the oars to drift on the azure waves.
Standing alone, enlightening the ages,
circling to survey the eight wilds.
Heaven’s stars do not fall,
earth’s veins stretch without end.
Illusions spew forth a thousand points,
floating life is but a dream’s scene.
The spirit transforms at hand’s turn,
flowers and trees briefly flourish.
A century’s span is short,
the road to the Three Mountains long.
Seeking immortality, lamenting Han Wu,
losing the Dao, sighing for Qin Huang.
The herb-gathering lad has aged,
the raft-riding traveler remains unknown.
Only the traces of the Three Isles remain,
at times revealing auspicious signs.
Great Bamboo Mountain, Little Bamboo Mountain, and Oxcart Isle—
these are the Three Isles.
Auspicious signs—these are the mirages of the sea.

---

**IV. Autumn Day on Mount Ai**

Autumn winds sweep the mountains,
dawn’s sun drives the clouds and mist.
Tender chrysanthemums carpet the earth in yellow,
bright rosy clouds adorn the sky in emerald.
Ascending, thoughts turn to the sea’s peaks,
playing, drawing from the mountain springs.
Massive stones, though perilous, stand firm,
cold pines, aged, grow ever sturdier.
Rock flowers exude fragrant perfume,
ravine grasses stretch in lush green.
Secluded, I wander the hidden Dao,
an empty heart—no sitting in meditation.
Observing emptiness, though free,
encountering scenes, I linger.
Wielding the brush beyond the red dust,
my name soars near the Purple Court.
Still ashamed of the Queen Mother’s secret,
how dare I claim the Jade Emperor’s decree?
Abiding in the world, surpassing the Three Joys,
at peace with the times, outstripping the Seven Sages.
Hiding my light, I return to simplicity,
responding to things, I follow conditions.
The butterfly’s dream startles the ages,
spiritual wandering awaits a hundred years.
Each person may yet encounter this,
mouth to mouth, it is passed on.

---

**V. Pear Blossoms at the Martial Abbey**

The White Emperor departs the golden gates,
the Azure Dragon descends to the jade capital.
Earth spirits unveil their wondrous secrets,
heaven’s essence bestows pure brilliance.
Color suffuses the silver toad’s charm,
fragrance drifts through the jeweled hall’s clarity.
Trees number in the thousands, uneven,
their brightness gleams in the second or third watch.
Flamboyant apricots pale in comparison,
bewitching peaches bow in humility.
Plum blossoms have already hidden,
willow catkins dare not slight them.
Best when the warm breeze caresses,
finest when the fair sun shines.
Travelers anticipate carefree roaming,
feathered adepts celebrate peace.
No dust is permitted to stain,
only nurtured by rain and dew’s glory.
West of the city, old traces remain,
north of the mountains, new fame resounds.
Brilliant orioles flit in joy,
spreading magpies startle in flight.
Jade halls face the doors and windows,
mushroom chambers adjoin the eaves and pillars.
Graceful as Mount Gu’s elegance,
ethereal as Mount Hua’s essence.
Soon the year’s harvest will ripen,
the Dharma Bridge’s completion will universally aid.

---

**Climbing the Mountain of the Daoist Valley**

Gentle and warm, the spring breeze,
languid and mild, the morning sun.
Donning cold robes, I ascend the winding path,
at the summit, I marvel at the secluded wonders.
The Northern Sea’s waves surge vast,
the Southern Mountains’ marshes loom perilous.
East winds carry the blue-black bird down,
western ridges trail white clouds.
The eye’s reach spans the empty vastness,
misty light drifts in the distance.
How untrammeled the spirit,
the Dao and virtue naturally uphold.
Dimly discerned beyond the cinnabar clouds,
uneven at the azure Han’s edge.
No need to gather the magic fungus,
I proceed directly to the immortals’ appointed time.

*End of Scroll Three of the Panxi Collection*

chunks.original_text: 栖霞长春子邱处机撰 五言律诗 博州战姑庭楸诗并引 聊城之南，邹氏之室，有战姑者，本蓬莱人。 生含巧思，以彩缕纫结乌默鱼虫花草之类，随物变态，不待规模，而应之於手。 其精理过於生者远甚。 自中年后守寡，信道甚笃，建庵设食，以待四方烟霞之侣，且有日矣。 无何，佻薄者构成谤讟之私，用浼松筠之操。 姑知不易明辨，即会其戚属，指庭下枯楸而祝之曰：今仙圣在上，妾身若无毫发过，愿树复荣，苟或不然，是妾自负矣，吾誓不与若等共天日。 祝后岁几半，宝无朕兆。 里人笑而嘲之曰：繄树若生，不特尔之贞，而我亦富且贵矣。 姑闻之春梦然。 彼楸树者，以大定庚子岁始植，既植即死，风摧雨剥，殆几五稔，形质朽残，固无生理。 越明年建巳之夏，即姑始祷之月也。 忽尔灵芽笋发於枯树之下，状如朱草，日引修条茂叶，蔽于阶砌。 予初在陕右，屡闻是说，然未详所见。 逮明昌辛亥，涂经此州，闻闾里赞道。
chunks.translated_text:
**Five-Character Regulated Verse on the Withered Catalpa in Madam Zhan’s Courtyard**
*Composed by Qiu Chuji, the Long Spring Daoist of Mount Qixia*

**Preface:**
South of Liaocheng, in the household of the Zou clan, there lived a woman named Madam Zhan, originally from Penglai. From birth, she possessed a nimble mind, deftly weaving silk threads into birds, fish, insects, flowers, and grasses—each form taking shape without need of pattern, flowing effortlessly from her hands. Her craftsmanship surpassed that of the living by far.

After her husband’s death in middle age, she remained a widow, her devotion to the Dao profound. She built a hermitage and set out offerings to welcome the cloud-and-mist companions of the four directions, a practice she maintained for many years. Yet before long, frivolous tongues wove slanderous whispers, tarnishing her steadfast integrity like pine and bamboo besmirched by mud.

Realizing the futility of clearing her name, she gathered her kin and, pointing to the withered catalpa in the courtyard, made this vow before the immortals: *"If my conduct bears not the slightest fault, let this tree revive in glory. Should I prove false, I shall bear the shame alone and swear never to share the same sky and sun as you."* Months passed after her prayer, yet the tree showed no sign of life.

The villagers mocked her, jeering: *"If this tree blooms again, not only will your virtue be proven, but we too shall grow rich and noble!"* Madam Zhan heard their words as if in a spring dream.

That catalpa had been planted in the *gengzi* year of the Dading era (1180). No sooner had it taken root than it withered, battered by wind and rain for nearly five years until its form decayed beyond hope of revival. Yet in the summer of the following *jisi* year (1199)—the very month of Madam Zhan’s prayer—suddenly, a miraculous sprout emerged from the dead wood. Crimson as sacred grass, it stretched forth branches and lush leaves day by day, until its foliage shaded the courtyard steps.

I first heard this tale while in Shaanxi, though I did not witness it myself. By the *xinhai* year of the Mingchang era (1191), as I passed through this prefecture, the streets and lanes still resounded with its praise.
