chunks.translated_text:
Upon lodging in Madam Zhan’s courtyard, I at last confirmed the truth of the matter. Six years have now passed since the tree’s revival. Its height spans twice a man’s reach, its branches and boughs luxuriant, unlike any common wood. Four lateral shoots emerge, sturdy and sinewy, their bearing lofty as if straining toward the clouds. Master Changchun observed: “Utmost sincerity moves things; luminous virtue stirs Heaven—does this not describe Madam Zhan? Who says the Dao is distant? The fault lies only in man’s failure to cultivate true virtue.” Thus I composed forty words to record this wondrous response.

*On the day of...*
Outsiders slander with idle tongues,
Yet with empty heart she prayed for proof.
The long catalpa’s roots had rotted,
Yet from withered stump, fresh shoots arose.
Meng’s lament for yellow bamboo,
Tian Zhen’s sigh for purple brier—
Of old, filial piety was praised;
Today, loyalty stands revealed.

**Reply to Meng’an of Guoxian County**
Enamored of this land untouched by men,
I soar high, freed from the crow’s cage.
Reciting poems to pass the idle days,
Observing transformations in the still wind.
Staff in hand, I roam south of Southern Mountain,
Singing boldly east of Western Slope.
How many red-dust affairs exist?
None reach the realm of white clouds.

**Reply to Scholar Li Si of Guoxian County**
In deepest winter, most carefree,
Short days hasten my rounds.
Standing alone beyond the red dust,
I chant poems before emerald peaks.
Glancing sideways at the cave’s mouth,
My bright gaze rests on mountain summits.
Gazing afar at snowy green peaks,
Brilliant white mirrors the sky.

**Visiting Huaidao Village South of Mount Zhongnan, Lodging in a Bamboo Garden**
Seeking the Dao in Huaidao,
My feelings far from worldly passions.
At ease, my spirit soars;
Half-asleep, my dreams still stir.
The immortal’s courtyard, elegant in its scenery,
Jade groves bathed in moonlight’s clarity.
A scholar truly finds delight—
Why cling to purple-robed honors?

**In Praise of Master Changsheng**
Whose blessed company do I keep?
Among immortals, who is most favored?
The eminent scholar of Donglai,
The renowned figure of Xiluo.
Later, he received the ancestral teachings;
He was the last to leave the household,
First to establish the model of Dao and virtue.
Deeply he knew the power of youth,
Thus moved by sages’ support.

**In Praise of Master Yuyang**
A true immortal of the ancient land,
A great man of the Eastern Realm.
Pure and lofty, how unlike the vulgar,
Bright and untrammeled, beyond worldly dust.
Inner and outer gifts bestowed by Heaven,
His conduct and retreat peerless in the age.
Timely he discerns fortune and misfortune,
His proofs silently commune with the divine.

**Inscribed at the Temple of the Great Duke of Panxi**
One scene unites high and low,
Three peaks stand guard through ancient and modern times.
The path winds through cloud-washed caves,
The shrine nestles deep by the angling stream.
From crevices, flying springs burst forth,
Ancient cypresses shade the sky.
How joyous this pure and secluded place—
Fit to gladden the heart of a rustic.

**Spring Day Excursion**
Emerging from the Hall of Azure Clouds,
I turn and gaze across the eight wilds.
Clouds disperse, a thousand li made clear,
Wind scatters the fragrance of a hundred flowers.
The sea of desire stirs distant sorrows,
Spring mountains awaken lasting delight.
Leaning on my staff, the climb complete,
I plunge deep into the land of intoxication.

**First Snow**
Last night’s rain turned to snow,
This morning the earth transformed to silver.
The window brightens, yet dawn has not come;
The wilds darken, yet dust is no more.
From the sea, golden waves grow pale,
Across the sky, jade trees stand new.
At first sight, purity fills the eyes—
Enough to stir the poet’s heart.

**Autumn Rain**
For two nights, Heaven sends down rain,
In clear autumn, the earth swells with waves.
Gloom veils sun and moon,
Surging waters swell rivers and streams.
At the Purple Frontier, returning geese bear sorrow,
On green mountains, recluses sing their songs.
Unfazed, I dwell in my stone chamber,
High-pillowed, chanting amidst mist and vines.

**Leaving the Capital**
Just beyond the imperial capital,
I chant poems, my rustic spirit soaring.
The parrot, freed from its cage, is splendid;
The phoenix, spreading its wings, is wondrous.
A white horse gallops lightly,
Green mountains drift slowly by.
Chang’an, a brocade of a thousand pieces—
Undoubtedly, I shall arrive soon.

**Ascending Western Mountain of Yizhou**
Lifting my robes, I tread barren ground,
From the summit, I survey the autumn’s minutiae.
Deep valleys plunge into dark abysses,
Jumbled peaks rise in towering layers.
The forest’s chill chills to the bone,
My eyes strain with the vastness.
Laughing at this heartless wanderer,
How can I compare to the gibbons of cassia cliffs?

**Inscribed at Mount Ai**
A single dark cloud, cold and aloft,
Stands solitary amidst the distant haze.
Heaven hangs over the vast blue sea,
Earth anchors the leisurely white clouds.
Though its name is hidden among the Five Peaks,
The path to the Three Spirits may yet be climbed.
At times, I observe stones transformed by touch,
Sweet dew anointing the dusty world.

**Gazing Toward Kunlun**
Once I dwelled in Kunlun’s land,
A single glance southeast brings joy.
Jade peaks array like sea and mountains,
Cloud brocade scatters like heavenly flowers.
Qi gathers, concentrating triple excellence,
Spirit clears, surpassing the Nine Flowers.
Now, as spring snow melts,
My eyes brim with cinnabar white.

**Ascending Penglai Pavilion**
Once atop Penglai Pavilion,
With empty heart, I gaze into the distance.
Clouds shift, mountains seem to grow,
Waters reach the sea and vanish.
Below, I peer into the dragons’ lair,
Beside me, I watch the magpies’ bridge.
Why fear the distant, weightless ascent?
The cinnabar heavens lie close at hand.

**Gazing at the Sea**
Sea’s hue swallows Heaven’s hue,
Wind’s voice mingles with water’s voice.
Clouds churn, startling fish and turtles,
Thunder roars, shocking gods and spirits.
Waves surge against a thousand perilous cliffs,
Vast and boundless, a myriad li of calm.
Now, without a fisher of giant turtles,
Who will cast a line to hook the great whale?

**Mountain Hall After Rain Clears**
Morning sun, three poles high, shines bright,
A thousand peaks stretch level in the distance.
Chanting high, my spirit grows ever freer,
Gazing far, my eyes grow ever clearer.
After rain, the eaves drip with moisture,
Wind arrives, the seat grows cool.
If one’s heart is not aligned with the Dao,
Do not let them pass my gate.

**Two Poems on the Moon at Midnight**
**I**
The midnight moon, steadfast and bright,
Walks alone where none accompany.
Below, it joins the white of the blue sea,
Above, it fills the void with purity.
Its traces leave the Three Isles,
Its light roams, illuminating ten thousand cities.
In those cities, how many guests lie,
Too deep in sleep to be stirred.

**II**
The midnight moon, steadfast and bright,
Shines alone where none accompany.
At the sky’s edge, the Dipper dims,
On earth, a hundred evils take fright.
Wild cranes are faintly discerned,
A host of dragons soar and cry.
On ordinary nights of the fifteenth,
Never has it been so clear.

**Early Winter: Rain Delays the Purchase of a Horse**
In the tenth month, torrential rain,
At the third watch, roaring waves.
Floating clouds link sea and peaks,
Rushing waters flood the mountain city.
Wilds darken, wind and waves rage,
Mud deepens, roads collapse.
Travelers and galloping horses alike
Race through the night till dawn.

**First Snow**
As the tenth month draws to a close,
By chance, I see the six-petaled snowflakes fly.
Scattered and swift in the whirling wind,
Intricate and faint as night falls.

chunks.original_text: 山川淡屏帐，星斗失珠玑。 晓色冲天净，银霞烂目辉。 游春 一夜春风暖，三竿晓日华。 有山皆着锦，无地不开花。 金谷人多感，桃源路易差。 回头皆是梦，说与道人家。 春夜雨二首 山光犹冷淡，景色未铺陈。 细雨偏沾物，轻风不着人。 融和三月暖，次第百花新。 静夜轩中卧，闲吟海上春。 春色来何晚，清明不见花。 开轩观翠竹，拨土认黄芽。 夜雨微微作，光风渐渐嘉。 参差三月尽，桃李满天涯。 云峰 九夏时炎赫，千山气郁蒸。 翔空初漠漠，变态复层层。 岌嶪真堪画，孤高不可升。 何当仙去也，跨鹤上凭凌。 〔筏木得风〕 修殿乏材，令工师筏木海北，至滨阻风，殆十余日。 秋八月有九日，方西南风，筏木乘之，始达胶东。 日落金风顺，潮平筏木开。 云帆争岸急，晓日映天来。 海北虽多难，胶东幸少灾。 不忧成大厦，已见得良材。 自述
chunks.translated_text:
**Mountains and Rivers as a Faint Screen**
Mountains and rivers like a pale bed-curtain,
Stars and constellations lose their pearl-like gleam.
Dawn’s light pierces the sky, so pure,
Silver clouds dazzle the eye with radiance.

**Spring Outing**
One night of spring wind brings warmth,
By the third watch, dawn’s sun glows bright.
Every mountain wears brocade,
No land but blooms with flowers.
Golden Valley stirs deep feeling,
Peach Blossom Spring is easily misjudged.
Turning back, all is but a dream—
I tell this to the Daoist’s household.

**Two Poems on a Spring Night’s Rain**

**I**
Mountain light remains cold and faint,
Scenery not yet arrayed.
Fine rain clings to all things,
A gentle breeze touches no one.
Harmony warms the third month,
One by one, a hundred flowers renew.
Lying in the quiet chamber at night,
I idly chant of spring by the sea.

**II**
How late the spring colors arrive—
At Clear Brightness, no flowers appear.
Opening the window to watch emerald bamboo,
Brushing soil to find golden sprouts.
Night rain falls softly,
A balmy breeze grows fair.
As the third month draws unevenly to a close,
Peach and plum blossoms fill the horizon.

**Cloud Peaks**
In the scorching ninth month of summer,
A thousand mountains steam with sultry qi.
Soaring space at first is vast and hazy,
Then shifts in layers, ever-changing.
Towering and sheer, fit for a painting,
Too lofty for mortal ascent.
When shall I ascend as an immortal,
Riding a crane to soar above?

**Rafting Timber with the Wind**
Lacking timber for the temple’s repair,
The master craftsman was ordered to raft logs from north of the sea.
Near the shore, wind held them back for over ten days.
In autumn’s eighth month, on the ninth day,
A southwesterly wind arose—
The rafts rode it at last to Jiaodong.
As the sun sets, the golden wind follows,
Tides level, the rafts set forth.
Cloud-sails race the shore in haste,
Dawn’s sun rises, gilding the sky.
Though the north sea brings many trials,
Jiaodong is spared from great disaster.
No need to fear the grand hall unfinished—
Fine timber is already here.

**Self-Portrait**

chunks.original_text: 白发年来长，红颜日渐凋。 未能明道术，欲去问松乔。 罔象如何觅，还丹着甚烧。 钦依三洞诀，得使万缘消。 五言绝句 蓝田 万壑舒纹锦，千峰列画屏。 雨余蓝水白，云断玉山青。 复归陇山二首 鹤性还山好，云峰当夏奇。 避风权过海，得雨不留池。 独坐长松下，孤吟乱石边。 夜骑朱顶鹤，时访白云仙。 憨物二首 皇天生万类，万类属皇天。 何事纵陵虐，不教生命全。 阴阳成造化，生灭递浮沉。 最苦有情物，难当无善心。 秋夜二首 露气含秋爽，天光照夜明。 陇头残月暗，溪上晓风清。 玉露夜漫漫，银河秋耿耿。 风含水谷清，月耀天衢冷。 清晓二首 银河初变色，星斗欲翻空。 残月半轮白，晓霞千丈红。 舞鹤夜初晓，游仙梦始惊。 月衔山转大，风度水偏清。 清兴二首 三冬游海上，六出满天涯。 为访神仙窟，经过道士家。 酒倾金露滑，茶点玉芝香。 神爽得三昧，清和消百殃。 造物三首 造物通神化，流形满大千。 群迷长受苦，万圣不能悛。 太混一时剖，空花千古繁。 神奇亿万变，道德杳冥存。 万花随时出，三光合度明。 九霄宫运转，八极自生成。 示众三十七首 色身元有限，情欲浩无涯。 痴似蜂贪蜜，狂如蝶恋花。 六根谁是主，贪欲自招殃。 一念色心动，百骸秋气伤。 外物於身患，狂心不自监。 病深方省欲，祸极始知贪。 最爱三田宝，难禁五欲情。 后生须自重，元气莫相轻。 四大本无托，百年还有期。 众人皆不悟，三教莫能规。 失道本无命，得时元有期。 有无皆自定，贪爱复何为。 红颜若春树，白发似秋霜。 俯仰一时过，驱驰三界忙。 繁华媚春雨，衰草淡秋烟。 日月暗相逼，古今经几迁。 罗绮千箱满，金珠万斛盈。 只知他物好，不觉自心萦。 厦屋千间峻，泪田万亩平。 自心非实相，他物是虚名。 世事无穷变，闷愁不测来。 志心行言之，门户少凶灾。 祸福相生灭，荣枯递献酬。 不穷天外乐，那免世间忧。 精神多削弱，机巧益巉岩。 未及开笼乌，还同作茧蚕。 遇战皆奔北，逢迷孰指南。 身合多自役，道德有谁参。 物裹光阴促，人间兴废多。 觉来浑似梦，贪得又如何。 彼此众生性，朝昏杂念魔。 静观无以救，长叹复如何。 假饶身富贵，不及性圆通。 道德希夷妙，春秋杀伐空。 大梦何时觉，浮生旷劫迷。 乾坤无昼夜，日月走东西。 妙理无由得，狂心不奈何。 念随空变化，精自欲消磨。 爱欲时光短，前程地岳深。 莫教空度日，切要紧降心。 宽容无怨害，柔弱胜刚强。 满口齿先落，终身舌未伤。 江海无拘容，乾坤自在人。 子陵犹傲帝，王霸不称臣。 石髓能延寿，丹砂解驻颜。 葛洪游大海，王烈遇深山。 触情常决烈，非道莫参差。 忍辱调猿马，安闲度岁时。 真阳加满腹，遐寿可齐天。 世事皆虚耗，心神莫倒颠。 像教终难入，名言不可求。 心中无杂念，境上得闲游。 浮华皆是梦，外物岂能坚。 若不通三一，如何出大千。 可畏风前烛，堪嗟水上沤。 百年如反掌，千古暂回头。 众生多患难，大道苦希微。 不有神仙福，难明造化机。 众生皆为口，终日苦劳心。 目眩空花乱，身随万物淫。 众生心不尽，大道理难明。 若要开天眼，须当灭世情。 日月交加迫，朝昏返复催。 光阴留不住，生死突将来。 自然生有漏，谁解入无余。
chunks.translated_text:
**White Hair**

White hair grows longer with the years,
Rosy cheeks fade day by day.
Failing to grasp the Dao’s arts,
I long to seek the pine and crane immortals.
Where to find the elusive spirit?
How to refine the returning elixir?
Following the Three Caverns’ secrets,
All worldly ties dissolve at last.

---

**Quatrain**

*Lantian*
A thousand valleys unfurl like brocade,
A thousand peaks stand as painted screens.
After rain, the blue waters gleam white,
Clouds part to reveal jade mountains green.

---

**Returning to Mount Long (Two Poems)**

The crane’s nature loves the mountains,
Cloud-capped peaks wondrous in summer’s heat.
To escape the wind, it crosses the sea,
After rain, it lingers not in pools.
Beneath the tall pine it sits alone,
By jagged stones it chants in solitude.
At night it rides a crimson-crested crane,
Visiting the immortals of the white clouds.

---

**On the Folly of Things (Two Poems)**

Heaven births the ten thousand kinds,
The ten thousand kinds belong to Heaven.
Why does it permit cruelty and tyranny,
Denying life its wholeness?
Yin and yang shape creation,
Life and death alternate in rise and fall.
Most piteous are the sentient beings,
Who suffer hearts devoid of goodness.

---

**Autumn Night (Two Poems)**

Dew-laden air holds autumn’s crispness,
Heaven’s light illumines the night.
A waning moon dims over the ridge,
Dawn’s wind clears the stream.
Jade-like dew stretches through the endless night,
The Silver River gleams in autumn’s sky.
Wind carries the valley’s purity,
Moonlight chills the celestial thoroughfare.

---

**Dawn (Two Poems)**

The Silver River shifts its hue,
Stars and constellations wheel in the void.
A half-moon gleams pale and white,
Dawn’s glow blazes crimson for miles.
Cranes dance as night yields to dawn,
A dream of wandering immortals startles awake.
The moon cradles the mountain, vast and growing,
Wind crosses the water, pristine and clear.

---

**Pure Joy (Two Poems)**

Three winters spent roaming the seas,
Six-petaled snowflakes blanket the earth.
To visit the grottoes of immortals,
I pass by the homes of Daoist adepts.
Wine flows smooth as golden dew,
Tea steeps with the fragrance of jade mushrooms.
Spirit refreshed, I grasp the three mysteries,
Harmony dispels a hundred ills.

---

**Creation (Three Poems)**

Creation wields divine transformation,
Forms fill the boundless cosmos.
The deluded suffer endlessly,
Even sages cannot awaken them.
The primal chaos split in an instant,
Empty blossoms flourish through the ages.
Wondrous changes shift a myriad times,
Yet the Dao and virtue abide in mystery.
A thousand flowers bloom in their season,
The three luminaries align in measured brightness.
The Nine Heavens’ palaces turn,
The eight directions arise

chunks.translated_text:
**Creation (Three Poems, continued)**

Not seeing desire before one’s eyes,
Only then does one know the heart’s emptiness.
With feeling, the Dao seems distant;
Without affairs, the mind feels vast.

Creation opens the celestial cavern,
The spirit endures the biting cold.
Boundless, the Three Realms stretch wide,
Profound, the hundred evils run deep.
The Dao abides through all ages,
Yet living beings never fathom the heart.
Of the five fortunes, only long life stands high;
Of the three luminaries, only humans align.

Leisurely I pass the years,
Unfettered, unbound by dust.
Sages and worthies are not far from the Dao—
Virtue lies in human cultivation.
If not sought within this heart,
Where else could it be found?

---

**Twenty Poems on Cultivating the Dao**

Eyes and ears depart from sound and color,
Body and mind transcend being and non-being.
Naturally, one communes with creation—
Why debate the fine or coarse?

The qi-refining, heart-cleansing adept
Soars above the world, a towering standard.
The heart, steadfast as a mountain,
Qi, ceaseless as the tides.

Ten thousand cares melt like wax,
The three poisons dissolve like ice.
Once free from the yin-yang shell,
What need to debate Mahāyāna or Hīnayāna?

The five eyes share one essence,
The three bodies branch from a single stem.
When the inch of heart is free of self,
Perfect enlightenment illumines the void.

Self-arising, self-vanishing,
Neither shallow nor deep.
Failing to realize the body is not the self,
How can one grasp that things are the mind?

Trampling the realm of emptiness,
Shattering the power of creation.
Floating clouds gather in stillness,
The sun of wisdom lights the zenith of meditation.

Where does a single word reside?
Ten thousand matters leave no trace.
Creation opens the celestial cavern,
The spirit endures the biting cold.

Though the eye’s faculties serve their use,
The mind’s ground rests in clarity.
For now, within this dream of life,
I wander freely with the myriad transformations.

The body may be narrow as a square foot,
Yet the heart spans the vastness of the void.
Though seas and mountains divide the four quarters,
The three luminaries are seen as one.

In the land of no-mind, quiescence reigns,
Radiance gleams through the great void.
Lapis lazuli cradles the jewel moon,
A net of pearls spans the heavens.

Ascending to truth, no turbid qi remains,
Transcending the world, one bears a pure standard.
Swiftly I depart the long night,
Obscurely I rise to the highest heavens.

The jade crucible boils with cinnabar,
The golden flask brims with fragrant wine.
Ghosts and spirits cannot fathom the heart,
Heaven and earth defy the measure of time.

Awakened from the dream of Huaxu,
The spirit roams the Purple Palace of Heaven.
I invite companions from the three isles,
Leisurely visiting immortals of the ten continents.

The Dao is attained through non-action,
Dharma arises from the mind’s intent.
If one can dissolve the three poisons,
One ought to transcend the five phases.

The Dao manifests through non-doing,
The heart arises through dharma.
Hun Yuan embraces all phenomena,
Tai Yi stirs the void to fame.

Movement arises from stillness,
Non-doing is itself doing.
Where the three lights do not shine,
The ten thousand forms reveal their clarity.

Originally attained without the heart’s effort,
Why labor with intent?
Where the five phases do not reach,
The myriad transformations all return.

The moon ascends, bright at mid-heaven,
The wind arrives, pure in the midnight hour.
In grotto-heavens, mortals never tread,
Yet the idle wanderer finds welcome.

The herb gardens and mushroom fields are pristine,
The golden altar and jade halls renewed.
Within the gourd, night never falls,
Beyond the world, spring is eternal.

The ten caves array the lofty perfected,
The three heavens house the exalted sages.
White clouds escort the traveler,
The azure bird conveys their letters.

---

**Ten Hymns in Praise of the Dao**

The Great Dao is without limit,
Long life knows no shore.
When kalpas end, the provisional returns to reality,
The turning of time blooms anew.

Virtue and the Dao bear no form,
No painting can capture their truth.
Sages and worthies silently aid the world,
Through past and present, they commune with the divine.

The Dao unfolds the three principles,
Heaven and earth display the ten thousand forms.
Mountains and rivers coil around the earth’s axis,
Sun and moon course through the celestial wheel.

In the indistinct, spirit is the trunk,
In the misty, qi is the sprout.
Heaven and earth are like long leaves,
Sun and moon resemble blossoms unfurled.

The Dao governs the flourishing of yin and yang,
Heaven perfects the work of creation.
Ghosts and spirits’ essence remains unseen,
Yet the qi of mountains and seas flows in secret.

The Dao governs the flourishing of yin and yang,
Heaven bestows the essence of rain and dew.
The three lights shine together,
The myriad transformations all take form.

The Dao governs the flourishing of yin and yang,
Humans receive the grace of rain and dew.
Through darkness and light, they follow sun and moon,
Creation emerges from heaven and earth.

Great simplicity embraces primordial qi,
From no direction, it receives the divine.
The divine penetrates creation,
Primordial qi weaves the warp and weft.

Great sages open heaven and earth,
Across the vast expanse, they array sun and stars.
Revolving, they divide day and night,
Through past and present, they illumine living beings.

Sun and moon radiate their brilliance,
Wind and thunder shake the depths.
In boundless harmony, no action is taken,
Yet transformation holds the numinous.

*End of Scroll Four of the Panxi Collection*

**Creation (Three Poems)**

Creation wields divine transformation,
Forms fill the boundless cosmos.
The deluded suffer endlessly,
Even sages cannot awaken them.
The primal chaos split in an instant,
Empty blossoms flourish through the ages.
Wondrous changes shift a myriad times,
Yet the Dao and virtue abide in mystery.
A thousand flowers bloom in their season,
The three luminaries align in measured brightness.
The Nine Heavens’ palaces turn,
The eight directions arise

chunks.original_text: 栖霞长春子邱处机撰 词 无俗念#1居磻溪 孤身赠蹬，泛秦川、西入磻溪乡域。 旷峪岩前幽涧畔，高凿云龛栖迹。 烟火俱无，箪瓢不置，日用何曾积。 饥餐渴饮，逐时村巷求觅。 选甚冷热残余，填肠塞肚，不假珍羞力。 好弱将来糊口过，免得庖厨劳役。 装贯皮囊，熏蒸关窍，图使添津液。 色身轻健，法身容易将息。 其二　岁寒守志 同云瑞雪，正三冬、郁闭严凝时节。 寂寞山家孤悄悄，终日无人谈说。 败袖重披，寒埪独坐，夜永愁难彻。 长更无寐，朔风穿户凄冽。 求饭朝入西村，临泉夹道，玉叶凌花结。 陕西有一种草，长二尺许，不知名。 秋冬则上茎死，下茎活。 晓寒则於半茎之间，结冰二棱，如箭羽状。 冻手频呵仍自恨，浊骨凡胎为劣。 昼夜参差，饥寒逼迫，早晚超生灭。 须凭一志，撞开千古心月。 其三　枰棋 前程路远，未昭彰、金玉仙姿灵质。 寂寞无功天赐我，棋局开颜销日。 古相岩前，清风台上，宛转晨餐毕。 幽人来访，雅怀闲斗机密。 初似海上江边，三三五五，乱鹤群鸦出。 打节冲关成阵势，错杂蛟龙蟠屈。 妙算嘉谋，斜飞正跳，万变皆归一。 含弘神用，不关方外经术。 其四　赞师 漫漫苦海，似东溟、深阔无边无底。 逮逮群生颠倒竞，还若游鱼争戏。 巨浪浮沉，洪波出没，嗜欲如痴醉。 漂沦无限，化鹏超度能几。 唯有当日重阳，惺惺了了，独有冲天志。 学易年高心大悟，掣断浮华缰击。 十载丹成，一时功就，脱壳成蝉蜕。 从师别后，更谁风范相继。 其五　蓑衣 深溪古岸，到秋来、莎密茸茸无极。 拣择修纤归洞府，虚落晴天吹炙。 两束丝乾，千条绳就，不假良工识。 闲轩亲自，结成渔父装饰。 时伴樵牧嬉游，青山绿水，带雨和烟适。 妙绝堪珍幽径晚，披雪冲开芦荻。 我本忘名，人皆易号，唤作蓑衣客。 磻溪皆呼蓑衣先生。 他年功满，化云天上无迹。 其六　材 虚心翠竹，禀天然、一气生来清独。 月下风前堪赏玩，嘲谑令人无俗。 嫩叶萧骚，隆冬掩映，秀出千林木。 英姿光润，状同玄圃寒玉。 好事东里田侯，乃东邻庵主也，南溪新种，使我开青目。 尽日高吟窗外看，风飐筠梢摇绿。 冉冉幽香，萧萧疏影，坐卧清肌肉。 云龛闲伴，雅怀惟称仙福。 其七　月 偎岩傍陇，益音隘长更、萧索昏魔非一。 皓月澄澄山上显，天角辉辉初出。 露结霜凝，金华玉润，淡荡何飘逸。 清临寰宇，发扬神秀姿质。 凄怆六合群情，淹沉幽昧，惨怛劬劳疾。 大阐良因弘济度，皆得逍遥宁谧。 浩气腾腾，余光蔼蔼，至性那亏失。 圆明法界，法轮常自充实。 其八　暮秋 霜风荡扬，舞飘零、木叶斜飞阡陌。 极目长郊凝望处，衰菊斓斑犹坼。 点点苍苔，漫漫朝露，渐结清霜白。 山川高下，尽成一片秋色。 潇洒万物摧残，凄凉天气，愁损征途客。 水谷云根无可玩，独有苍苍松栢。 悟道真仙，忘机逸士，亘古同标格。 欺寒压众，自来天地饶得。 其九　迷怀 群山四渎，暮天晴、挥斥阴魔潜伏。 太一岩前风道快，千尺波翻蟾足。 怒雪惊涛，冲堤拍岸，雷辊云翻逐。 青鸥白鹭，月明江上飞速。 高下万迭千群，相呼相召，会合清江曲。 宝月神珠时逗引，辊出都忘钤束。 踊跃飘飘，玲珑灿灿，价忽连城玉。 含弘光大，上天入地翻覆。
chunks.translated_text:
**Qiu Chuji of Eternal Spring at Mount Qixia: Lyrics Without Worldly Thoughts**

**#1 Dwelling at Panxi**
Alone I tread the steep path, drifting down the Qin River,
Westward into Panxi’s countryside.
Before the vast valley’s cliffs, beside the secluded stream,
I carve a cloud-high niche to rest my trace.
No smoke nor fire, no basket nor gourd laid by,
What daily needs have I to store?
Hungry, I eat; thirsty, I drink,
Seeking sustenance through village lanes as time allows.
Cold or hot, scraps or leftovers,
Fill my gut, no need for rare delicacies.
Weak or strong, I make do to pass the day,
Spared the toil of kitchen labor.
The skin-bag is clad, its pores steamed,
To moisten and replenish its fluids.
The colored body light and hale,
The Dharma-body easily nurtured.

**#2 Upholding Resolve in the Cold of Winter**
Amidst auspicious clouds and auspicious snow,
In the depths of winter’s frozen, sealed season,
A mountain hut stands silent and solitary,
All day without a soul to speak to.
Tattered sleeves worn again, alone in the cold cave,
The long night’s sorrow hard to endure.
Through endless watches, no sleep comes,
The north wind howls through the door, piercing and bleak.
Morning, I seek rice in the western village,
By the spring-lined path, jade-like leaves and frost-flowers form.
In Shaanxi grows a kind of grass, two feet tall, nameless.
In autumn and winter, its upper stem dies, the lower lives on.
At dawn’s chill, between the half-stems, ice forms two ridges,
Like the fletching of an arrow.
Frostbitten hands warmed by breath, yet still I resent
This impure frame, this mediocre mortal flesh.
Day and night, hunger and cold press in,
When will I transcend birth and death?
I must rely on steadfast will,
To shatter the moon of the ancient heart.

**#3 The Chessboard**
The road ahead is long, its splendor yet unseen—
Golden, jade-like, the immortal’s spirit and form.
In solitude, with no merit, heaven bestows upon me
A chessboard to brighten my face and while away the days.
Before the Ancient Minister’s Cliff, upon the Clear Wind Terrace,
I linger till the morning meal is done.
A recluse comes to visit,
Our refined hearts delight in the game’s subtle strategies.
At first, like riverside or seashore,
In threes and fives, scattered cranes and crows emerge.
Breaking ranks, charging passes, forming arrays,
Tangled like coiling dragons and serpents.
Brilliant calculations, clever schemes,
Diagonal leaps and straight advances—
Ten thousand changes all return to one.
In boundless divine function,
No need for arts beyond the world.

**#4 In Praise of the Master**
Vast and boundless, the bitter sea,
Like the eastern deep—profound, wide, bottomless.
Endless sentient beings, topsy-turvy in competition,
Like fish at play, vying in the waves.
Tossed by towering swells, submerged in surging waves,
Their cravings like drunken madness.
Adrift without end,
How few become soaring Peng to transcend!
Only that day’s Chongyang,
Clear-eyed and awakened, alone held lofty aspirations.
Studying the *Yi* in advanced years, his heart fully enlightened,
He snapped the reins of fleeting vanity.
After ten years, the elixir perfected,
In an instant, his work complete—
Shedding his shell like a cicada’s molt.
Since parting from the Master,
Who else has carried on his noble example?

**#5 The Straw Cape**
By the ancient banks of the deep stream,
When autumn comes, the sedge grows thick and lush without end.
Selecting the long and short, I return to the grotto,
Where the empty sky’s sunlight dries them.
Two bundles of silk dried, a thousand strands bound,
No need for skilled craftsmen’s discernment.
In my leisurely pavilion, I myself
Knit the fisherman’s garb.
At times, I roam with woodcutters and herders,
Through green mountains and emerald waters,
With rain and mist as my companions.
Exquisite beyond compare, to treasure in the twilight of secluded paths,
Donning it to push through reeds and rushes in the snow.
I have forgotten my name,
Others all call me by another—
The Straw Cape Guest.
Panxi calls me the Straw Cape Master.
When my work is complete in years to come,
I shall transform into clouds, vanishing without trace in the heavens.

**#6 The Bamboo**
Hollow-hearted, emerald bamboo,
Endowed by nature with a singular purity.
Beneath the moon, before the wind, fit for admiration,
Its banter free of worldly俗.
Tender leaves rustling,
Even in deep winter, they stand out amidst a thousand woods.
Its noble bearing, lustrous and smooth,
Like the cold jade of the Mystic Garden.
The good-hearted Lord Tian of Eastern Li—
The abbot of the eastern neighbor’s hermitage—
Newly planted them by South Stream,
Opening my eyes to verdant hues.
All day I gaze beyond the window, chanting high,
As the wind stirs the green tips of the bamboo.
Gently wafting, its subtle fragrance,
Sparse shadows swaying, soothing body and flesh.
A tranquil companion in the cloud niche,
Its refined spirit befits an immortal’s blessing.

**#7 The Moon**
Nestled by cliffs and ridges,
The long night’s stillness deepens—
Desolate, the demon of dusk is not alone.
The bright moon, clear and luminous, appears over the mountain,
Its radiance at the edge of heaven just emerging.
Dew congeals, frost forms,
Golden splendor, jade-like luster,
How ethereal and free!
Its purity descends upon the world,
Revealing the divine beauty of its form.
Mournful, the six directions’ multitudes,
Sunken in darkness, grieving in toil and sickness.
The great Dharma’s good causes widely spread salvation,
All attain carefree tranquility.
Vast qi surges,
Its lingering light suffuses—
How could this true nature ever falter?
The perfect brightness of the Dharma-realm,
The Dharma-wheel ever self-sustaining.

**#8 Late Autumn**
Frost-laden winds sweep and stir,
Dancing, scattering leaves slant across the paths.
Gazing to the farthest reaches of the long fields,
Withered chrysanthemums, mottled, still bloom.
Specks of gray-green moss,
Endless morning dew,
Gradually congealing into white frost.
Mountains high and low,
All become a single hue of autumn.
Unfettered, all things wither and decay,
The weather desolate and bleak,
Saddening the traveler on the road.
The roots of clouds in valleys offer no delight,
Only the verdant pines and cypresses remain.
Those who awaken to the Dao, true immortals,
Those who forget worldly schemes, recluses—
From ancient times, they share this standard.
Defying the cold, surpassing the multitude,
Ever since heaven and earth began, they have been thus endowed.

**#9 Confused Longing**
The four seas and myriad mountains,
At dusk, the sky clears—
Dispelling lurking yin demons.
Before the Taiyi Cliff, the wind’s path swift,
A thousand-foot wave churns the toad’s legs.
Furious snow, startling waves,
Crashing against the dike, pounding the shore,
Thunder rolls, clouds tumble in pursuit.
Green gulls and white egrets,
Fly swiftly over the moonlit river.
High and low, a thousand flocks, ten thousand groups,
Calling, summoning, gathering at the bend of the clear river.
The moon’s jewel, the divine pearl, now entice,
Rolling forth, all restraint forgotten.
Leaping, floating, exquisitely radiant,
Their worth suddenly like jade worth a thousand cities.
In boundless brilliance,
They overturn heaven and earth.

chunks.original_text: 其十　仙景 十洲三岛，运长春、不夜风光无极。 宝阁琼楼山上耸，突兀巍峨千尺。 绿桧乔松，丹霞密雾，簇拥神仙宅。 漫漫云海，水不何无处寻觅。 遥想徐福当时，楼船东下，一去无消息。 万里沧波空浩渺，远接天涯秋碧。 痛念人生，难逃物化，怎得游仙域。 超凡入圣，在乎身外身易。 其十一　乐道 迎今送古，叹春花秋月，年年如约。 物换星移人事改，多少翻腾沦落。 家给千兵，官封一品，得也无依托。 光阴如电，百年随手偷却。 有幸悟入玄门，擘开疑网，撞透真欢乐。 白玉壶中祥瑞罩，一粒神丹辉霍。 月下风前，天长地久，自在乘鸾鹤。 人间虚梦，不堪回首重作。 其十二　性通 法轮初转，慧风生、陡觉清凉无极。 皓色凝空嘉气会，豁荡尘烦胸臆。 五贼奔亡，三尸逃遁，表裹无踪迹。 神思安泰，湛然不动戈戟。 信步紫陌红尘，饥餐渴饮，度日随缘觅。 物外闲中天地宝，时复玎珰敲击。 后约参师，前程归路，自有真消息。 鹤书来召，坐升云汉游历。 沁园春　示众三首 世事纷纷，似水东倾，甚时了期。 叹利名千古，争驰虎豹，丘原一旦，总伴狐狸。 枳棘丛中，桑榆影裹，乱冢堆堆谁是谁？ 君知否，谩徒劳百载，空皱双眉。 争如归去来兮。 放四大、优游无所为。 向碧岩古洞，完全性命，临风对月，笑傲希夷。 一曲玄歌，千锺美酒，日月循环不老伊！ 童颜在，镇龟龄鹤寿，罢唱黄鸡。 又 列鼎雄豪，兔走乌飞，转头悄然。 似电光开夜，云中乍闪，晨霜迎日，草上难坚。 立马文章，题桥名誉，恍惚皆如作梦传。 争如我，效忘机息虑，返朴归原。 壶中异景堪怜。 是别有、风花雪月天。 玩四时时现，祥云瑞气，三光光罩，玉洞琼筵。 满泛流霞，高吟古调，骨健神清丹自圆。 真堪爱，待功成一举，永镇飞仙。 又 智慧男儿，速悟尘劳，勿将性疲。 但此身彼物，皆名幻化，多虚少实，不可追随。 万种缠绵，千般汨没，荏苒光阴老却伊。 争如向，太玄真教法，讨论希夷。 乾坤荡荡无依。 似一片、闲云出世奇。 悟性宗合道，恩山易挫，神舟得岸，苦海难迷。 行满功成，仙游羽化，物外何如土底归。 无他事，要升天入地，俱在心为。 其二　心通 大智闲闲，放荡无拘，任其自然。 寄雅怀幽兴，松间石上，高歌沉醉，月下风前。 玉女吹笙，金童舞袖，送我醺醺入太玄。 玄中理，尽浮沉浩浩，来去绵绵。 奇哉妙景难言。 算别是、人间一洞天。 傲立身敦厚，山磨岁月，从他轻薄，海变桑田。 神气冲和，阴阳升降，已占逍遥陆地仙。 无烦恼，任开怀纵笔，狂写诗篇。 其三 九日虢县修朝真醮 晔哗重阳，秀气飘飘，廓周大千。 正故庵交会，宾朋浩浩#2，青霄依约，鸿雁翩翩。 是处登高，衔杯逸兴，放旷犹如陆地仙。 朝真会，赞金风淡荡，玉露新鲜。 黄花嫩蕊堪怜。 散袅袅、清香满坐传。 使众人得味，皆明至道，群莺无语，独王去声秋天。 艳杏妖桃，繁华春景，莫与凝霜敢斗坚。 乘嘉趣，对芳丛烂饮，一醉三年。 水龙吟　西号 凤鸣南邑清嘉，大仙降迹行鸾地。 琳宫宝阁，星坛月馆，槐阴竹翠。 烟盖云幢，影摇寒殿，往来呈瑞。 向虚亭东望，平川似锦，洪河泛，渺天际。 山秀水甜人义。 遍坊村、各生和气。 我来不忍，轻归刘蒋#3，天心地肺。
chunks.translated_text:
**#10 Immortal Scenery**
The Ten Continents and Three Isles,
Bearing eternal spring—boundless the light of endless night.
Jade pavilions and crystal towers rise upon the peaks,
Towering, majestic, a thousand feet high.
Green cypress and towering pines,
Crimson clouds and dense mists,
Cluster round the immortals’ abode.
Vast the sea of clouds,
Yet where is the water to be found?

From afar, recalling Xu Fu of old,
His towering ships sailing east—
Gone without a trace.
Ten thousand miles of azure waves stretch empty and vast,
Far as the autumn sky’s edge.
Grieving for mortal life,
How escape the transformations of things?
How wander the immortal realms?
To transcend the mundane, to enter sagehood,
Lies in the ease of the body beyond the body.

---

**#11 Delighting in the Dao**
Welcoming the present, sending off the past,
Sighing for spring blossoms and autumn moons,
Year after year, as promised.
Things shift, stars drift, human affairs change—
How many rise and fall, sink into oblivion?
Households fed by a thousand soldiers,
Officials ennobled to the first rank,
Yet even these find no refuge.
Time flashes like lightning,
A hundred years stolen away in an instant.

Fortunate to awaken within the Mystery Gate,
To rend the web of doubt,
To crash through to true joy.
Enveloped in auspicious radiance within the white jade pot,
A single grain of divine elixir gleams bright.
Beneath the moon, before the wind,
Enduring as heaven and earth,
Freely riding the phoenix and crane.
The illusory dream of the world—
Unbearable to revisit once more.

---

**#12 Nature’s Permeation**
The Dharma Wheel first turns,
Wisdom’s wind arises—
Suddenly, boundless cool clarity.
Bright hues congeal in the void, auspicious qi gathers,
Dispelling the dust’s vexations from breast and mind.
The Five Thieves flee,
The Three Corpses vanish,
No trace within or without.
The spirit rests in peace,
Profoundly still, unmoved by spear or halberd.

Strolling the purple paths of the red dust,
Hungry, one eats; thirsty, one drinks,
Passing days as fate allows.
Beyond things, in leisure, lies heaven and earth’s treasure,
From time to time, the chime of jade rings.
A later pact to seek a master,
A future path to return home—
True tidings come of themselves.
The crane’s summons arrives,
Seated, one ascends the Milky Way to wander.

---

**Three *Shen Yuan Chun* Poems to Instruct the Assembly**

**I**
Worldly affairs surge like water rushing east—
When will they ever end?
Sighing for fame and profit through the ages,
Vying like tigers and leopards,
While hills and plains, in a single day,
All keep company with foxes and jackals.
Amid thorns and brambles,
Within the shade of mulberry and elm,
Who among the piled-up graves knows who is who?
Do you know?
In vain, a hundred years of toil,
Only to furrow one’s brows in vain.

How much better to return home!
Release the Four Great Elements,
Roaming freely, doing nothing.
By ancient cliffs and caves,
Preserve life’s essence;
Facing the wind, beneath the moon,
Laugh and wander in carefree ease.
A song of mystery,
A thousand goblets of fine wine,
As the sun and moon cycle on—never aging!
A youthful face remains,
Ever granting the tortoise’s longevity, the crane’s years,
No need to sing of the yellow cock’s lament.

**II**
Feasting from tripods in grand splendor,
Hare flees, crow flies—
In a turn of the head, all fades to silence.
Like lightning splitting the night,
A sudden flash amid the clouds;
Morning frost greeting the sun,
Hardly enduring upon the grass.
Proud steeds and literary fame,
Inscribed bridges and renown—
All fleeting, like tales from a dream.
How much better I,
Emulating the carefree, calming thoughts,
Returning to simplicity, restoring the original.

Pitiable the wondrous scenes within the pot—
A realm apart,
Of wind, flowers, snow, and moon.
Playing with the four seasons as they appear,
Auspicious clouds and propitious qi,
The Three Lights’ radiance enveloping,
Jade grottoes and jeweled feasts.
Overflowing cups of rosy dawn,
Chanting ancient melodies,
Bones strong, spirit clear—the elixir naturally rounds.
Truly worthy of love—
Awaiting the moment of accomplishment,
To eternally abide as a flying immortal.

**III**
Wise sons of men,
Swiftly awaken to the toils of the dusty world,
Do not weary your nature.
For this body and those things—
All are but illusions,
More empty than real,
Not to be pursued.
A thousand entanglements,
Ten thousand sinkings,
As time slips by, aging you.
How much better to turn
To the true teachings of the Great Mystery,
To discuss the carefree and formless.

Heaven and earth vast, with no reliance—
Like a single drifting cloud,
Emerging from the world, wondrous.
Awakening to the nature’s union with the Dao,
The mountain of karma easily crumbles;
The divine boat reaches shore,
The bitter sea cannot bewilder.
When deeds are complete and merit fulfilled,
One soars as an immortal, transformed by feathers—
What compares to returning to the earth’s depths?
Nothing else matters—
To ascend to heaven, to enter the earth,
All lies in the mind’s doing.

---

**#2 Mind’s Permeation**
Great wisdom, leisurely and free,
Unfettered, following nature’s course.
Entrusting refined feelings and hidden joys,
Among pines and upon rocks,
Singing loudly, deeply drunk,
Beneath the moon, before the wind.
Jade maidens play the sheng,
Golden youths dance with sleeves,
Escorting me, tipsy, into the Great Mystery.
Within the Mystery’s principle,
All floating and sinking, vast and boundless,
Coming and going, ceaselessly.

Wondrous! The ineffable marvelous scene—
Count it as another
Heavenly grotto in the human world.
Proudly standing, body steadfast,
Mountains wear away the years;
Let the frivolous change,
Seas turn to mulberry fields.
Spirit and qi harmoniously surge,
Yin and yang rise and fall—
Already claiming the carefree life of an earthbound immortal.
Without affliction,
Freely open the heart, wield the brush,
Wildly inscribing poems.

---

**#3 On the Ninth Day, Offering the Morning True Rite at Guoxian**
Resplendent Double Ninth,
Auspicious qi drifting, drifting,
Encompassing the vast thousand worlds.
Just as the old hermitage gathers,
Guests and friends in throngs,
The azure sky faintly visible,
Wild geese gracefully gliding.
Everywhere, climbing heights,
Holding cups, carefree delight,
Unfettered as earthbound immortals.
At the Morning True Assembly,
Praising the golden wind’s gentle sway,
The jade dew’s freshness.

Tender yellow blossoms, lovely buds,
Wafting delicate fragrance,
Filling the seats.
Enabling all to taste and savor,
Each awakening to the supreme Dao,
While the flock of orioles falls silent—
Only the autumn king’s voice rings through the sky.
Lush apricots, bewitching peaches,
Spring’s riotous splendor—
None dare contend with frost’s steadfastness.
Seizing the joyous moment,
Facing the radiant clusters, drinking to intoxication,
A single drunkenness lasting three years.

---

**Water Dragon Chant: Western Hao**
Phoenix cries in the southern village, pure and fine,
A great immortal descends, riding the phoenix’s land.
Jewel palaces and precious pavilions,
Star altars and moon halls,
Scholars’ groves and verdant bamboo.
Incense canopies and cloud banners,
Shadows swaying in the cold halls,
Coming and going, manifesting auspiciousness.
Gazing east from the empty pavilion,
The plain spreads like brocade,
The mighty river flows,
Vast as the horizon.

Mountains fair, waters sweet, people righteous—
Every ward and village
Brimming with harmonious qi.
I come, unable to bear
Lightly departing from Liu and Jiang,
Heaven’s heart and earth’s lungs.

gainst the dike, pounding the shore,
Thunder rolls, clouds tumble in pursuit.
Green gulls and white egrets,
Fly swiftly over the moonlit river.
High and low, a thousand flocks, ten thousand groups,
Calling, summoning, gathering at the bend of the clear river.
The moon’s jewel, the divine pearl, now entice,
Rolling forth, all restraint forgotten.
Leaping, floating, exquisitely radiant,
Their worth suddenly like jade worth a thousand cities.
In boundless brilliance,
They overturn heaven and earth.

chunks.original_text: 须待他时，暗淘真秀，育成丹桂。 去长安路上，眠冰卧日，作终身异。 其二　警世 算来浮世忙忙，竞争嗜欲闲烦恼。 六朝五霸，三分七国，东征西讨。 武略今何在，空凄怆，野花芳草。 叹深谋远虑，雄心壮气，无光彩，尽灰槁。 历遍长安古道。 问郊墟、百年遗老。 唐朝汉市，秦宫周苑，明明见告。 故址留连，故人消散，莫通音耗。 念朝生暮死，天长地久，是谁能保。 其三　夜晴 夜晴寥廓初寒，淡天莹彻瑠璃翠。 无阴树下，长安楼上，月明风细。 百祸潜消，万家同赏，一般清味。 见金星朗朗，银河耿耿，交光灿，满天地。 流转碧空如水。 任纵横、略无凝滞。 冲山拍海，倾光腾秀，绵绵吐瑞。 达了从兹，宝缾坚固，玉浆时泥#4。 把衷情欲诉，何人会得，且陶陶醉。 其四　春兴二首 吴天空阔初晴，气回万物欣欣茂。 亭台俯仰，山川高下，糙成锦绣。 碧洞清泉，响闻迢递，一声长溜。 更时时注目，悠悠远看，青峰上，白云奏。 无限灵禽异兽。 慰闲心、不辞柴瘦。 含风翠柏，双崖争长，千株竞秀。 耀日丹台，四时为伴，百年随寿。 任寒来暑往，星移物换，得高眠昼。 又 洞天春色盈盈，乱山秀出千堆锦。 云收雨敛，晓晴烟淡，碧空横枕。 高卧怡怡，顿开怀抱，释迷忘寝。 看仙花瑞草，迎风照日，腾光彩，异凡品。 欢庆时丰岁稔。 万邦宁、百邪俱禁。 太平国裹，长安陌上，纵横有甚。 大道无疑，傍门斜径，不须详审。 是从来浩劫，神仙过路，但曾经恁。 其五　道运 混元南岳初开，瑞云透出昆仑表。 星移电转，阴升阳降，红光缥缈。 鹤舞鸾翔，看乌龟共，赤蛇蟠远。 尽鸿蒙一气，烹成造化，神仙道，片时了。 云散十洲三岛。 洞天深、月明风袅。 此时占得，长生门户，遐龄体调。 吟咏从他，海移山变，石枯松老。 伴烟霞独向，非非境外，恨知音少。 满庭芳　述怀 漂泊形骸，颠狂踪迹，状同不系之舟。 逍遥终日，食饱恣遨游。 任使高官重禄，金鱼袋、肥马轻裘。 争知道，庄周梦蝶，蝴蝶梦庄周。 休休。 吾省也，贪财恋色，多病多忧。 且麻袍葛屦，闲度春秋。 逐疃巡村过处，儿童尽、呼饭相留。 深知我，南柯梦断，心上别无求。 其二　警世 百尺危楼，千间峻宇，艳歌出入从容。 幻身无赖，何异烛当风。 旧日掀天富贵，当时耀、绝代英雄。 百年后，都归甚处，一日一尽成空。 诸公。 闻早悟，抽身退迹，跃出樊笼。 念本初一点，牢落无穷。 幸遇时平岁稔，偷闲好、消息圆融。 忘机处，灵波湛湛，独镇水晶宫。 其三 余因求道，西留关中十五余年，闻乡中善士为葬先考妣，不胜感激。 遂成小词寄谢云。 幼稚抛家，孤贫乐道，纵心物外飘蓬。 故山坟珑，时节罢修崇。 幸谢乡豪并力，穿新圹、起塔重重。 遗骸并，同区改葬，迁入大茔中。 人从。 关外至，皆言盛德，悉报微躬。 耳闻言，心下感念无穷。 自恨无由报德，弥加志、笃进玄功。 深回向，虔心道友，各各少灾灾凶。 其四　九日 塞雁声回，园林色变，暮秋别是风光。 练波横地，锦树映天长。 过雨云山磊落，迎霜茂、金菊芬芳。 佳辰会，千门万户，欢笑庆重阳。 嘉祥。 谁得遇，吾门四友，极味先尝。 乃频沾清露，时倒霞浆。 饮罢醍醐灌顶，归来后、月满虚堂。
chunks.translated_text:
**Waiting for the Time**
We must await the hour when hidden dregs are sifted,
Nurturing the cinnamon of elixir’s truth.
On Chang’an’s road, they sleep on ice and lie beneath the sun,
Becoming lifelong marvels.

**II. Admonition to the World**
Counting the haste of this floating life,
All vie in craving and idle vexation.
Six dynasties, five hegemons,
Three kingdoms split seven ways—
Eastward campaigns, westward wars.
Where now are those martial schemes?
Only desolation,
Wildflowers and fragrant grasses.
Mourn the deep designs, the far-reaching plans,
The heroic hearts and towering qi—
All dimmed to ash, all withered to dust.

I have traversed Chang’an’s ancient roads,
Asking the hundred-year-old elders of the ruins.
Tang courts and Han markets,
Qin palaces and Zhou gardens—
All plainly declare their tale.
Former sites linger, yet
Former men have scattered,
No word left to send.
Consider the ephemeral—
Born at dawn, dead by dusk—
Who can secure heaven’s permanence, earth’s endurance?

**III. Clear Night**
The night clears, vast and chill at first,
The pale sky gleams like flawless beryl.
Beneath the unshaded trees,
Atop Chang’an’s towers,
The moon shines bright, the wind is fine.
A hundred ills dissolve in silence,
Ten thousand households share the same pure savor.
See Venus gleam,
The Silver River gleam,
Their radiance intertwined,
Filling heaven and earth.

The azure void flows like water,
Unobstructed in its boundless course.
It surges against mountains, crashes upon seas,
Pouring forth light, teeming with splendor,
Endlessly emitting auspiciousness.
From this moment on, understanding dawns—
The treasure vase stands firm,
The jade nectar flows freely.
To whom shall I pour out my heart’s longing?
Who will comprehend?
Let us drink deep and grow blissfully drunk.

**IV. Spring Inspirations (Two Poems)**

**I**
The Wu sky stretches wide, newly clear,
Qi revives, and all things flourish in joy.
Pavilions rise and fall,
Mountains soar and valleys dip,
Woven into brocade’s richness.
Emerald grottoes, limpid springs—
Their echoes ring afar,
A single, ceaseless stream.
Ever and again, I lift my gaze,
Gazing into the distance,
Where blue peaks touch
The white clouds’ melody.

Countless numinous birds and wondrous beasts
Console my idle heart,
Unmoved by woodcutter’s lean frame.
Wind-whispering verdant pines,
Twin cliffs vie in height,
A thousand trees compete in splendor.
Sunlit cinnabar terraces,
Four seasons for companions,
A hundred years of life’s span.
Let cold come, let heat depart,
Let stars shift and things transform—
I sleep high through the day.

**II**
Grotto-heavens brim with spring’s hues,
Jumbled peaks embroider a thousand heaps of brocade.
Clouds withdraw, rain ceases,
Dawn clears, mist thins,
The azure sky lies pillowed across the land.
I recline in bliss,
My cares unfurled,
Delusions dissolved, sleep forgotten.
Behold the immortal blossoms, auspicious herbs—
Facing the wind, bathed in sunlight,
They glow with radiance,
Transcending the mundane.

A time of joy and abundant harvest,
All nations at peace,
Every evil restrained.
Within this realm of Great Peace,
On Chang’an’s streets,
What hinders free passage?
The Great Dao is without doubt,
Side paths and crooked trails
Need no scrutiny.
For since the primal kalpas,
Even immortals passing by
Have known such scenes.

**V. The Dao’s Course**
At the Primordial’s first unfolding on Southern Marchmount,
Auspicious clouds pierced Kunlun’s outer bounds.
Stars shifted, lightning turned,
Yin ascended, Yang descended,
Crimson light drifted in the distance.
Cranes danced, phoenixes soared,
Watching the black tortoise and
The crimson serpent coil afar.
All within the primordial qi,
Refined into creation—
The Dao of immortals
Completed in an instant.

Clouds disperse across the Ten Isles and Three Mountains,
Within the grotto-heavens, deep—
Moon bright, wind gentle.
Now I claim
The gate of longevity,
A body tuned to distant years.
Let others chant as they will,
Though seas shift and mountains change,
Though stones wither and pines age.
I alone wander amidst mist and rosy clouds,
Beyond the realm of *fei-fei*—
Only lamenting that few know my tune.

**Lyrics to "Court Filled with Fragrance"**

**I. Expressing My Heart**
Adrift in form, unmoored in spirit,
My madcap traces resemble an untethered boat.
Carefree all day,
Well-fed, I roam at will.
Let them offer high office and heavy emoluments,
Golden fish pendants,
Fat horses and light furs—
What do I know?
Zhuang Zhou dreamed of butterflies,
Butterflies dreamed of Zhuang Zhou.

Enough.
I understand:
Greed for wealth, lust for beauty,
Sickness and sorrow abound.
Better a hempen robe and straw sandals,
Passing the seasons in leisure.
As I wander village lanes,
Children all call out,
Offering rice to detain me.
I know well—
The dream of Southern Branch is over,
My heart seeks nothing more.

**II. Admonition to the World**
A hundred-foot tower, perilous,
A thousand grand halls,
With wanton songs and effortless comings and goings.
This illusory body—how wretched!
No different from a candle in the wind.
Once, they flaunted boundless wealth,
Dazzling as the age’s brightest heroes.
A hundred years hence,
Where will all this lead?
In a single day, all turns to emptiness.

Gentlemen,
Awaken early!
Withdraw, retreat,
Leap free from the cage.
Recall the original, single spark—
Lost in endless wandering.
Fortunate to meet an age of peace and plenty,
Steal moments of leisure,
Let understanding grow round.
Where thoughts dissolve,
Luminous waves settle,
Alone I guard the crystal palace.

**III**
In my youth, I left home,
Poor and alone, delighting in the Dao,
My heart drifting beyond the world like tumbleweed.
The graves in my homeland,
Neglected through the seasons,
No rites performed.
Fortunate that the village’s worthy men joined forces,
Dug new tombs,
Erected pagodas in layers.
The remains were gathered,
Moved together,
Reinterred in the great burial ground.

People from beyond the pass
All speak of their great virtue,
Each repaying my humble self.
Hearing their words,
My heart brims with boundless gratitude.
I regret I have no way to repay their kindness,
Only redoubling my resolve,
Deepening my devotion to the mysterious work.
With profound reverence,
I dedicate this to my Daoist companions,
Each may suffer fewer calamities.

**IV. The Ninth Day**
Wild geese call from the frontier,
Gardens change their hues—
Late autumn bears a different scene.
Silken waves stretch across the land,
Brocade trees mirror the endless sky.
After rain, clouds and mountains stand bold,
Frost-kissed, golden chrysanthemums bloom in splendor.
On this fine day,
A thousand gates, ten thousand households
Celebrate Double Ninth with joy and laughter.

Auspiciousness—
Who is blessed to meet
The four friends of my gate,
First to taste the purest flavors?
They drink deeply of clear dew,
Often pouring rosy nectar.
When the draught of ghee anoints their crowns,
They return home—
The moon fills the empty hall.

chunks.translated_text:
Free from care, blissfully joyous,
Drunk and deep in the immortal realm.
Divine radiance gleams from three heads—
*Shengsheng Man* #5

Joy and sorrow cast aside,
Sight and sound forgotten,
From the first, called "Seeking Stillness."
Ignorant of the root,
They stubbornly debate right and wrong.
Plucking flowers, picking leaves in vain,
Exhausting schemes to no avail.
Such matters—
All may grasp them easily,
Yet none can truly follow.

Not in verbal sparring,
Nor in vying before others,
With pretentious learning and vast knowledge.
The noble one contends not,
Only seeks to return to simplicity and dispel doubt.
In darkness, release the four great elements,
Let worldly toils scatter in an instant.
Once recognized,
The wise will clap their hands and laughingly return.

Furthermore—
Probing the Three Teachings,
Guiding all beings,
All are led to align with Heaven.
Aspiring to the Dao, cultivating truth,
In movement, stillness, sitting, lying—all is devotion.
First, preserve the body’s purity,
Within, ever hold compassion for all beings.
Subdue sharpness,
This is the initial act and foundation of the beginner’s mind.

Gently refining temperament,
Cutting away residual desires,
Ever pruning folly and delusion.
With blessings and wisdom both complete, enlightenment dawns,
Naturally entering stillness.
Within the sacred chamber, no remorse,
Amidst all circumstances, no doubt.
Thoroughly awakened,
All of empty space severs right and wrong.

Moreover—
The gate of truth-cultivation,
The great tradition of the Daoist family,
A boundless realm of eternal spring.
Vital essence brimming,
In leisure, another world within a gourd.
Heaven’s midst, natural joy,
Revolving the Three Lights day by day.
No reliance on cunning,
Only pure wind, level and vast,
The sagely Dao, even and serene.

A single thought returns to the quiet homeland,
The Three Palaces enshrouded,
Pure spirit—ten thousand streams return to the source.
Vast and boundless, divine radiance comes and goes,
Penetrating the bones, unbroken.
The practitioner suddenly sheds all artifice,
Awaiting the day of accomplishment, ascending as an immortal.
For those yet to begin,
Seek a single word of clarity within these verses.

Ascending the cinnabar clouds—
The grotto-heavens clear,
Divine mountains fair,
Few tread their paths.
All cling to the towering dream of the world.
Immortal winds and auspicious scenes,
Though suddenly before their eyes, they remain as blind.
In the River of Love, all day,
They rise and sink, drifting to and fro.

East they rise, west they set,
South they die, north they live.
Turning through the four directions,
Transforming into myriad forms.
When will this fleeting life
Open the eye of Dao and quell desire?
May their spiritual essence awaken,
Grasping the flower of emptiness,
Ascending the distant shore.

chunks.original_text: 赠京兆府统军夹谷龙虎 感皇恩，承天诏，控西南。 大门敞、高对烟岚。 双权再任，过期无代复登三。 晏然军国，事和平，灾害封缄。 年将暮，心归道，搜玄路，访清谈。 降尊宠、谦下无惭。 山人放旷，本来无得有何参。 但能慈忍，戒荒淫、名挂仙衔。 其三 答陇州防御裴满镇国 厌尘劳，抛家计，慕清闲。 向物外、观照人间。 须臾变灭，蜃楼歌欹侧海涛翻。 暂时光景，转身休、百岁如弹。 掀天富，倾城丽，过人勇，彻心奸。 尽逐境、颠倒循环。 纷纷醉梦，往来争夺苦摧残。 不如闻早，伴烟霞，高卧云山。 月中仙　赏月 日色西沉，上高台、迥观天地寥廓。 疏星隐现，空#8一轮明月，昭昭无着。 皓然三界外，似百炼、青铜鉴跃。 处处息光被，家家照临，庭户启溟漠。 长生万里清风，助乾坤荡摇，云雾难作。 仙宫宝殿，正烂霞金碧，相辉参错。 大哉销夜景，镇千古、含弘磊落。 有志攀青桂，蟾宫兔边看捣药。 其二　山居 侧磬悬锺，慕巢由、隐沦活计萧索。 天然耿介，爱一身孤僻，逍遥云壑。 利名千种事，我心上、何曾挂着。 幸遇清平世，诸军宴安，刀剑罢挥霍。 民歌两穗之丰，教门兴我忘，三岛之约。 来宾去友，递日常幽谷，骖鸾骑鹤。 洞前无限景，异花秀、香风喷薄。 更谢汧源众，分餐助余长啸乐。 其三　对松 落落长松，倚浮云、大山高占幽僻。 亭亭隐士，爱洞天岩穴，深藏虚极。 对门开是景，挂猿狖、离罗峭壁。 尽日无他事，唯调虎龙，交媾坐盘石。 时时鹤听嘉音，动笙簧转流，空外飘激。 人明至道，恶管弦幽噎，花间沉溺。 出群常羡此，岁寒重、孤凝黛色。 炼性超於彼，身闲永同居寿域。 瑶台月　自咏 平生懒堕。 只赢得、无忧一枕高卧。 蓬头垢面，不管形骸摧挫。 任三光、日夜奔驰，放四大、林泉担荷。 深溪畔，幽岩左。 青山拥，白云锁。 灾祸。 雷轰电掣，无由近我。 日午起行了还坐。 把旧习般般打破。 清闲处，唯有这些儿个。 倦贪心、乐受贫穷，爱恣意、慵兴烟火。 粮无贮，丹无货。 萧然唱，洒然和。 堪可。
chunks.translated_text:
**To Jiaogu Longhu, Military Commissioner of Jingzhao Prefecture**

Grateful for imperial grace, bearing Heaven’s decree,
He guards the southwest—
The great gates stand open, high against mist and haze.
Twice entrusted with dual authority,
Beyond his term, yet none replace him; he ascends again.
The realm and army rest in peace,
All affairs harmonious, disasters sealed away.

The years draw late,
His heart turns to the Dao,
Searching the mysterious path, seeking pure discourse.
Lowering his noble rank, humbled without shame,
A mountain man, unbound—
Originally possessing nothing, what is there to compare?
Only through kindness and forbearance,
Renouncing excess and lust,
May his name be inscribed among the immortals’ ranks.

**Part Three**
**In Reply to Peiman Zhen’guo, Defender of Longzhou**

Weary of worldly toil, he casts aside family cares,
Yearning for purity and leisure.
Beyond the mundane, he gazes upon the mortal realm—
In an instant, all shifts and fades,
Like mirage towers, songs tilting, or surging sea waves.
Fleeting as a moment’s light,
A lifetime vanishes like a flick of the finger.

Sky-toppling wealth, city-toppling beauty,
Peerless valor, heart-piercing cunning—
All chase after illusions, trapped in endless cycles.
Drunken and deluded, they contend and struggle,
Worn to ruin by suffering.
Better to awaken early,
To dwell with mist and clouds,
High in the mountains, lost in slumber.

**Moon Immortal • Moon Gazing**
The sun sinks in the west,
I ascend the high terrace, gazing afar at heaven and earth’s vast expanse.
Scattered stars flicker in and out,
While a single bright moon hangs in the void,
Luminous, unattached.
Radiant beyond the Three Realms,
Like a hundred-times-refined bronze mirror, it leaps forth.
Its light pours everywhere,
Illuminating every household,
Opening gates to boundless emptiness.

A wind of eternal life, a thousand miles of clarity,
Aids the swaying of heaven and earth,
Though clouds and mist dare not arise.
In the immortal palaces and jeweled halls,
Golden splendor and azure radiance intertwine.
Great indeed is the night’s dissolving glow,
Everlasting through the ages, vast and unconfined.
Those with aspiration,
Climb the jade osmanthus,
To watch the toad in the moon pound elixir.

**Part Two • Mountain Dwelling**
Bells and chimes hang aslant,
I admire the recluses Chao and You,
Their secluded lives sparse and desolate.
By nature upright and unyielding,
I love my solitary self,
Wandering carefree through clouded valleys.
A thousand kinds of fame and profit—
Never once have they lingered in my heart.
Fortunate to live in this era of peace,
All armies at rest,
Swords and spears stilled.

The people sing of two ears of grain in abundance,
The teachings flourish, and I forget my vow—
The pact of the Three Isles.
Guests come and friends depart,
Day after day, I dwell in the hidden valley,
Riding phoenixes and cranes.
Before the grotto, endless scenes unfold—
Exotic blossoms bloom, fragrant winds burst forth.
I thank the people of Qianyuan,
Who share their meals to aid my long, joyous whistling.

**Part Three • Before the Pine**
Towering, the tall pine,
Leaning on floating clouds, claims the heights of the great mountain’s seclusion.
Solemn and aloof, the hidden scholar,
Loves the grotto-heaven’s caves,
Deeply concealed, utterly empty.
Before the gate, the view unfolds—
Gibbons and apes hang from the sheer cliffs.
All day, no other affairs,
Only harmonizing dragons and tigers,
Mating upon the seated boulder.

From time to time, cranes listen to fine music,
As the pipes and flutes flow and swirl,
Drifting beyond the empty sky.
Those enlightened to the supreme Dao
Detest the stifling of pipes and strings,
The drowning in flowers and indulgence.
I always admire this one,
Steadfast through the cold years,
Its dark hue unyielding.
Refining my nature beyond it,
I dwell in leisure, forever within the realm of longevity.

**Jade Terrace Moon • Self-Reflection**
All my life, indolent and idle,
I’ve gained only this—
A pillow of no cares, high in slumber.
Unkempt hair, a grimy face,
Heedless of the body’s decay.
I let the three luminaries—
Sun, moon, and stars—race day and night,
And the four great elements—
Wood, fire, earth, and water—bear the burdens of forests and springs.

By the deep stream,
To the left of the secluded crag,
Green mountains embrace,
White clouds enclose.
Disasters—
Thunder roars, lightning flashes,
Yet none can approach me.
At noon, I rise, walk, then sit again,
Shattering every old habit.
In this tranquil place,
Only these few remain.

Weary of greed, I delight in poverty,
Loving the freedom to idle, indifferent to smoke and fire.
No grain stored, no elixir sold.
Empty, I sing;
Unfettered, I harmonize.
Such is enough.

chunks.translated_text:
The immortal’s path unfinished,
I wander at ease, passing time as it flows.

**II. Exhorting to Wine**

Fleeting fame, fleeting gain—
I sigh for past and present,
the ceaseless toil of men lost in the mire.
Vast the cosmos,
how many sentient beings, wise or foolish,
all wear themselves out in vain,
spending their days in greed,
racing to their deaths in restless striving.
Behold the sun and moon,
lament this fleeting life—
a hundred years of life,
a spring’s dream of sleep.
What waste!
Better to fill the cup,
let rosy clouds escort my drunkenness,
bolster the four great elements to invigorate the spirit.
Discern the myriad transformations,
set aside talk of wealth and rank.
From time to time, seek out
the mountain-dwelling Daoist at play,
emulate his wild abandon,
chanting high beyond the world,
celebrating the bold zest of wine’s fine savor.
Open the heart’s embrace,
forget sorrow, strike the cares away.
Unravel the tangles,
blunt the sharp edges.

Far off,
green pines and white cranes,
year after year, drift by in serenity.

**Magnolia Blossoms Slow: The Turning Wheel**

I sigh for the numinous source, long lost through the ages,
boundless in truth, yet at ease.
Since the primordial simplicity scattered and form arose,
the chaos worn thin,
I have fallen into the prison of wandering.
Limping and stumbling, turning through the four directions,
lost in the ford, mired in the bitter sea’s depths.
The dharma-realm’s multitudes stir in turmoil,
dream-spirits drift through a thousand ages of longing.

Sunk in the flow—
bones traded like mountains,
who knows when the journey’s end will come?
Best to forge the true emptiness,
let the three luminaries’ wisdom shine,
gather the clouds of ten thousand kalpas.
In the end, one must cast off body and life,
yet how long will you cling to face and head?
Shatter the single point at the center,
and at once ascend the divine vessel to the other shore.

chunks.original_text: 西虢作善者多，而感应屡至。 伫登临旷望，涌云气、北山兴。 旋恍惚阴阳，虚无变化，寥廓充盈。 奇峰状如太华，霭棱层、峻极染空青。 急雨翻盆泼墨，迅雷激电飞声。 威灵。 大骋神通，三伏暑、结凝冰。 叹是处飘风，良田遇害，厦屋遭倾。 唯斯道乡幸感，屡涔涔至也忽然轻。 深信皇天辅德，善因恶果分明。 望海潮　学道 神仙风范，长生门户，从来道德为基。 余外万般，留心一念，颠狂造作皆非。 真教示开迷。 自上古轩辕，龙驾腾飞。 代代相传授，至今日，尽归依。 虚无千圣同规。 盖摧残嗜欲，剖判天机。 贪利喻雠，观身是梦，婪耽不整容仪。 恬素返希夷。 任垢面蓬头，纸袄麻衣。 行满都抛却，泛寥廓，步云霓。 其二　脱俗 坚牢基址，清闲门户，生涯不比尘缘。 幽旷大山，通明上士，逶迤仿效神仙。 勤动向岩前。 缓植桂栽松，药圃芝田。 万仞高峰下，伴龟鹤，度流年。 吾常志僻心颠。 爱箪瓢淡薄，词翰嘲掀。 幽洞小溪，开怀取兴，时成短句长篇。 驰马胜花笺。 任奋笔狂吟，走雾飞烟。 放荡如如性，混终日，恣乾乾。 醉蓬莱 九月十八日西虢刘氏醮 乍三清鹤降，万里云收，昊天空翠。 玉磬琅琅，动乾坤声锐。 尽日修斋，虚堂设醮，庆大仙恩惠。 满献霞觥，长歌妙曲，留连师意。 二九良辰，菊花开遍，正是重阳，素秋佳气。 烂熳香风，健飘飖丹桂。 秀景稀逢，上真难遇，幸一时相际。 雁影沉沙，蟾光照夜，醺醺同醉。 齐天乐　忆法眷 自东离海上，元本三州，四人同契。 异域殊乡，同行并坐，终日相将游戏。 谈玄论妙，究方外清虚，道家真味。 唱和从容，一时法眷情何义。 如今分头迥然，苦志勤心，磨炼各逃倾逝。 既是飘零，难为会合，幽僻关山迢递。 乾坤间隔。 望落落犹如，晓星之势。 再遇何年，驾云朝上帝。 汉宫春　苦志 二十年间，大魔交正阵，约度千重。 狂弓迸箭暗窗，零落无穷。 因心睡觉，透历年、无碍真宗。 兴慧剑，群魔自然消散，独骋威雄。 出入锐光八表，算神机莫测，天网难笼。 驱云扫雾荡摇，法界无踪。 飞腾变化，任太虚、萧瑟鸣风。 巡四海，峥嵘往来，□□几个人同。 贸客住　修道 四元遇，过华山、共临秦地。 咏歌谈笑，暗阐重阳嘉趣。 无为自令人化，有幸天使，官磨相间阻。 东连海上，奋三公高义，大开门户。 教行普。 叹我离群，忘形慵举。 内省无愆，外患何忧何惧。 三光盛衰，交变万化，恩害相生天地数。 留身且住。 待青霄得志，坦然行步。 梅花引　磻溪旧隐 无名客，无牵迫。 无桑无梓无田宅。 古岩前，老松边。 长歌隐几，徐徐考太玄。 玄中默论无生死，实际何曾分彼此。 贯千经，协三灵。 包含万化，都归一念冥。 行不劳，坐不倦。 任行任坐随吾便。 晚风轻，暮天晴。 逍遥大道，南溪上下平。 溪东幸获忘形友，月下时斟消夜酒。 酒杯停，月华清。 披襟散发，欣欣唱道情。 六么令　法性 浑沦朴散，天地始玄黄。 乌飞兔走渐生，群物类开张。 一点如如至性，扑入臭皮囊。 游魂失道，随波逐浪，万年千载不还乡。 错了鸿蒙体段，憎爱日相望。 却认父母形骸，做我好容光。 劫劫轮回贩骨，受尽苦和殃。 何人闻早，寻他归路，莹然恢廓旧嘉祥。 芰荷香　乞食 日奚为。 信腾腾绕村，觅饭充饥。
chunks.translated_text:
**To the Tune of "Gazing at the Sea Tide"**

In Xigu, those who do good abound,
and responses come again and again.
I stand in wait, gazing afar,
where clouds surge and qi rises from the northern mountains.
In an instant, the interplay of yin and yang shifts,
transforming through emptiness and nothingness,
vast and boundless, filling all.

The strange peaks take the shape of Mount Taihua,
their layered ridges steep, dyeing the sky with azure.
Sudden rain pours like ink from an overturned basin,
while swift thunder and flashing lightning roar.

**Mighty spirits!**
They unleash their divine powers,
turning the scorching heat of triple summer to solid ice.
Yet alas, where the whirlwind passes,
good fields are ravaged,
and grand houses topple.
Only in this land of the Dao do blessings flow,
where sudden lightness follows ceaseless tears.
I deeply trust that Heaven aids virtue,
and the fruits of good and evil are clearly divided.

---

**To the Tune of "Gazing at the Sea Tide"**
**On Cultivating the Dao**

The demeanor of immortals,
the gateway to longevity—
from ancient times, virtue and the Dao have been their foundation.
All else, if pursued with even a single thought,
leads to madness and folly, all in vain.
The true teaching dispels delusion,
handed down since the days of the Yellow Emperor,
who soared on a dragon’s chariot.
Passed through generations,
to this day, all return to its embrace.

The void and nothingness—
a rule shared by a thousand sages.
For it crushes cravings and desires,
revealing the secrets of heaven.
Greed and profit are like enemies;
seeing the body as a dream,
one clings to excess, neglecting appearance.
Return to simplicity, embrace the subtle and serene.
Let your face be unwashed, your hair disheveled,
clad in paper robes and hempen garments.
When merit is complete, cast all aside,
and wander the vast expanse,
stepping upon clouds and rainbows.

---

**To the Tune of "Breaking Free from the Mundane"**

A steadfast foundation,
a tranquil gateway—
this life is unlike worldly ties.
In secluded, vast mountains,
enlightened beings of the highest order
meander, emulating immortals.
Diligently they labor before the cliffs,
slowly planting osmanthus and pines,
tending herb gardens and fields of lingzhi.
Beneath peaks ten thousand fathoms high,
they keep company with tortoises and cranes,
passing the years in ease.

My heart has long been set on the remote and strange,
loving the simplicity of bamboo baskets and gourd ladles,
mocking the clamor of poetry and prose.
By secluded caves and small streams,
I open my heart to joy,
sometimes composing short verses, sometimes long.
Racing horses outpace flowered stationery;
freely I wield my brush, chanting wildly,
moving through mist and flying smoke.
Unrestrained, in suchness I abide,
mingling through the days,
carefree and content.

---

**To the Tune of "Drunken Immortal in Penglai"**
**On the Ninth Day of the Ninth Month, the Liu Family of Xigu Holds a Ritual**

Suddenly, the Three Pure Ones’ cranes descend,
as clouds gather from ten thousand miles,
and the vast sky clears to emerald.
Jade chimes ring out,
stirring heaven and earth with their sharp tones.
All day, the fast is observed,
the empty hall hosts the ritual,
celebrating the great immortals’ grace.
Libations overflow in rosy cups,
long songs and wondrous melodies
linger in the master’s heart.

This double ninth day,
chrysanthemums bloom in profusion—
just as the Double Yang arrives,
the pure autumn air is finest.
Fragrant winds scatter,
and red osmanthus sways in the crisp breeze.
Such rare beauty is seldom met,
and the highest immortals are hard to encounter—
fortunate to meet in this moment.
Wild geese cast shadows on the sand,
moonlight illuminates the night,
and all grow mellow with wine.

---

**To the Tune of "Joy of Heaven"**
**Remembering Dharma Kin**

From the eastern shores of the sea,
originally of three provinces,
four of us formed a bond.
In foreign lands and distant towns,
we walked and sat together,
passing days in shared play.
We spoke of mysteries, discussed wonders,
exploring the pure emptiness beyond the world,
the true flavor of the Daoist path.
In leisurely song and response,
what deep meaning bound our dharma kin!

Now, scattered far apart,
each with苦志 and diligent heart,
we refine ourselves, each escaping collapse.
Since we drifted apart,
meetings have been rare,
separated by secluded mountains and distant passes.
Divided by heaven and earth,
we gaze like fading stars at dawn.
When shall we meet again,
riding clouds to pay homage to the Heavenly Emperor?

---

**To the Tune of "Han Palace Spring"**
**On Perseverance**

For twenty years,
the great demon’s host clashed with the true ranks,
a thousand layers of trials to cross.
Wild arrows from mad bows darkened the windows,
endless in their fall.
Yet through mindful awakening,
I passed the years,
unobstructed in the true source.
Wielding the sword of wisdom,
the demon horde naturally scattered,
and I alone displayed mighty power.

Moving in and out of the radiant light of the eight directions,
my divine mechanism was unfathomable,
even heaven’s net could not contain me.
Sweeping clouds, clearing mist, shaking the dharma-realm,
I left no trace.
Soaring and transforming,
I roamed the great void,
where the wind howled in desolation.
Patrolling the four seas,
how many peers shared this journey?

---

**To the Tune of "The Traveling Merchant Stays"**
**On Cultivating the Dao**

Meeting at the four origins,
passing Mount Hua,
we arrived together in the land of Qin.
Singing and laughing,
we subtly revealed the joyous essence of Chongyang.
The effortless way naturally transforms people;
fortunate to be guided by heaven’s will,
official duties and worldly hindrances intervened.
Eastward, by the sea,
the three lords’ noble righteousness
opened wide the gates of the teaching.

The teaching spreads universally.
Yet I, parted from the group,
forget my form, too weary to rise.
Looking inward, I find no fault;
what external calamities could I fear?
The three luminaries wax and wane,
intertwining with myriad changes—
favor and harm arise from heaven and earth’s design.
I will remain for now,
awaiting the day I achieve my ambition in the azure heavens,
and walk with ease.

---

**To the Tune of "Plum Blossom Melody"**
**Old Retreat at Pan Creek**

A nameless guest,
with no ties or burdens,
no mulberry or catalpa, no fields or home.
Before the ancient cliff,
beside the old pine,
I sing long songs, leaning on my armrest,
slowly pondering the Great Mystery.
In silence, I discuss the deathless—
in reality, what ever separated self and other?
Through a thousand scriptures,
in harmony with the three spirits,
I embrace all transformations,
all returning to a single, profound thought.

No weariness in walking,
no fatigue in sitting.
Whether walking or sitting, I follow my whim.
The evening wind is light,
the twilight sky clear.
The great Dao is carefree,
the upper and lower reaches of South Creek level.
East of the creek, I fortunately found a friend who forgets form;
beneath the moon, we often pour wine to pass the night.
When the wine cup pauses,
the moonlight shines pure.
I loosen my robe, let down my hair,
joyfully singing of the Dao’s sentiment.

---

**To the Tune of "Six Orders"**
**On Dharma Nature**

When the primordial simplicity scattered,
heaven and earth first took on their hues.
As the crow flew and the hare ran,
the myriad beings and kinds unfolded.
A single point of suchness, the true nature,
plunged into this foul skin-bag.
The wandering soul lost the Dao,
drifting with the waves,
for ten thousand years and a thousand ages, never returning home.

The body of the primal chaos was broken,
and love and hate gazed upon each other day by day.
Yet one mistakes the parents’ form
for one’s own fine appearance.
Age after age, trading bones in the wheel of rebirth,
suffering endless hardship and calamity.
Who awakens early,
seeks the path home,
and restores the radiant vastness of the old, auspicious state?

---

**To the Tune of "Fragrant Water Chestnut"**
**On Begging for Food**

What is the purpose of this?
Wandering idly through the village,
seeking rice to fill my hunger.
chunks.overlap_context:

The dharma-realm’s multitudes stir in turmoil,
dream-spirits drift through a thousand ages of longing.

Sunk in the flow—
bones traded like mountains,
who knows when the journey’s end will come?
Best to forge the true emptiness,
let the three luminaries’ wisdom shine,
gather the clouds of ten thousand kalpas.
In the end, one must cast off body and life,
yet how long will you cling to face and head?
Shatter the single point at the center,
and at once ascend the divine vessel to the other shore.

**To the Tune of "Joyous Oriole"**
**On Tempering the Heart**

Blocking the gate, a starving dog,
charging and leaping like flight.
Baring fangs, glaring eyes,
ready to tear at the heart,
to gnaw the skin of the living.
True, it guards the house,
yet knows no good from evil,
no high from low.
Pity this yelping creature—
through many lives, perverse and base,
its nature sunk in darkness.
Precepts expounded, teachings performed,
yet it snaps at the ear, deaf to all.
Though the Most High
descends in person,
there is no place for mercy.
For men, best to cultivate early.
If you wait until then,
your resolve will come too late.

**To the Tune of "Partridge Sky"**
**On Refining the Heart**

Leave behind birth and death.
Take old habits,
one by one, grind them away.
Through a thousand layers of desire,
a hundred temperings of body and mind,
forge the heart to iron.
Let the six spirits harmonize,
the three corpses cease their stumbling.
With fierce resolve,
rely on this empty space,
this passionless discernment.

Break the bonds.
Only then will you meet the perfected one,
who transmits the subtle oral formula.
Suddenly, a divine wind
blows open the demon’s ranks,
and your form stands like wood carved, like clay molded.
Once you attain the celestial jewel of true nature,
you see through spring flowers and autumn moon.
At that time,
ghosts cannot summon you—
only immortals may lift you up.

chunks.translated_text:
**To the Tune of "Phoenix Perched on Wutong"**
**Sent to a Dao-Seeker in the East**

Where in the world is the fairest scene?
The Eight Waters, the Three Rivers—
since ancient times, the road to Chang’an.
Broidered trees, screen-like mountains, winding and distant,
who can reach the ends of earth and sea?

Since you’ve left home, do so early.
Set forth on cloud and water,
do not linger for idle flowers and grasses.
Press on to Tong Pass, to the Western Peak’s temple,
and your breast will open wide with clarity.

---

**Two Poems**
**A Dao-Companion Visits Me at Pan Brook**

A rugged cliff, a realm of purity.
I hew the earth to house myself,
embracing the Dao, forgetting knowledge and understanding.
Do not think it strange, my Dao-companion,
that I, poor and idle, cling to simplicity with nothing to offer.

Wealth and honor, fame and rank—what can they lean upon?
So much right, so much wrong,
so many perils breeding success and failure.
Jade-like feasts and fragrant incense never endure,
while plain gourd and bamboo bowl bring lasting peace.

---

**Reflecting on the Past**

Today I ponder the days gone by.
I knew my future path,
yet time stretched long and hard to traverse.
Heaven gave no great blessing, no aid,
and suddenly I wished to leave, but had no way to go.

A walking corpse, a moving skeleton—my heart has awakened.
Dreams drift endlessly,
so for now I dwell at Pan Brook.
Fortunate to have left the mansions of the powerful and bold,
yet still they come, from time to time, to visit me.

---

**Third Poem**
**Expressing My Feelings**

The golden crow wheels west to greet the White Emperor.
I gaze east at the silver toad,
its bright glow enfolding the green cassia.
Gradually I knock at *Nanhua*, joining the chrysanthemum gathering,
filling my cup with the North Sea’s wine until I’m drunk.

Drunk, I lie amid the hues of Zhongnan Mountain.
The mountain’s colors are pure and lofty,
the night sky unobscured by clouds.
Not a bird sings, the wind is soft,
the moon bright as day, the heavens like water.

---

**To the Tune of "Double Swallows"**
**Spring Mountains**

Spring mist drifts lightly,
green mountains smile,
floating clouds scatter across the boundless sky.
Flowers gleam, stones glisten,
strange wonders emerge from grotto-heavens.
Doors and windows stand high as ten thousand fathoms,
so that ears and eyes may feast on the wind’s delight.
The passions of countless kalpas,
vast and clear, leave not a speck of dust.

How lovely—
carefree and at ease.
Shedding the shackles,
casting off karmic debts and enmities.
Wind as neighbor, moon as companion,
the Dao harmonizes with the crystal sounds of heaven.
Endless towering, sublime scenes
are all bestowed upon the mountain hall to share.
The thousand sages’ priceless pearl—
who can name its price?
Ask: who understands?

---

**To the Tune of "Ten Thousand Years of Spring"**
**Earthen Cavern**

As autumn comes to the earthen cave,
warmth gradually grows, the yang-qi prevailing.
Secluded dwelling—
how the Daoists favor it.
Laziness, poverty, and illness abound.
The bitter cold of winter,
leaves fallen, mountains and rivers cleansed.
Before the window, the contest:
snow flies, the wind rages.

**Leisurely Recitations by the Heat**

**II. Patchwork Robe**
With autumn’s arrival, the patchwork robe,
worn close, feels ever more fitting.
Frost-cleansed sky—
the heart roams free, unbound.
No fear of the west wind’s might.
Hundreds of scraps, thousands of stitches,
stitched firm from top to toe.
Loose yet proper,
outwardly wild in spirit,
inwardly radiant as a luminous pearl.

**III. Cuckoo**
In spring’s warmth, misty and clear,
the cuckoo cries all day in fragrant trees.
Each call a bitter plea,
urging one to return home—
yet where is home to go?
I long to journey east,
but find no path to take.
You, sir, raise the question—
what proof do you hold?
All is but idle chatter.

**IV. Startled from Sleep**
Deep autumn night, profound and still,
the water clock drips long—sleep heavy with thoughts.
One must rely on
the Dao’s harmony and ease,
not yielding to the demon king’s sway.
Gather the spirit,
casting all things from the heart.
Within the empty tent,
the lamp of wisdom shines bright.
Seated, I await the golden parrot’s song.

**The Immortal Who Endures Humiliation**
*For Yuan, the Clerk of Guoxian*

Beyond the world’s workings, heaven’s mysteries remain obscure,
while in the human realm, affairs never surpass this.
Though you be a hero, your rank the highest—
your body is but borrowed,
what more can greed and gluttony compel you to seek?
I eat when hungry, drink when thirsty,
my hempen robe needs no envy of brocade.
Beyond warmth and fullness, all perversity is restrained.
In the empty hall,
I recline, arm for pillow, legs stretched, sleeping clothed.

**II. Spring Rain (Two Poems)**

For years, the fields have languished in drought,
but this spring, rain and snow fall in abundance.
A clear omen—more than half the harvest is assured.
Come the time, we’ll see
a sky-reaching bounty, songs of joy filling the land.

In February, flowers bloom in patches,
a thousand willows line the embankments.
Again, they urge men to play the hero,
calling to one another,
flasks and jugs in hand, they scramble and race.

**Again**
The grace of heaven’s rain is met with universal celebration,
all living things upon the earth know no hunger.
Worry vanishes from furrowed brows.
Truly,
streets overflow, fields brim with the year’s yield.
Wine is brewed, guests are invited, songs exchanged,
feasts are laid, platters piled high.
Drunk and sated, the heart remains unshaken by foul desires.
Yet pride may overstep—
beware, for blessings may yet breed misfortune.

**III. Spring Delights**
Spring days, spring winds, spring’s beauty fair,
spring mountains, spring valleys flowing with spring waters.
Spring grasses, spring blossoms carpet the earth.
Riding spring’s momentum,
a hundred birds vie in song, contending in spring’s spirit.

The rains are rich as cream, the fields are fine,
the time of Cold Food Festival beckons for play.
Just right for flowers in bloom—
drunk through the night.
No cares to bind,
I let my jade-like form collapse, sleeping clothed.

**IV. Sensual Pleasures**
Arrogance soars to the heavens, feasting from tripods,
flutes and songs clamor, jade palaces arrayed.
Jade stirrups, flying dragons—robes and caps immaculate.
Gallantry runs wild,
unaware of the fall into the lapis lazuli well.

Slick as a thousand-fathom mirror, its walls gleam,
no path in or out where the ways cross.
Though you possess a clever, nimble nature,
your fate cannot escape—
you’ll but surrender your scalp’s shadow to him.

**V. Wondrous Use (Two Poems)**

Since ancient times, sages and worthies have followed one path,
from the very beginning, attainment arises from the heart.
Beyond this lies the land of carefree ease and peace.
No other principle—
naturally, the workings are serene and fair.

Not in toiling the spirit or tormenting the self,
but in letting go of all things, each becomes right.
Why choose the willow lanes or flower streets?
The body of emptiness
is originally one thing, without obstruction.

**Again**
Roaming the world without moving the body,
illuminating the human realm without using the heart.
Idly, I kick at the void, playing with it.
Clouds follow—
lightly gathered and released in all eight directions.

The rabbit-horn awl pierces to the bone,
the tortoise-hair whisk strikes the mountain heavy.
Sweeping away demons and spirits, leaving all empty.
A pure wind carries me—
riding the phoenix through the land of Great Peace.

**Immortal of Yellow Crane Cave**
*For Fellow Daoists*

All rush about in haste—
who will steadfastly hold fast?
North, south, east, west—all are the same,
beyond this, there is nothing more.
Wearing out iron shoes in confusion,
yet enlightenment lies not beyond the hermitage door.
When water flows, the channel forms naturally—
when the practice is complete, merit is fulfilled.

**II. Guoxian, Weinan, and the Luán Region**

This place’s scenery excels,
its people all in harmony.
Hidden among water and bamboo, dozens of households,
each knows the Mandate of Heaven.
I love the pure and empty landscape,
staff in hand, I seek secluded paths.
Each day, I wander the village once,
strolling at ease, reciting poems.

**III. Self-Portrait**

My homeland lies beyond the horizon,
a nameless scholar upon the sea.
Meeting the immortal of Zhongnan’s earth,
he brought me here to wander.
I have always loved the drifting tumbleweed,
the wild crane’s solitary cloud-like aspirations.
Straw hat on head, rain cape draped—
none know me,
yet this is the wind-madman.

**Gazing Toward Penglai**
*For Wang and Qiao, Two Disciples*

Wang Qiao’s land—
a melody most pure and fine.
Ancient paths wind and loop through water and stone,
weeping willows and eaves draped in mist and rosy clouds.
Peaches and plums interspersed with mulberry and perilla.
Within it dwell
two or three who uphold the Dao.
