chunks.original_text: 知命固穷皆淡薄，乐天清俭不奢华。 随分保生涯。 其二　秦川 秦川好，一片锦纹华。 日出雨晴山色秀，月明风急水声嘉。 千里净无涯。 余到此，喜庆复难加。 天佑时登堪养道，地灵人杰不生邪。 时复伴烟霞。 其三　南溪竹 南溪竹，腾秀入青冥。 直节虚心功未显，深根固蒂道先明。 霜雪岂凋零。 休怅恨，大器晚圆成。 自有孤高栖凤质，能教倜傥化龙形，他日看超升。 其四　游兴 飘蓬客，天赐水云闲。 自在行时无日月，相随到处有蓑蛮。 风雨亦开颜。 修炼事，地轴锁天关。 出有入无三尺剑，长生不死一丸丹。 名列上仙班。 青莲池上客#6　入关 重肠羽化登仙路，兄弟如何措。 各各勤修生觉悟。 通无入有，静思忘念，密考丹经祖。 一时浩劫真容露，放荡情怀任诗句。 直待人间功行具。 云朋霞友，爽邀风月，笑指蓬瀛去。 其二　幽栖 一从东别长安道，西往磻溪庙。 渐扣南山名迹杳。 洪沟冷淡，土龛潇洒，北府何曾到。 夜深陌上行人悄，独听岩前子规叫。 切切松梢啼到晓。 声声相劝，不如归去，争奈功夫少。 报师恩#7　嘲有髭僧
chunks.translated_text:
**On Knowing Fate**

To know fate and endure hardship with indifference,
to delight in heaven’s simplicity and frugality, never indulging in extravagance—
thus I preserve the course of my life.

**II. The Qin Plain**

The Qin Plain is fine,
a tapestry of brocade in bloom.
At sunrise after rain, the mountains gleam in beauty;
under bright moon and rushing wind, the waters sing their praise.
A thousand miles stretch boundless, pure and clear.

I have come here,
joy upon joy, beyond measure.
Heaven’s blessing in this timely ascent nurtures the Dao;
the land’s spirit and its noble people breed no evil.
From time to time, I keep company with mist and clouds.

**III. Bamboo by the Southern Stream**

Bamboo by the southern stream,
soaring in verdant splendor toward the azure void.
Upright in stem, hollow in heart—its merit yet unseen;
deep-rooted, firmly grounded—the Dao first made manifest.
How could frost and snow cause it to wither?

Do not grieve or resent,
for great vessels take time to perfect.
It bears the solitary, lofty nature of the phoenix’s perch,
and may yet transform the untrammeled into dragon form—
one day, watch it ascend beyond.

**IV. The Wanderer’s Joy**

A drifting tumbleweed,
heaven grants me the leisure of water and cloud.
When I wander at ease, time knows no sun or moon;
wherever I go, my rain cape and hat follow.
Even wind and rain bring a smile to my face.

The work of cultivation—
the earth’s axis locked with heaven’s gate.
Emerging from being, entering non-being: a three-foot sword;
eternal life, undying: a single elixir pill.
My name inscribed among the ranks of the immortals.

**The Guest by the Green Lotus Pond**

**Entering the Pass**

Feathered transformation, ascending the immortal’s path—
how should my brothers proceed?
Each must diligently cultivate awakening to life.
Traversing non-being to enter being,
in stillness, thoughts forgotten,
secretly studying the ancestral alchemical classics.

When the great calamity’s true visage is revealed,
my unbridled heart roams freely in poetic verse.
Only when merit and conduct in the world are complete
shall cloud companions and mist friends,
inviting the cool breeze and bright moon,
laughingly point the way to Penglai and Yingzhou.

**II. Secluded Dwelling**

Since parting eastward from Chang’an’s road,
I have journeyed west to the temple by Pan Stream.
Gradually, I sought the famed traces of Southern Mountain—
all faded into silence.
The vast gully lies desolate,
the earthen shrine refined,
yet I have never reached the northern abode.

Deep in the night, the path’s travelers grow still;
alone, I hear the cuckoo’s call before the cliffs.
Through the pine branches, its mournful cries persist until dawn,
each note urging:
*“Better to return—”*
Yet how can I, with so little cultivation?

**In Gratitude to the Master**

**Mocking the Bearded Monk**

**Gazing Toward Penglai**
*For Wang and Qiao, Two Disciples*

Wang Qiao’s land—

chunks.original_text: 不僧不道不温柔，九百人前不害羞。 觉性一时超法界，知身亿劫是吾囚。 改头换面人难悟，走骨行尸我不忧。 得意忘形还朴去，从教人笑不风流。 其二　渭南滦裹二首 一方胜景满川稀，水竹弯环四面围。 簇槛名花红冉冉，当门幽桧绿依依。 争歌稚子春风舞，斗巧灵禽晓树啼。 社内人家三十户，崇真修道压磻溪。 又 一横嘉景日常新，古栢森森四季春。 福地清高稀俗事，名坛时复会仙宾。 人人尽喜生中国，户户虔心敬上真。 唯愿诸公皆省悟，同登无漏出红尘。 其三　赠道友 神仙缥缈太虚私，世俗无由得见之。 幸遇门庭开教化，临逢斋醮莫推辞。 担家造孽常终日，作福治心只暂时。 更到时来心不谨，终身何以报恩慈。 其四　疏慵 懒看经教懒烧香，兀兀腾腾似醉狂。 日月但知生与落，是非宁辨短和长。 客来座上心慵问，饭到唇边口倦张。 不是故将形体纵，养成贫病疗无方。 金莲出玉花#8　得遇行化 重阳师父，昔日甘河曾得遇。 大道心开，设教东游海上来。 天涯回首，挈得吾乡三四友。 魏国升遐，惊动秦川百万家。 其二　自述 蓬头垢面，不管形骸贫与贱。 抱朴颐神，恬恢无忧乐本真。 冰姿玉体，到了难逃沉土底。 子羽潘安，泉下枯髅总一般。 其三　法门寺李生求 一团殠肉，千古迷人看不足。 万种狂心，六道奔波浮更沉。 天真佛性，昧了如何重显证。 宝范仙宗，觉后凭君豁蔽蒙。 其四　夏旱 时当正热，正值天高时雨阙。 万里晴晖，云欲生来风旋吹。 如炉天地，尽日炎炎镕暑气。 物困人疲，忆得前春嫌雨时。 其五　西虢南村 南村地胜，曲水横斜穿柳径。 是处池塘，拍塞荷花映粉墙。 高堂大厦，户户如屏堪入画。 峻岭崇岗，日日生云遥降祥。 其六　青峰 云收雨霁，露出青峰寒骨势。 野静天空，岌岌高横碧落中。 南溪无景，与尔炎天销日永。 永日题诗，不赋闲愁只赋伊。 其七　虢州与丹阳致魔作 登莱潍密，四海皆闻头插笔。 爱争多词，不肯饶人些子儿。 余今向道，非似从前生计较。 好弱都休，脑后如今没笔头。 悟南柯#9二首 下元醮乔生簪菊 白露三秋尽，清霜十月初。 群花零落共萧疏。 唯有重阳，佳景独魁梧。 烂熳真堪爱，馨香不可辜。 人人皆插满头敷。 试问乔公，簪着一枝无。 又 烂熳黄金药，轻盈白玉枝。 重阳留得下元时。 醮谢星官，特地献真师。 牒奏三天主，声闻九地司。 存亡福庆已潜资。 大道洪恩，兼付出家儿。 其二　赠裴满子 浩浩尘埃境，翩翩幻化躯。 中情不解了须臾。 任意奔波，颠倒走崎岖。 逗引中丹坏，销磨内藏虚。 悲愁灾患共萦纡。 百便千方，医疗不能除。 炼丹砂#10　赠西虢周道全 守分莫强图。 遣日闲居，乐天知命忍萧疏。
chunks.translated_text:
**Mocking the Bearded Monk**

Neither monk nor Daoist, nor gentle in demeanor,
Unashamed before nine hundred souls.
Awakened nature transcends the dharma-realm in an instant,
Yet this body, through countless kalpas, remains my prison.
A changed face and altered guise—none can fathom,
A walking corpse with wandering bones—no cause for my sorrow.
Exultant, I forget form and return to simplicity,
Let others mock me as unrefined.

**II. Two Poems from Weinan’s Lu Creek**

**I**
A rare vista fills the river plain,
Water and bamboo curve to encircle all sides.
Clustered railings bloom with crimson flowers,
Before the gate, verdant cypresses sway gently.
Children vie in song as spring winds dance,
Spirited birds contend in skill at dawn’s tree-tops.
Thirty households dwell within the community,
Their devotion to the true Dao outshines Pan Stream.

**II**
A splendid scene renews itself daily,
Ancient cypresses stand dense in four-season spring.
This blessed land, lofty and pure, shuns worldly affairs,
The sacred altar often hosts immortal guests.
Each rejoices in being born within the Middle Kingdom,
Every household reverently honors the Perfected.
If only all gentlemen would awaken,
Together ascending the leakless realm beyond the red dust.

**III. Presented to a Daoist Friend**

Immortals drift ethereal in the Great Void’s secrecy,
The worldly have no means to glimpse them.
Fortunate to encounter an open gate of teaching,
When fasting and rites arise, do not refuse.
Burdened by family, one sins all day long,
Yet cultivating fortune and refining the heart lasts but a moment.
Should carelessness arise when the time comes,
How then to repay such boundless kindness?

**IV. Indolence**

Too lazy to read scriptures, too lazy to burn incense,
Stupefied and reeling as if drunk and mad.
Sun and moon know only rise and fall,
Right and wrong—why discern short from long?
Guests arrive, yet my heart is too weary to inquire,
Food reaches my lips, yet my mouth is too sluggish to open.
Not that I deliberately indulge this body,
But poverty and sickness have left me no cure.

**Golden Lotus Emerges from Jade Flower #8: Encountering the Teachings**

**Master Chongyang**
Long ago at Gan River, I first met him—
Master Chongyang, whose heart opened to the Great Dao.
He established teachings and journeyed east to the sea,
Turning back from the ends of the earth,
He brought three or four friends from my homeland.
When Wei Guo ascended, it startled a million households in Qin Chuan.

**II. Self-Description**

Unkempt hair, a face caked in grime,
I disregard this frame’s poverty and lowliness.
Embracing simplicity, I nurture the spirit,
Content and carefree, delighting in true nature.
Though ice-pure and jade-fair,
All must sink into the earth in the end.
Whether a Zi Yu or Pan An,
Beneath the springs, all skulls are the same.

**III. For Li Sheng of Famen Temple**

A lump of foul flesh,
For ages deluding people, never enough.
Ten thousand kinds of restless thoughts,
Six paths of ceaseless rising and sinking.
The Buddha-nature innate and true,
How can it be obscured and not reawakened?
The treasure of the immortals’ lineage,
Once enlightened, dispels your delusions.

**IV. Summer Drought**

At the height of heat,
Under a lofty sky, timely rains are absent.
A thousand miles of clear radiance,
Clouds attempt to form but are scattered by the wind.
Heaven and earth like a furnace,
All day long, scorching heat melts the air.
Creatures languish, people grow weary,
Recalling last spring’s complaints of too much rain.

**V. South Village of Western Guo**

A land of excellence,
Winding waters meander through willow-lined paths.
Everywhere, ponds and embankments,
Lotus flowers press against powdered walls.
Lofty halls and grand mansions,
Each household like a painted screen.
Towering peaks and soaring ridges,
Day by day, clouds descend with auspicious omens.

**VI. Green Peak**

Clouds disperse, rain clears,
Revealing the Green Peak’s cold, bony majesty.
Wilds still, heavens vast,
Its towering form pierces the azure vault.
The southern stream holds no charm,
With you, I while away the scorching days.
All day I compose poems,
Not of idle sorrow, but of you alone.

**VII. To Dan Yang on Provoking Demonic Obstacles**

In Deng, Lai, Wei, and Mi,
Across the four seas, all know of the brush behind the ear.
Loving to argue, never yielding an inch,
I now walk the Dao,
Unlike before, no longer calculating gains.
Let go of strength and weakness,
For now, no brush remains behind my head.

**Awakening from Southern Branch #9: Two Poems**

**I. Offering Chrysanthemums at the Lower Prime Festival for Master Qiao**

White dew marks the end of autumn’s third month,
Clear frost arrives in the tenth.
All flowers wither in desolate decay,
Only the Double Ninth’s splendor stands tall.
Resplendent and lovable,
Its fragrance must not be wasted.
Everyone adorns their heads with clusters,
I ask Master Qiao—
Have you pinned even a single stem?

**II**
Resplendent golden elixir,
Light and graceful as a white jade branch.
The Double Ninth lingers at the Lower Prime,
Offering rites to the stellar officials,
Specially presented to the true master.
Petitions ascend to the Three Heavens’ Lord,
Voices reach the Nine Earths’ overseers.
Life and death, blessings and fortune, are subtly bestowed,
The Great Dao’s vast grace,
Also entrusted to those who leave the household.

**II. Presented to Pei Manzi**

A boundless world of dust,
A fluttering, illusory body.
The heart within never understands even a moment,
Yet recklessly it rushes,
Stumbling through rugged paths.
Enticed, the inner elixir is ruined,
Worn thin, the inner organs grow hollow.
Sorrow, calamity, and suffering entwine,
A hundred remedies, a thousand methods—
None can cure.

**Refining Cinnabar #10: Presented to Zhou Daoquan of Western Guo**

Abide by your lot, do not force ambition.
Pass the days in leisure,
Content with heaven’s decree, enduring solitude.

chunks.original_text: 万事休论成与败，兀兀前途。 失也本来虚，得也何如。 百年返覆乃须臾。 不似中心存道念，贤圣相扶。 清心镜#11二首　警杀生 万灵中，人最贵。 超群化，数属三才品位。 愚夫甚却骋凶顽，便将为容易。 杀害生灵图作戏。 全不念地狱，重重暗记。 一朝若大限临头，与他家恺气。 又 鬼神擒，鞭挞跪。 愁开眼，强欲思量巧计。 当头把业镜高悬，那冤家怎讳。 拔舌剜心酬快意。 全不似旧日，馨香美味。 三涂任百毒陵迟，再生人卒未。 其二　赠醮众信内一强公病噎 建斋筵，须省可。 休罗列，看食重重堆种。 本来要荐福求恩，却招殃惹祸。 强老先生还见么。 莫不是受用，於身太过。 如今纵百味珍羞，眼相看咽唾。 玉炉三涧雪#12 劝止同道杨公游海 最苦三冬冰雪，难当万里风尘。 天涯海角不离身，何处参同心印。 况是中丹宛转，徒劳外景因循。 争如作伴到青春，看我行藏远近。 其二　勤劳 物外虽分端的，天心未放玲珑。 区区陌上走西东。 也学浮生作梦。 梦寐更劳数载，岩龛复度三冬。 待他消息显真空。 放出凌云螮蝀。 其三二首　自咏 夜宿墦溪古庙，晓登竹径荒村。 日中无事馁巡门，淡饭求他一顿。 不会深穷造化，随缘且度朝昏。 是非人我绝谈论。 却返生前混沌。 又 一性昭彰乍显，二仪混合初融。 飘飘法界任西东，到处神光覆拥。 万籁寒泉凌顶，八方瑞霭腾空。 怡然独向九霄中。 坐看浮生作梦。 其四　暮景二首 杲日西沉远陇，轻飙南起洪崖。 飘飘逸兴爽情怀，吹断愁思俗态。 渐渐放开心月，微微射透灵台。 澄澄湛湛绝尘埃，莹彻青霄物外。 又 日落风生古洞，夜深月照寒潭。 澄澄秋色净烟岚，独弄圆明宝鉴。 认得心田要妙，咄回世俗贪婪。 自欣山谷卧松岩，情愿披粗食淡。 诉衷情　九日后作二首 纷纷霜叶乱飘扬，时令过重阳。 黄花烂熳依槛，犹自吐清香。 秋渐老，夜弥长，道情昌。 云庵入定法界，游仙不动凄凉。 又 孤城寒角韵悠扬，风送入斜阳。 池塘菡萏无色，兰畹有余香。 秋日短，暮天长，月华昌。 空空寂照荡荡，虚心一片清凉。 其二　风景 长安风景古今奇，吾道少人知。 天心地肺时正，生杀按枢机。 灵物秀，玉芝肥，射虹霓。 山头凝望目下，三川压尽华夷。 解冤结#13　赠醮众 山河已定，干戈不起，太平时、八方和义 。
chunks.translated_text:
**All Matters**

Let all matters of success or failure rest,
The path ahead stretches on, unyielding.
Loss is but emptiness from the start,
What then is gain?
A hundred years pass in but a moment’s turn.
Not so for one whose heart holds fast to the Dao’s thought—
Sage and saint lend their aid.

**Clear Heart Mirror #11: Two Poems**
*Admonishing the Taking of Life*

Among the ten thousand spirits, humans are most noble,
Transcending all, ranked among the Three Powers’ station.
Yet fools indulge in cruelty and folly,
Taking life as mere play.
They never consider the hells,
Layer upon layer of dark reckoning.
When the great limit arrives at last,
They shall answer for their deeds.

*Again*

Ghosts and spirits seize them, lash and force them to kneel.
Eyes open in dread, they strain to devise clever schemes.
Yet the Mirror of Karma hangs high above—
How can they hide from their foes?
Tongues torn out, hearts carved out to sate vengeance,
Nothing like the old days of fragrant feasts.
Through the Three Ways they suffer a hundred torments,
Rebirth as human? Not yet.

**II. Presented to a Certain Strong Elder Among the Offering Assembly, Stricken with Choking Sickness**

When setting up the feast for rites, take heed—
Do not heap dish upon dish in lavish display.
The intent was to seek blessings and grace,
Yet you invite misfortune and calamity instead.
Old Master Strong—do you see now?
Was it not indulgence,
Excess upon the body?
Now, though a hundred delicacies lie before you,
Your eyes can only watch as you choke on spittle.

**Jade Brazier and Three Streams of Snow #12**
*Advising Fellow Daoist Yang Against Voyaging to the Sea*

Most bitter are winter’s ice and snow,
Harder still to bear the winds and dust of ten thousand miles.
From the ends of the earth to the edge of the sea, you never leave the self—
Where then can you seek the seal of the heart’s unity?
Moreover, the inner elixir turns and shifts,
While you vainly chase external scenes.
How much better to keep company through the spring,
Watching my comings and goings near and far.

*II. Diligence*

Though beyond the world the truth is clear,
Heaven’s heart remains unyielding, its depths unseen.
Trudging east and west on dusty paths,
You but mimic the floating life’s dream.
Dreaming, you toil for years,
Passing three winters in mountain caves.
Wait for the message of true emptiness to appear—
Then shall the rainbow bridge rise into the clouds.

*III. Two Poems: Self-Reflection*

At night, lodging in an ancient temple by Fan Stream,
At dawn, climbing a bamboo path through a deserted village.
At midday, wandering door to door, hungry,
Begging a simple meal.
I do not delve deeply into the workings of creation,
But drift with fate through dawn and dusk.
All talk of right and wrong, self and other, I abandon—
Returning to the primal chaos before birth.

*Again*

One nature shines forth, suddenly revealed,
The Two Modes blend in their first fusion.
Lightly I roam the Dharma-realm, east or west,
Everywhere the divine radiance enfolds me.
A thousand cold springs cascade over my crown,
Auspicious mists rise in the eight directions.
Joyfully I ascend alone to the ninefold heavens,
Watching the floating life dream on.

*IV. Two Poems: Evening Scenes*

The bright sun sinks beyond distant ridges,
A gentle breeze rises from the southern peaks.
My carefree spirit soars, my mood refreshed,
Blowing away sorrow and worldly cares.
Gradually the moon of the heart unfurls,
Its faint light piercing the spirit’s terrace.
Clear and still, unstained by dust,
It gleams beyond the azure heavens.

*Again*

The sun sets, wind stirs in the ancient cave,
Deep night, the moon shines on the cold pool.
The autumn hues are limpid, mists and vapors pure,
Alone I play with the round, luminous mirror.
Recognizing the wondrous essence of the heart’s field,
I rebuke the world’s greed and craving.
Content, I lie in the mountain valley beneath pines,
Willing to wear coarse cloth and eat plain fare.

**Telling of Innermost Feelings: Two Poems Written After the Ninth Day**

Scattered frosted leaves swirl in flight,
The season has passed the Double Ninth.
Chrysanthemums bloom riotously by the railing,
Still exhaling their pure fragrance.
Autumn ages, nights grow long,
The Dao’s mood flourishes.
Clouded hermitage, entering samadhi in the Dharma-realm,
Wandering immortals, unmoved by desolation.

*Again*

A lone city, the cold horn’s notes drift,
Wind carries them into the slanting sun.
The pond’s lotuses have lost their color,
But the orchid’s marsh still holds lingering scent.
Short are the autumn days, long the evening sky,
The moon’s brilliance waxes.
Empty and still, vast and bright,
A heart of pure coolness.

**II. Scenery**

The scenery of Chang’an is wondrous through the ages,
Yet few know the Way.
Heaven’s heart and earth’s lungs are in perfect accord,
Life and death turn on the pivot of the mechanism.
Spiritual beings flourish, jade mushrooms grow plump,
Rainbows arch across the sky.
Gazing from the mountain’s height,
The Three Rivers overawe all beneath heaven.

**Untying Karmic Knots #13: Presented to the Offering Assembly**

The rivers and mountains are settled,
Weapons laid down, no war arises.
In this time of great peace,
The eight directions are harmonious and just.

chunks.original_text: 斋醮频修，盛答报、虚空天地。 谢洪息， 谙中慈惠。 千年一遇，神仙出世。 幸遭逢、 莫生轻易。 供养精严，但一岁、胜如一岁。 遇良辰、大家沉醉 其二　自咏 当初学道，凭空炼己，志冲天、人间无比。 放旷山林，次后复、逍遥云水。 过夷门、 又临秦地。 飘蓬十载，游程万里。 度关津、 崎岖迢递。 事事谙来，但悟了、般般总弃。 只随缘、布裘芒履。 其三　觅饭 北方一日，南方一日，共东西、四方交日。 梦寐沉沉，且往来、游行销日。 待他年、 道心开日。 百年短景，都来几日。 暗推排、 今朝明日。 不觉推排，到圣贤、佳音来日。 洞天开、是吾归日。 玩丹砂#14　游历 云水飘飘物外吟，醍醐默默醉中斟。 神仙活计道人心。 容易肯争三寸气，寻常不贮一文金。 清贫柔弱祸难侵。 其二　土埪避暑 仙院深沉古相青，森森寒影拂苔轻。 萧条终日爽人情。 洞冷不知门外暑，心闲唯觉腹中清。 达身浑似积冰凌。
chunks.translated_text:
**Frequent Offerings and Rituals**

Frequent offerings and rituals are held,
Abundantly repaying heaven and earth’s boundless grace.
Gratitude for the cessation of floods,
And for the compassion and kindness within.
A once-in-a-millennium encounter,
When immortals descend to the world.
Fortunate to have met this time—
Do not treat it lightly.
Offerings are made with utmost reverence,
Each year surpassing the last.
On auspicious days,
Let all sink into intoxication.

**II. Self-Reflection**

When first I sought the Dao,
I refined myself in emptiness,
My resolve soaring to the heavens,
Unmatched among mortals.
Roaming free in mountains and forests,
Later wandering clouds and waters.
Passing through Yi Gate,
Then arriving in Qin’s land.
Like a tumbleweed for a decade,
Journeying ten thousand miles.
Crossing passes and fords,
Through rugged and distant paths.
All affairs now familiar,
Yet once enlightened,
All is cast aside.
Simply following fate,
Clad in coarse robes and straw sandals.

**III. Seeking Sustenance**

One day in the north, one day in the south,
East and west alike—
Four directions, days intertwined.
In dreamlike torpor,
Coming and going,
Passing time in wandering.
Awaiting the day
When the heart of the Dao unfolds.
A century is but a fleeting scene,
How many days in all?
Silently counting,
Today and tomorrow.
Unnoticed, the counting leads
To the day of sages’ glad tidings.
When the grotto-heavens open—
That shall be my day of return.

**Roaming in Alchemy #14: Travels**

Clouds and waters drift, chanting beyond the mundane,
Sipping the nectar of stillness in drunken reverie.
The immortal’s livelihood—
The heart of a Daoist.
Easily yielding, unwilling to quarrel over trifling breath,
Ordinary in bearing, hoarding not a single coin of gold.
In pure poverty and gentle weakness,
Misfortune cannot invade.

**II. Sheltering from Heat in an Earthen Chamber**

The immortal’s abode runs deep, ancient pines verdant,
Cold shadows dense, brushing lightly over moss.
Desolate yet refreshing all day,
The mind at ease.
The grotto’s coolness oblivious to the heat beyond its gate,
The heart untroubled, the belly alone aware of clarity.
In such attainment,
The body is as pure as layered ice.

chunks.translated_text:
**III. Retreat from the Dao**

Sword trees, blade mountains—snow-bright edges cross,
A thousand torments, a hundred tortures, death yet life reborn.
A single dawn’s cry, blood streaming—how bitter the climb.
Needles pierce the flesh, still the pain lingers,
Steel blades flay the nature—how could it not ache?
Why then, in wanton abandon, forsake cultivation?

**Roaming in the Leakless #15: Delighting in the Dao**

Last year’s grain,
This year’s wheat—
The land swells like clouds, brimming full.
Years of plenty, an age of peace,
The common folk at ease.
Hearts content, leisure unbound,
Everywhere carefree, untroubled.
Hungry, they seek shelter;
Weary, they beg for a meal—
No village, no lane turns them away with scorn.

**II. Autumn Clearing**

The setting sun glows red,
Autumn waters grow still—
Rain passed, the azure sky like a mirror.
Hedge chrysanthemums bloom,
Border geese return,
The broad fields’ leaves scatter in flight.
Ascend the western hills,
Sip from the northern sea,
Drunken, the spirit roams the immortal realms.
Frost-chilled night, moonlight pure—
Bemused, the intoxication lingers, unshaken.

**III. The Borrowed Body**

A clot of pus,
A breath of three inches—
Used, yet no more than a puppet’s guise.
Boasting of form,
Strutting in vanity—
None willing to cease.
Skin of white jade,
Faces rouged and powdered,
All mere adornments of fleeting splendor.
Flesh rots, blood dries—
Go, gaze upon the wild wastes.

**Roaming Freely #16: Two Poems for Daoist Friends**

Seeds of good sown in the past,
This life’s blessed ground.
The Void responds—
Celestial perfected ones lend their guard.

chunks.original_text: 开坛阐化，垂恩普济。 凡一月、於中建成三会。 至日相呼，临时莫避。 乘斋且、散心游戏。 家中不足，眉头长系。 也则是、浮生过了半世。 又 忙裹偷闲，师前取意。 胜如那、苦求庸昧。 连朝抵暮，贪生不已。 也道我、为人过了一世。 假使狂图，兼能巧智。 多方便、蕴成家计。 儿孙有靠，金珠没底。 终比、精神较些憔悴。 桃源忆故人　答丹阳二首 虚空照耀明如镜，好弱头头皆应。 随逐状同形影，稍错还提正。 他人谗说浑虚佞，远道狂言无证。 切告后来休听，默默依贤圣。 又 故人别后闲吟罢，寂寞云溪潇洒。 百尺孤松影下，独弄周天卦。 清风皓月虽无价，妙手奇工难画。 欲向世间夸诧，谁是分真假。 好离乡#17　迷怀二首 独坐向南溪，一事无能百不知。 所爱冥冥烟雨后，东西。 云绽峨峨列翠微。 苍骨太虚齐，冉冉寒光映日飞。 何事中心看不足，忘归。 似有膏肓病着肌。 又
chunks.translated_text:
**Expounding the Dao and Transforming Through Ritual**

Altars opened to propagate transformation,
Grace bestowed for universal salvation.
Each month, within its span,
Three assemblies are convened.
On the appointed day, summon one another—
At the hour, none may shirk.
Ride the fast, let the heart wander in play.

At home, lacking sufficiency,
Brows forever knit in care—
Thus half a fleeting life is spent.
Yet stealing moments of leisure amid the bustle,
Seek meaning before the master’s gaze,
Far surpassing blind pursuit of ignorance.

From dawn till dusk, clinging to life without cease,
One claims, “I’ve lived this life for others.”
Even if wild ambition and cunning wit
Are marshaled in manifold schemes to build a household,
With heirs to rely on and gold and pearls in endless store,
Still, in the end, what compares to the spirit’s withering?

**Remembering the Peach Blossom Source: Two Poems in Reply to Dan Yang**

The Void shines bright as a mirror,
Every weak and strong point meets its response.
Chasing after it like shadow follows form—
The slightest error, and it corrects you.

Others’ slander is but empty flattery,
Distant paths’ wild words lack proof.
Warn those who come after: do not heed them,
Silently follow the worthy and sage.

**#17: Two Poems on Deluded Longing**

**I.**
Alone, I sit by the southern stream,
One thing I cannot do—
A hundred things I do not know.
What I love appears in the misty rain’s wake:
East or west,
Clouds part to reveal emerald peaks in ranks.

**II.**
Bones as pale as the Great Void,
A chill radiance glows, catching the sunlight in flight.
Why does the heart never tire of gazing?
Forgetting to return,
As if a sickness has seeped into the marrow.

**Again**

After parting from an old friend, the idle chant ends,
In solitude by Cloud Creek, free and untrammeled.
Beneath the shadow of a hundred-foot lone pine,
Alone, I cast the Zhou Tian hexagrams.

Pure wind and bright moon, though priceless,
Even the finest hand and wondrous craft cannot paint them.
Should I boast of them to the world,
Who could discern the true from the false?

chunks.translated_text:
**III.**
Amid the tangled grasses, I crouch alone,
Drumming my belly, I sing at ease in idle leisure.
A pillow’s wandering immortal dream now broken—
Yet my face remains glad,
Laughing and roaming where green peaks resound.

At noon, I unbolt the wicker gate,
Leaping and lingering to gaze at distant mountains.
Below the peaks, someone comes to ask the Dao—
I know it’s hard.
Leaping again, wordless, I laugh and turn away.

---

**Penglai Pavilion**
*Immortal Mountains*

Penglai’s towers—
Vast, vast, the mighty sea, deep and hard to cross.
Deep and hard to cross—
Raging waves surge and roar,
Angry breakers churn like snow.

On the eastern edge of Jade Empyrean, I’ve heard it said,
There lies a realm of emptiness, by nature set apart.
By nature set apart—
The Mount of the Great Turtle stands unmoved,
Mirage towers endure unbroken.

---

**II. Deluded Thoughts**

A sojourner of rosy clouds,
I wander west and lodge beside South Stream.
Beside South Stream—
A thousand fathoms of crimson cliffs,
Ten thousand trunks of verdant cypress.

My heart is empty—only pale clouds drift white,
I lift my head but see no hue of splendor.
No hue of splendor—
Vain blossoms scatter in confusion,
While the world clings to greed.

---

**Burning Heart Incense**
*Two Poems on Cultivating the Dao*

**I.**
The Great Dao has no form—
How can the square inch of the heart rely on it?
Yet in every person, wisdom and insight shine bright.
To subdue the host of desires,
To untangle the tangle of passions—
Be tranquil amid clamor,
Still amid busyness,
Clear amid turbidity.

Like an infant in disposition,
Like ice in embrace—
Once the cocoon is rent,
The former path is seen.
My words are utmost counsel,
Listen deeply with your ears.
Exert full effort,
Full resolve,
And full accomplishment.

**II.**

**II.**
When wild geese turn homeward,
The chrysanthemums blaze in the wilds.
I crouch by deep streams,
In ancient caves winding.
Solitary chanting in stillness,
Alone refining the returning elixir.
Yet night falls desolate,
The cave cramped,
Sitting in hardship.

One nature scattered,
Years spent lingering—
Only now does the cause and condition reveal itself.
Jade pearls reach the earth,
The moon of treasure pierces the heavens.
Thus I emerge, luminous,
Forgetting schemes,
Free from toil and strife.

---

**Two Self-Chants on Delayed Beginnings**

**I.**
A drifting idler, born a Qiu,
Dwelling in the east—
Dengzhou on the eastern road.
From youth, I severed the net of worldly ties,
Following my master west in wanderings.
Unfettered, adrift,
Like a lone leaf on the long river.
Let the red dust burn bright as day—
I drift with the clouds, untroubled.

**II.**
A carefree body beyond the world,
Like a wisp of idle cloud in the blue sky.
Let empty space bring forth auspicious signs—
I remain unstained by the slightest dust.
Roaming the eight directions of heaven,
I meet the three luminaries—
Sun, moon, and stars.
In stillness, no worldly affairs arise,
Only companionship as my neighbor.

---

Yin and yang shift,
Eternal as the ages.
Gain and loss are but fleeting moments—
Why cling to joy in life,
Or dread in death?

**On Life and Death**
Life and death, long and short years—
all within a hundred springs.
Turn and gaze:
Behold Mount Bei Mang,
where mounds rise in endless rows,
all alike.

The body is but a borrowed dwelling,
the nature a transient guest.
Where lies the true homeland?
Yet the six paths turn ceaselessly,
driven by fate’s whip.

Awakened, lay all down,
free from toil and torment.
No kin, no need to grieve for others—
guard only your own steps.

---

**Leaving the Sea of Suffering**
*For Zhou Daoquan of Xiguo*

I know your heart has long admired the good,
yet how can one shed the dust of fleeting splendor?
Though you wish to drift like tumbleweed,
your feet remain bound by worldly cords.

Swiftly the sun and moon race overhead—
take care not to squander time in vain.
The Dao of immortals lies close at hand,
but alas, the human heart remains unenlightened.

---

**Spring in Wuling**
*For Yang Wusheng of Weinan’s Birthday*

The new year has just begun,
all things stir to life,
as the season nears the Lantern Festival.
Auspicious mist descends from azure skies—
a celestial scion is born.

His bearing is noble, surpassing all in wit,
turning to the Dao, weary of worldly clamor.
Though rocks crumble and pines wither,
his years stretch far beyond—
tortoise and crane alike outlived.

---

**Roaming Clouds and Waters**
*Self-Reflection*

Stay—stay.
Dwell by the emerald cliffs,
free from schemes and cares.
I know my share is meager, my ties light,
and thus I remain obscure.

A fleeting phantom, I hide my name,
grasping at the passing seasons.
With the bold folk of Panxi’s shores,
I weave bonds of wonder and delight.

---

**Far-Reaching Gaze**
*For the Daoist Friends of Weinan’s Rite During Drought*

For nine summers, the heavens parch,
all things wither in the scorching heat.
This stems from the human heart,
which breeds needless strife.

Fine robes and sleek horses,
parading in grand processions,
while young and old waste their days
gathering in every village.

The petty cannot discern right from wrong,
yet Heaven judges high and low.
Our hearts differ—
why do their aspirations drift so aimlessly?

Awaken to sincerity, cultivate the fast,
chant the good through passing years.
I hope the Perfected will lift us,
empty-handed, in their embrace.

---

**Crows Crying at Night**
*A Warning Against Washing the Face*

Alas, the ways of the world—
people indulge their desires without restraint.
They speak of human nature,
spending their days in vanity.

Yin and yang reverse,
heaven and earth rise and fall.
Fortune fades, calamity comes—
how can sorrow be endured?

The year barely passes,
the belly’s hunger just sated,
yet they wash their faces, rinse their veins,
still chasing lust and greed.

Those without foresight
plant deep roots of disaster.
Before misfortune sprouts,
who understands the need for vigilance?

---

**Congratulations to the Sage at Dawn**
*A Still Night*

The setting sun sinks,
the ridges swallow the last light,
cypress and mist lock in cold.
By the southern stream, I sit alone,
listening to the wind carry
a cascade of murmuring springs.

Through the long night,
affairs fade, the spirit at ease,
I pluck the stringless zither.
When the azure bird descends with omens,
I shall prove myself a divine immortal
upon this earth.

---

**No Dreams Command**
*Against Extravagance*
*Two Poems*

People of the Shaanxi region, heed me:
in this blessed land, cultivate good karma.
Nowhere under heaven compares—
rich and poor alike walk the same path.

Beware—beware—
beware of excessive pride.

In the famine years of Huangtong,
ten thousand households knit their brows in sorrow.
Mouths open, yet no food—
tears fall like scattered pearls.

Roaming the eight directions of heaven,

Sun, moon, and stars.
In stillness, no worldly affairs arise,
Only companionship as my neighbor.

---

**Cloud Brook Reflects the Moon of the Heart: On Qiao’s Loss of His Wife**
Yin and yang shift,
Eternal as the ages.
Gain and loss are but fleeting moments—
Why cling to joy in life,
Or dread in death?
